					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Turkey</span></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 332 languages"   >
	<label id="p-lang-btn-label" for="p-lang-btn-checkbox" class="vector-dropdown-label cdx-button cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--weight-quiet cdx-button--action-progressive mw-portlet-lang-heading-332" aria-hidden="true"  ><span class="vector-icon mw-ui-icon-language-progressive mw-ui-icon-wikimedia-language-progressive"></span>

<span class="vector-dropdown-label-text">332 languages</span>
	</label>
	<div class="vector-dropdown-content">

		<div class="vector-menu-content">
			
			<ul class="vector-menu-content-list">
				
				<li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-ace mw-list-item"><a href="https://ace.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turuki" title="Turuki – Acehnese" lang="ace" hreflang="ace" data-title="Turuki" data-language-autonym="Acèh" data-language-local-name="Acehnese" class="interlanguage-link-target"><span>Acèh</span></a></li><li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-ady mw-list-item"><a href="https://ady.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A2%D1%8B%D1%80%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%B5" title="Тыркуе – Adyghe" lang="ady" hreflang="ady" data-title="Тыркуе" data-language-autonym="Адыгабзэ" data-language-local-name="Adyghe" class="interlanguage-link-target"><span>Адыгабзэ</span></a></li><li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-kbd mw-list-item"><a href="https://kbd.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A2%D1%8B%D1%80%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%B5%D0%B9" title="Тыркуей – Kabardian" lang="kbd" hreflang="kbd" data-title="Тыркуей" data-language-autonym="Адыгэбзэ" data-language-local-name="Kabardian" class="interlanguage-link-target"><span>Адыгэбзэ</span></a></li><li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-ang mw-list-item"><a href="https://ang.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrcland" title="Tyrcland – Old English" lang="ang" hreflang="ang" data-title="Tyrcland" data-language-autonym="Ænglisc" data-language-local-name="Old English" 					<div id="contentSub"><div id="mw-content-subtitle"></div></div>
					
					
					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-subjectpageheader">
</div><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in West Asia and Southeast Europe</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1320445320">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the country. For the bird, see <a href="/wiki/Turkey_(bird)" title="Turkey (bird)">Turkey (bird)</a>. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Turkey_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Turkey (disambiguation)">Turkey (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"Türkiye" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Türkiye (disambiguation)">Türkiye (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:TR" title="ISO 3166-2:TR">TR</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/.tr" title=".tr">.tr</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Turkey</b>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>a<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> officially the <b>Republic of Türkiye</b>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>b<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> is a country mainly located in <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> in <a href="/wiki/West_Asia" title="West Asia">West Asia</a>, with a smaller part called <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">East Thrace</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">Southeast Europe</a>. It borders the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> to the north; <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a> to the east; <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to the south; and the <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">Aegean Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> to the west. Turkey is home to over 86 million people;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Population&#95;of&#95;Turkey&#95;7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Population_of_Turkey-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> most are ethnic <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turks</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Turkey" title="Kurds in Turkey">Kurds</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Minorities_in_Turkey" title="Minorities in Turkey">largest ethnic minority</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Officially <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">a secular state</a>, Turkey has <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Turkey" title="Islam in Turkey">a Muslim-majority</a> population. <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a> is Turkey's capital and <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_and_towns_in_Turkey" title="List of largest cities and towns in Turkey">second-largest</a> city. <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> is its largest city and economic center. Other major cities include <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0zmir" title="İzmir">İzmir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bursa" title="Bursa">Bursa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Antalya" title="Antalya">Antalya</a>.
</p><p>First inhabited by modern humans during the <a href="/wiki/Late_Paleolithic" class="mw-redirect" title="Late Paleolithic">Late Paleolithic</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> present-day Turkey was home to <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_peoples_of_Anatolia" title="List of ancient peoples of Anatolia">various ancient peoples</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hattians" title="Hattians">Hattians</a> were assimilated by the <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">Hittites</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_peoples" title="Anatolian peoples">Anatolian peoples</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Classical_Anatolia" title="Classical Anatolia">Classical Anatolia</a> transitioned into cultural <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenization</a> after <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a>'s conquests, and later <a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Anatolia" title="Romanization of Anatolia">Romanization</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Byzantine" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine">Byzantine</a> eras.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Seljuk Turks</a> began migrating into Anatolia in the 11th century, starting the <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">Turkification</a> process.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Seljuk <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">Sultanate of Rum</a> ruled Anatolia until the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Anatolia" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasions of Anatolia">Mongol invasion</a> in 1243, when it disintegrated into <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">Turkish principalities</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;38–39&#95;19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016_38–39-19"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Beginning in 1299, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottomans</a> united the principalities and <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Rise of the Ottoman Empire">expanded</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_II" title="Mehmed II">Mehmed II</a> conquered <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul) in 1453</a>. During the reigns of <a href="/wiki/Selim_I" title="Selim I">Selim I</a> and <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>, the Ottoman Empire became a <a href="/wiki/Global_power" class="mw-redirect" title="Global power">global power</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From 1789 onwards, the empire saw major changes, <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">reforms</a>, centralization, and <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_nationalism_in_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Rise of nationalism in the Ottoman Empire">rising nationalism</a> while <a href="/wiki/Decline_and_modernization_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Decline and modernization of the Ottoman Empire">its territory declined</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the 19th and early 20th centuries, <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Muslims_during_the_Ottoman_contraction" title="Persecution of Muslims during the Ottoman contraction">persecution of Muslims during the Ottoman contraction</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Muslims#Russian_Empire" title="Persecution of Muslims">in the Russian Empire</a> resulted in large-scale loss of life and <a href="/wiki/Muhacir" title="Muhacir">mass migration into modern-day Turkey</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimea</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Pashas" title="Three Pashas">Three Pashas</a>, the Ottoman Empire <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_entry_into_World_War_I" title="Ottoman entry into World War I">entered World War I</a> in 1914, during which the Ottoman government committed <a href="/wiki/Late_Ottoman_genocides" title="Late Ottoman genocides">genocides</a> against its <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide" title="Armenian genocide">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Greek</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Assyrian genocide">Assyrian</a> subjects.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Tatz2&#95;23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tatz2-23"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-SchallerZimmerer&#95;24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SchallerZimmerer-24"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following Ottoman defeat, the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">Turkish War of Independence</a> resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Ottoman_sultanate" title="Abolition of the Ottoman sultanate">abolition of the sultanate</a> and the signing of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a>. Turkey emerged as a more homogenous <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Republic <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Proclamation of the Republic of Turkey">was proclaimed</a> on 29 October 1923, modelled on <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_reforms" title="Atatürk&#39;s reforms">the reforms</a> initiated by its founder and first president, <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Mustafa Kemal Atatürk</a>. Turkey <a href="/wiki/Turkey_during_World_War_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkey during World War II">remained neutral during most of World War II</a>, but was involved in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>. Several military interventions interfered with the transition to a multi-party system.
</p><p>Turkey is an <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_income" title="Gross national income">upper-middle-income</a> and <a href="/wiki/Emerging_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Emerging country">emerging country</a>; <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Turkey" title="Economy of Turkey">its economy</a> is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">16th-largest by nominal</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">11th-largest by PPP-adjusted GDP</a>. As the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_electricity_production" title="List of countries by electricity production">15th-largest electricity</a> producer in the world, Turkey aims to become a hub for regional energy transportation. It is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> presidential <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">republic</a>. Turkey is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>, <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Turkic_States" title="Organization of Turkic States">Organization of Turkic States</a>. With a geopolitically significant location, Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> member and has <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO#Military_personnel" title="Member states of NATO">its second-largest military force</a>. It may be recognized as an <a href="/wiki/Emerging_power" title="Emerging power">emerging</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional</a> power. As <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">an EU candidate</a>, Turkey is part of the <a href="/wiki/EU_Customs_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="EU Customs Union">EU Customs Union</a>.
</p><p>Turkey has coastal plains, <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Turkey" title="Geography of Turkey">a high central plateau</a>, and various mountain ranges with rising elevation eastwards. <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Turkey" title="Climate of Turkey">Turkey's climate</a> is diverse, ranging from <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Temperate_climates" class="mw-redirect" title="Temperate climates">temperate climates</a> to <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-arid">semi-arid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental</a> types. Home to three <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot" title="Biodiversity hotspot">biodiversity hotspots</a>, Turkey is prone to <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_Turkey" title="List of earthquakes in Turkey">frequent earthquakes</a> and is <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Turkey" title="Climate change in Turkey">highly vulnerable to climate change</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey has <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Turkey" title="Health care in Turkey">a universal healthcare system</a>, growing <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Turkey" title="Education in Turkey">access to education</a>, and increasing levels of <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">innovativeness</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is a leading <a href="/wiki/Turkish_television_drama" title="Turkish television drama">TV content</a> exporter.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> With numerous UNESCO <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">World Heritage</a> sites and <a href="/wiki/Intangible_cultural_heritage" title="Intangible cultural heritage">intangible cultural heritage</a> inscriptions, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">a rich and diverse cuisine</a>, Turkey is the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings" title="World Tourism rankings">fourth most visited country</a> in the world.
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Etymology">Etymology</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Turkey" title="Name of Turkey">Name of Turkey</a></div>
<p><i>Turchia</i>, meaning "the land of the Turks", had begun to be used in European texts for <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> by the end of the 12th century.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Everett&#95;32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Everett-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As a word in <a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic languages</a>, <i>Turk</i> may mean "strong, strength, ripe" or "flourishing, in full strength".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It may also mean ripe as in for a fruit or "in the prime of life, young, and vigorous" for a person.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As an <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonym</a>, the etymology is still unknown.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In addition to usage in languages such as Chinese in the 6th century,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Everett&#95;32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Everett-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the earliest mention of <i>Turk</i> (<span title="Old Turkic-language text"><span lang="otk" dir="rtl">𐱅𐰇𐰺𐰜</span></span>, <span title="Old Turkic-language romanization"><i lang="otk-Latn">türü̲k̲</i></span>; or <span title="Old Turkic-language text"><span lang="otk" dir="rtl">𐱅𐰇𐰼𐰚</span></span>, <span title="Old Turkic-language romanization"><i lang="otk-Latn">türk/tẄrk</i></span>) in Turkic languages comes from the <a href="/wiki/Second_Turkic_Khaganate" title="Second Turkic Khaganate">Second Turkic Khaganate</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Byzantine" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine">Byzantine</a> sources in the 10th century, the name <i><a href="/wiki/Tourkia_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Tourkia (disambiguation)">Tourkia</a></i> was used for defining two medieval states: <a href="/wiki/Tourkia_(Hungary)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tourkia (Hungary)">Hungary</a> (<i>Western Tourkia</i>); and <a href="/wiki/Tourkia_(Khazaria)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tourkia (Khazaria)">Khazaria</a> (<i>Eastern Tourkia</i>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-constantine&#95;vii&#95;37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constantine_vii-37"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate" title="Mamluk Sultanate">Mamluk Sultanate</a>, with its ruling elite of Turkic origin, was called the "State of the Turks" (<span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">Dawlat at-Turk</i></span>, or <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">Dawlat al-Atrāk</i></span>, or <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">Dawlat-at-Turkiyya</i></span>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkestan, also meaning the "land of the Turks", was used for a historic region in <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">Middle English</a> usage of <span title="Middle English (1100-1500)-language text"><i lang="enm">Turkye</i></span> or <span title="Middle English (1100-1500)-language text"><i lang="enm">Turkeye</i></span> is found in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Book_of_the_Duchess" title="The Book of the Duchess">The Book of the Duchess</a></i> (written in 1369–1372) to refer to Anatolia or the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The modern spelling <i>Turkey</i> dates back to at least 1719.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Turkey_(bird)" title="Turkey (bird)">bird called turkey</a> was named as such due to trade of <a href="/wiki/Guineafowl" class="mw-redirect" title="Guineafowl">guineafowl</a> from Turkey to England.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Everett&#95;32-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Everett-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The name <i>Turkey</i> has been used in international treaties referring to the Ottoman Empire.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> With the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Alexandropol" title="Treaty of Alexandropol">Treaty of Alexandropol</a> in 1920, the name <i>Türkiye</i> entered international documents for the first time. In the treaty signed with <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Afghanistan" title="Emirate of Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> in 1921, the expression <span title="Ottoman Turkish (1500-1928)-language romanization"><i lang="ota-Latn">Devlet-i Âliyye-i Türkiyye</i></span> ("Sublime Turkish State") was used, likened to the Ottoman Empire's name.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2021, President <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">Recep Tayyip Erdoğan</a> called for expanded official usage of <i>Türkiye</i>, saying that <i>Türkiye</i> "represents and expresses the culture, civilization, and values of the Turkish nation in the best way".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Genelge-2021/24&#95;45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Genelge-2021/24-45"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In May 2022, the Turkish government requested the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> and other international organizations to use <i>Türkiye</i> officially in English; the UN agreed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="History">History</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Turkey" title="History of Turkey">History of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Anatolia" title="History of Anatolia">History of Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Thrace" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Thrace">History of Thrace</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_regions_of_Anatolia" title="Ancient regions of Anatolia">Ancient regions of Anatolia</a></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Prehistory_and_ancient_history">Prehistory and ancient history</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Anatolia" title="Prehistory of Anatolia">Prehistory of Anatolia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Southeast_Europe" title="Prehistory of Southeast Europe">Prehistory of Southeast Europe</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Hattians" title="Hattians">Hattians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">Hittites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luwians" title="Luwians">Luwians</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pala_(Anatolia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pala (Anatolia)">Pala (Anatolia)</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe,_Urfa.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/250px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/500px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848" /></a><figcaption>Some <a href="/wiki/Henge" title="Henge">henges</a> at <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="Göbekli Tepe">Göbekli Tepe</a> were erected as far back as <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe#Large_enclosures" title="Göbekli Tepe">9600 BC</a>, predating those of <a href="/wiki/Stonehenge" title="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a> by over seven millennia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ArchMag&#95;49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArchMag-49"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Present-day Turkey has been inhabited by <a href="/wiki/Modern_humans" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern humans">modern humans</a> since the <a href="/wiki/Late_Paleolithic" class="mw-redirect" title="Late Paleolithic">late Paleolithic</a> period and contains some of the world's oldest <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> sites.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;24&#95;50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016_24-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-MET&#95;51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MET-51"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="Göbekli Tepe">Göbekli Tepe</a> is close to 12,000 years old.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;24&#95;50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016_24-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Parts of <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> include the <a href="/wiki/Fertile_Crescent" title="Fertile Crescent">Fertile Crescent</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Origin_of_agriculture" class="mw-redirect" title="Origin of agriculture">origin of agriculture</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other important Anatolian Neolithic sites include <a href="/wiki/%C3%87atalh%C3%B6y%C3%BCk" title="Çatalhöyük">Çatalhöyük</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alaca_H%C3%B6y%C3%BCk" title="Alaca Höyük">Alaca Höyük</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-3&#95;53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-3-53"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Neolithic Anatolian farmers differed genetically from farmers in <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jordan_Valley" title="Jordan Valley">Jordan Valley</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto3&#95;54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-54"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These early Anatolian farmers also <a href="/wiki/Early_European_Farmers" title="Early European Farmers">migrated into Europe</a>, starting around 9,000 years ago.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto3&#95;54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-54"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Troy" title="Troy">Troy</a>'s earliest layers go back to around 4500 BC.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-3&#95;53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-3-53"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Empire_of_the_Hitties.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Empire_of_the_Hitties.png/250px-Empire_of_the_Hitties.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="155" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Empire_of_the_Hitties.png/500px-Empire_of_the_Hitties.png 1.5x" data-file-width="2373" data-file-height="1469" /></a><figcaption>Map of the Hittite Empire at its greatest extent, with Hittite rule <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1300 BC</span></figcaption></figure>
<p>Anatolia's historical records start with <a href="/wiki/Clay_tablets" class="mw-redirect" title="Clay tablets">clay tablets</a> from approximately around 2000 BC that were found in modern-day <a href="/wiki/K%C3%BCltepe" title="Kültepe">Kültepe</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-4&#95;57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-4-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These tablets belonged to an <a href="/wiki/Karum_(trade_post)" title="Karum (trade post)">Assyrian trade colony</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-4&#95;57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-4-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The languages in Anatolia at that time included Hattian, Hurrian, <a href="/wiki/Hittite_language" title="Hittite language">Hittite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luwian" class="mw-redirect" title="Luwian">Luwian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Palaic" class="mw-redirect" title="Palaic">Palaic</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-McMahon&#95;Steadman&#95;2012&#95;p&#95;234&#95;58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McMahon_Steadman_2012_p_234-58"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hattic_language" title="Hattic language">Hattian</a> was a language indigenous to Anatolia, with no known modern-day connections.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-McMahon&#95;Steadman&#95;2012&#95;p&#95;234&#95;58-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McMahon_Steadman_2012_p_234-58"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hurrian_language" title="Hurrian language">Hurrian language</a> was used in northern <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-McMahon&#95;Steadman&#95;2012&#95;p&#95;234&#95;58-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McMahon_Steadman_2012_p_234-58"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Hittite, Palaic, and Luwian languages were "the oldest written <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European languages</a>",<sup id="cite&#95;ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> forming the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_languages" title="Anatolian languages">Anatolian sub-group</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-McMahon&#95;Steadman&#95;2012&#95;p&#95;522&#95;61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McMahon_Steadman_2012_p_522-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>c<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Hattians" title="Hattians">Hattian</a> rulers were gradually replaced by <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">Hittite</a> rulers.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-4&#95;57-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-4-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Hittite kingdom was a large kingdom in Central Anatolia, with its capital of <a href="/wiki/Hattusa" title="Hattusa">Hattusa</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-4&#95;57-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-4-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It co-existed in Anatolia with <a href="/wiki/Pala_(Anatolia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pala (Anatolia)">Palaians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luwians" title="Luwians">Luwians</a>, approximately between 1700 and 1200 BC.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-4&#95;57-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-4-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As the Hittite kingdom was disintegrating, further waves of Indo-European peoples migrated from southeastern Europe, which was followed by warfare.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Thracians" title="Thracians">Thracians</a> were also present in modern-day <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Thrace" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Thrace">Turkish Thrace</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto5&#95;67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-67"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is not known if the <a href="/wiki/Trojan_War" title="Trojan War">Trojan War</a> is based on historical events.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Late_Bronze_Age_Troy" title="Late Bronze Age Troy">Troy's Late Bronze Age</a> layers matches most with <i><a href="/wiki/Iliad" title="Iliad">Iliad</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s story.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Early_classical_antiquity">Early classical antiquity</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Classical_Anatolia" title="Classical Anatolia">Classical Anatolia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Phrygia" title="Phrygia">Phrygia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">Lydia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lycia" title="Lycia">Lycia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caria" title="Caria">Caria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Urartu" title="Urartu">Urartu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenization</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic period</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Lycian_Way_-_2014.10_-_panoramio.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/The_Lycian_Way_-_2014.10_-_panoramio.jpg/250px-The_Lycian_Way_-_2014.10_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/The_Lycian_Way_-_2014.10_-_panoramio.jpg/500px-The_Lycian_Way_-_2014.10_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Lycian_Way" title="Lycian Way">Lycian Way</a> is a 760 kilometers (470&#160;mi) long hiking path in Southwestern Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Around 750 BC, <a href="/wiki/Phrygia" title="Phrygia">Phrygia</a> had been established, with its two centers in <a href="/wiki/Gordium" class="mw-redirect" title="Gordium">Gordium</a> and modern-day <a href="/wiki/Kayseri" title="Kayseri">Kayseri</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-2&#95;71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-2-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Phrygians" title="Phrygians">Phrygians</a> spoke an Indo-European language, which was closer to <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a> than Anatolian languages.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-McMahon&#95;Steadman&#95;2012&#95;p&#95;522&#95;61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McMahon_Steadman_2012_p_522-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Phrygians shared Anatolia with <a href="/wiki/Neo-Hittites" class="mw-redirect" title="Neo-Hittites">Neo-Hittites</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urartu" title="Urartu">Urartu</a>. Luwian-speakers were probably the majority in various Anatolian Neo-Hittite states.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Urartians spoke a non-Indo-European language and their capital was around <a href="/wiki/Lake_Van" title="Lake Van">Lake Van</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-2&#95;71-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-2-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Urartu and Phrygia fell in seventh century BC.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-2&#95;71-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-2-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> They were replaced by <a href="/wiki/Carians" title="Carians">Carians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lycians" title="Lycians">Lycians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lydians" title="Lydians">Lydians</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These three cultures "can be considered a reassertion of the ancient, indigenous culture of the Hattian cities of Anatolia".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;74-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the late <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a>, there were three<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bryce&#95;2012&#95;pp369–370&#95;75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bryce_2012_pp369–370-75"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> or four<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Britannica&#95;76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-76"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Greek-speaking settlements in Anatolia, including <a href="/wiki/Miletus" title="Miletus">Miletus</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bryce&#95;2012&#95;pp369–370&#95;75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bryce_2012_pp369–370-75"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Britannica&#95;76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-76"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Around 1000 BC, <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age_Greek_migrations" title="Iron Age Greek migrations">Greeks started migrating</a> to the west coast of Anatolia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-2&#95;71-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-2-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These eastern Greek settlements played a vital role in shaping the Archaic Greek civilization;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-2&#95;71-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-2-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> important <a href="/wiki/Polis" title="Polis">cities</a> included <a href="/wiki/Miletus" title="Miletus">Miletus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">Ephesus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Halicarnassus" title="Halicarnassus">Halicarnassus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smyrna" title="Smyrna">Smyrna</a> (now <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0zmir" title="İzmir">İzmir</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantium</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These settlements were grouped as <a href="/wiki/Aeolis" title="Aeolis">Aeolis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ionia" title="Ionia">Ionia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Doric_hexapolis" class="mw-redirect" title="Doric hexapolis">Doris</a>, after the specific Greek groups that settled them.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Further Greek colonization in Anatolia was led by Miletus and <a href="/wiki/Megara" title="Megara">Megara</a> in 750–480 BC.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/250px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="194" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/500px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="9163" data-file-height="7100" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Celsus" title="Library of Celsus">Library of Celsus</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">Ephesus</a> was built by the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Romans</a> in 114–117.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus</a> attacked eastern Anatolia in 547 BC, and <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a> eventually <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Sardis_(547_BC)" title="Siege of Sardis (547 BC)">expanded into western Anatolia</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;74-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the east, the <a href="/wiki/Satrapy_of_Armenia" title="Satrapy of Armenia">Armenian province</a> was part of the Achaemenid Empire.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-2&#95;71-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-2-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">Greco-Persian Wars</a>, the Greek city-states of the Anatolian Aegean coast regained independence, but most of the interior stayed part of the Achaemenid Empire.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;74-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Two of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">Seven Wonders of the Ancient World</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Artemis" title="Temple of Artemis">Temple of Artemis</a> in Ephesus, and the <a href="/wiki/Mausoleum_of_Halicarnassus" class="mw-redirect" title="Mausoleum of Halicarnassus">Mausoleum of Halicarnassus</a>, were located in Anatolia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Following the victories of Alexander in <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Granicus" title="Battle of the Granicus">334 BC</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Issus" title="Battle of Issus">333 BC</a>, the Achaemenid Empire collapsed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;74-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This led to increasing cultural homogeneity and <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenization</a> of Anatolia,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which met resistance in some places.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;a&#95;87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016_a-87"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following Alexander's death, the <a href="/wiki/Seleucids" class="mw-redirect" title="Seleucids">Seleucids</a> ruled large parts of Anatolia, while native Anatolian states emerged in the Marmara and Black Sea areas. In eastern Anatolia, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Armenia_(antiquity)" title="Kingdom of Armenia (antiquity)">the kingdom of Armenia</a> appeared.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In third century BC, <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a> invaded central Anatolia and continued as a major ethnic group in the area for around 200 years. They were known as the <a href="/wiki/Galatians_(people)" title="Galatians (people)">Galatians</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Rome_and_Byzantine_Empire">Rome and Byzantine Empire</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Classical_Anatolia" title="Classical Anatolia">Classical Anatolia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Anatolia" title="Byzantine Anatolia">Byzantine Anatolia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Anatolia" title="Romanization of Anatolia">Romanization of Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Turkey" title="Christianity in Turkey">Christianity in Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Justinian555AD.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Justinian555AD.png/250px-Justinian555AD.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="135" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Justinian555AD.png/500px-Justinian555AD.png 1.5x" data-file-width="2111" data-file-height="1144" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Eastern Roman (Byzantine) Empire</a> in 555 under <a href="/wiki/Justinian_the_Great" class="mw-redirect" title="Justinian the Great">Justinian the Great</a>, at its greatest extent</figcaption></figure>
<p>When <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Pergamon" title="Kingdom of Pergamon">Pergamon</a> requested assistance in its conflict with the Seleucids, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Rome</a> intervened in Anatolia in the second century BC. Without an heir, Pergamum's king left the kingdom to Rome, which was annexed as <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="Province of Asia">province of Asia</a>. Roman influence grew in Anatolia afterwards.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following <a href="/wiki/Asiatic_Vespers" title="Asiatic Vespers">Asiatic Vespers</a> massacre, and <a href="/wiki/Mithridatic_Wars" title="Mithridatic Wars">Mithridatic Wars</a> with <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Pontus" title="Kingdom of Pontus">Pontus</a>, Rome emerged victorious. Around the 1st century BC, <a href="/wiki/Roman_province" title="Roman province">Rome expanded into parts of Pontus and Bithynia</a>, while turning rest of Anatolian states into Roman satellites.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Several <a href="/wiki/Roman%E2%80%93Parthian_Wars" title="Roman–Parthian Wars">conflicts with Parthians ensued</a>, with peace and wars alternating.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a>, early Christian Church had significant growth in Anatolia because of <a href="/wiki/St_Paul" class="mw-redirect" title="St Paul">St Paul</a>'s efforts. Letters from St. Paul in Anatolia comprise the <a href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" title="Early Christianity">oldest Christian literature</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto6&#95;93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto6-93"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under Roman authority, <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_councils" class="mw-redirect" title="Ecumenical councils">ecumenical councils</a> such as <a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Nicaea" title="First Council of Nicaea">Council of Nicaea (Iznik)</a> in 325 served as a guide for developing "orthodox expressions of basic Christian teachings".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto6&#95;93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto6-93"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Aya_Sophia_(7144824757).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Aya_Sophia_%287144824757%29.jpg/250px-Aya_Sophia_%287144824757%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="125" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Aya_Sophia_%287144824757%29.jpg/500px-Aya_Sophia_%287144824757%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2449" data-file-height="1225" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a> in <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>) was built by the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Roman">Eastern Roman</a> emperor <a href="/wiki/Justinian_the_Great" class="mw-redirect" title="Justinian the Great">Justinian the Great</a> in 532–537.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>The Byzantine Empire, also referred to as the Eastern Roman Empire, was the continuation of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> centered in <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> during <a href="/wiki/Late_Antiquity" class="mw-redirect" title="Late Antiquity">Late Antiquity</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>. The eastern half of the Empire survived the conditions that caused the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">fall of the West</a> in the 5th century AD, and continued to exist until the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">fall of Constantinople</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> in 1453. During most of its existence, the empire remained the most powerful economic, cultural, and military force in the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_world" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean world">Mediterranean world</a>. The term <i>Byzantine Empire</i> was only coined following the empire's demise; its citizens referred to the polity as the "Roman Empire" and to themselves as <i>Romans</i>. Due to the imperial seat's move from Rome to <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantium</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_as_the_Roman_state_religion" title="Christianity as the Roman state religion">adoption of Christianity as the state religion</a>, and the predominance of <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Greek" title="Medieval Greek">Greek</a> instead of <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>, modern historians continue to make a distinction between the earlier <i>Roman Empire</i> and the later <i>Byzantine Empire</i>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2024)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In the early Byzantine Empire period, the Anatolian coastal areas were Greek speaking. In addition to natives, interior Anatolia had diverse groups such as <a href="/wiki/Goths" title="Goths">Goths</a>, <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persians" title="Persians">Persians</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_the_Byzantine_Empire" title="History of the Jews in the Byzantine Empire">Jews</a>. Interior Anatolia had been "heavily Hellenized".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Horrocks&#95;pp&#95;778-779&#95;95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Horrocks_pp_778-779-95"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_languages" title="Anatolian languages">Anatolian languages</a> eventually became extinct after <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenization</a> of Anatolia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Seljuks_and_Anatolian_beyliks">Seljuks and Anatolian beyliks</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Seljuk Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">Sultanate of Rum</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">Anatolian beyliks</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Turkic_migration" title="Turkic migration">Turkic migration</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Turks" title="Oghuz Turks">Oghuz Turks</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">Turkification</a></div>

id="annotation&#95;210x90" style="position:absolute; left:210px; top:90px; font-size:6.5px; font-weight:bold; font-size:6.5; line-height:8.5px; text-align:center;"><span style="color:#4F311CFF">PECHENEGS</span></a></span></div><div id="annotation&#95;25x105" style="position:absolute; left:25px; top:105px; font-size:6.5px; font-weight:bold; font-size:6.5; line-height:8.5px; text-align:center;"><span style="background-color:transparent; color:#000000;"><a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate"><span class="mw-no-invert"
