line-height:8.5px; text-align:center;"><span style="background-color:transparent; color:#000000;"><a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Georgia" title="Kingdom of Georgia"><span class="mw-no-invert" style="color:#4F311CFF">GEORGIA</span></a></span></div><div id="annotation&#95;1x40" style="position:absolute; left:1px; top:40px; font-size:6.5px; font-weight:bold; font-size:6.5; line-height:8.5px; text-align:center;"><span style="background-color:transparent; color:#000000;"><a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire"><span class="mw-no-invert" style="color:#4F311CFF">BYZANTINE<br />EMPIRE</span></a></span></div><div id="annotation&#95;50x60" style="position:absolute; left:50px; top:60px; font-size:6.5px; font-weight:bold; font-size:6.5; line-height:8.5px; text-align:center;"><span style="background-color:transparent; color:#000000;"><a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum"><span class="mw-no-invert" style="color:#4F311CFF">RUM</span></a></span></div><div id="annotation&#95;245x145" style="position:absolute; left:245px; top:145px; font-size:6.5px; font-weight:bold; font-size:6.5; line-height:8.5px; text-align:center;"><span style="background-color:transparent; color:#000000;"><a href="/wiki/Seuna_(Yadava)_dynasty" title="Seuna (Yadava) dynasty"><span class="mw-no-invert" style="color:#4F311CFF">YADAVAS</span></a></span></div><div id="annotation&#95;186x45" style="position:absolute; left:186px; top:45px; font-size:6.5px; font-weight:bold; font-size:6.5; line-height:8.5px; text-align:center;"><span style="background-color:transparent; color:#000000;"><a href="/wiki/Kara-Khanid_Khanate" title="Kara-Khanid Khanate"><span class="mw-no-invert" style="color:#4F311CFF">KARAKHANID KHANATE</span></a></span></div><div id="annotation&#95;272x155" style="position:absolute; left:272px; top:155px; font-size:12px; font-weight:bold; font-size:12; line-height:14px; text-align:center;"><span style="background-color:transparent; color:#000000;"><a href="/wiki/Template:Continental_Asia_in_1000_CE" title="Template:Continental Asia in 1000 CE"><span class="mw-no-invert" style="color:#4F311CFF"> ◁ </span></a> <a href="/wiki/Template:Continental_Asia_in_1200_CE" title="Template:Continental Asia in 1200 CE"><span class="mw-no-invert" style="color:#4F311CFF"> ▷ </span></a></span></div></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Seljuk_Empire_(1090).png" title="File:Map of the Seljuk Empire (1090).png">class=notpageimage| </a></div><a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Seljuk Empire</a> <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1090</span>, during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Malik_Shah_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Malik Shah I">Malik Shah I</a>. To the west, Anatolia was under the independent rule of <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_ibn_Qutalmish" title="Suleiman ibn Qutalmish">Suleiman ibn Qutalmish</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">Sultanate of Rum</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>According to historians and linguists, the <a href="/wiki/Proto-Turkic_language" title="Proto-Turkic language">Proto-Turkic language</a> originated in Central-East Asia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Uchiyama&#95;et&#95;al&#95;2020&#95;97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Uchiyama_et_al_2020-97"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Initially, Proto-<a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic speakers</a> were potentially both hunter-gatherers and farmers; they later became <a href="/wiki/Nomadic" class="mw-redirect" title="Nomadic">nomadic</a> <a href="/wiki/Pastoralists" class="mw-redirect" title="Pastoralists">pastoralists</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Uchiyama&#95;et&#95;al&#95;2020&#95;97-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Uchiyama_et_al_2020-97"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Early and medieval <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic groups</a> exhibited a wide range of both East Asian and West-Eurasian physical appearances and genetic origins, in part through long-term contact with neighboring peoples such as <a href="/wiki/Iranic" class="mw-redirect" title="Iranic">Iranic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongolic_peoples" title="Mongolic peoples">Mongolic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tocharians" title="Tocharians">Tocharian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uralic_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Uralic people">Uralic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yeniseian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Yeniseian people">Yeniseian</a> peoples.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During the 9th and 10th centuries CE, <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Turks" title="Oghuz Turks">the Oghuz</a> were a Turkic group that lived in the <a href="/wiki/Pontic%E2%80%93Caspian_steppe" title="Pontic–Caspian steppe">Caspian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aral_Sea" title="Aral Sea">Aral</a> steppes.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Lee&#95;p84&#95;99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lee_p84-99"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Partly due to pressure from the <a href="/wiki/Kipchaks" title="Kipchaks">Kipchaks</a>, the Oghuz migrated into <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Plateau" class="mw-redirect" title="Iranian Plateau">Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Transoxiana" title="Transoxiana">Transoxiana</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Lee&#95;p84&#95;99-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lee_p84-99"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> They mixed with Iranic-speaking groups in the area and converted to <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Lee&#95;p84&#95;99-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lee_p84-99"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Oghuz Turks were also known as Turkmen or <a href="/wiki/Turkoman_(ethnonym)" title="Turkoman (ethnonym)">Turkoman</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;34&#95;100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016_34-100"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Lee&#95;p84&#95;99-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lee_p84-99"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Beylicats_d%25u2019Anatolie_vers_1330-en.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Beylicats_d%25u2019Anatolie_vers_1330-en.svg/500px-Beylicats_d%25u2019Anatolie_vers_1330-en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="176" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Beylicats_d%25u2019Anatolie_vers_1330-en.svg/960px-Beylicats_d%25u2019Anatolie_vers_1330-en.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="1545" data-file-height="779" /></a><figcaption>A map of independent <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">Turkish principalities</a> in Anatolia during the 14th century</figcaption></figure>
<p>The ruling family of <a href="/wiki/Seljuq_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Seljuq dynasty">the Seljuks</a> originated from the <i><a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1n%C4%B1k_(tribe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kınık (tribe)">Kınık</a></i> branch of the Oghuz Turks.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1040, the Seljuks defeated the <a href="/wiki/Ghaznavids" title="Ghaznavids">Ghaznavids</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Dandanaqan" title="Battle of Dandanaqan">Battle of Dandanaqan</a> and established the <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Seljuk Empire</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greater_Khorasan" class="mw-redirect" title="Greater Khorasan">Greater Khorasan</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid Caliphate</a>'s capital and center of <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">the Islamic world</a>, was taken by Seljuks in 1055.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;34&#95;100-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016_34-100"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Given the role <a href="/wiki/Khurasani" class="mw-redirect" title="Khurasani">Khurasani</a> traditions played in art, culture, and political traditions in the empire, the Seljuk period is described as a mixture of "<a href="/wiki/Turko-Persian_tradition" class="mw-redirect" title="Turko-Persian tradition">Turkish, Persian and Islamic influences</a>".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the latter half of the 11th century, the Seljuk Turks began penetrating into <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Armenia" title="Medieval Armenia">medieval Armenia</a> and Anatolia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;34&#95;100-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016_34-100"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> At the time, Anatolia was a diverse and largely Greek-speaking region after previously being <a href="/wiki/Hellenized" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenized">Hellenized</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Ahmed&#95;2006&#95;p1576&#95;h&#95;104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed_2006_p1576_h-104"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Davison&#95;1990&#95;p3&#95;4&#95;105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davison_1990_p3_4-105"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Horrocks&#95;pp&#95;778-779&#95;95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Horrocks_pp_778-779-95"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The Seljuk Turks defeated the Byzantines at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Manzikert" title="Battle of Manzikert">Battle of Manzikert</a> in 1071, and later established <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">the Seljuk Sultanate of Rum</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During this period, there were also <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">Turkish principalities</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Danishmendids" title="Danishmendids">Danishmendids</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Seljuk arrival started the <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">Turkification</a> process in Anatolia;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Davison&#95;1990&#95;p3&#95;4&#95;105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davison_1990_p3_4-105"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto5&#95;67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-67"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> there were Turkic/Turkish migrations, intermarriages, and conversions into Islam.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The shift took several centuries and happened gradually.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Members of <a href="/wiki/Mysticism#Islamic_mysticism" title="Mysticism">Islamic mysticism</a> orders, such as <a href="/wiki/Mevlevi_Order" title="Mevlevi Order">Mevlevi Order</a>, played a role in the <a href="/wiki/Islamization" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamization">Islamization</a> of the diverse people of Anatolia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Seljuk expansion was one of the reasons for the <a href="/wiki/Crusades" title="Crusades">Crusades</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 13th century, there was a second significant wave of Turkic migration, as people fled <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">Mongol</a> expansion.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Seljuk sultanate was defeated by the Mongols at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_K%C3%B6se_Da%C4%9F" title="Battle of Köse Dağ">Battle of Köse Dağ</a> in 1243 and disappeared by the beginning of the 14th century. It was replaced by various Turkish principalities.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016&#95;38–39&#95;19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016_38–39-19"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Ottoman_Empire">Ottoman Empire</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:OttomanEmpireMain.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/OttomanEmpireMain.png/250px-OttomanEmpireMain.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="179" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/OttomanEmpireMain.png/500px-OttomanEmpireMain.png 1.5x" data-file-width="3597" data-file-height="2581" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> at its greatest European extent, in 1683, during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vienna" title="Battle of Vienna">Battle of Vienna</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Based around <a href="/wiki/S%C3%B6%C4%9F%C3%BCt" title="Söğüt">Söğüt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Beylik" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Beylik">Ottoman Beylik</a> was founded by <a href="/wiki/Osman_I" title="Osman I">Osman I</a> in the early 14th century.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to Ottoman chroniclers, Osman descended from the <i><a href="/wiki/Kay%C4%B1_(tribe)" title="Kayı (tribe)">Kayı</a></i> tribe of the <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Turks" title="Oghuz Turks">Oghuz Turks</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Lee&#95;2023&#95;94&#95;119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lee_2023_94-119"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Ottomans started annexing the nearby Turkish beyliks (principalities) in Anatolia and expanded into the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_II" title="Mehmed II">Mehmed II</a> completed Ottoman conquest of the Byzantine Empire by <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">capturing its capital, Constantinople</a>, on 29 May 1453.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Selim_I" title="Selim I">Selim I</a> united Anatolia under Ottoman rule.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;p45&#95;122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_p45-122"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkification continued as Ottomans mixed with various indigenous people in Anatolia and the Balkans.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Lee&#95;2023&#95;94&#95;119-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lee_2023_94-119"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The Ottoman Empire was a global power during the reigns of <a href="/wiki/Selim_I" title="Selim I">Selim I</a> and <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;p45&#95;122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_p45-122"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Somel&#95;p&#95;xcvii&#95;123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Somel_p_xcvii-123"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 16th and 17th centuries, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="History of the Jews in the Ottoman Empire">Sephardic Jews</a> moved into Ottoman Empire following their <a href="/wiki/Reconquista#Conversions_and_expulsions" title="Reconquista">expulsion</a> from Spain.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From the second half of the 18th century onwards, the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Decline of the Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire began to decline</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> reforms, initiated by <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_II" title="Mahmud II">Mahmud II</a> in 1839, aimed to modernize the Ottoman state in line with the progress that had been made in Western Europe. The <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_constitution_of_1876" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman constitution of 1876">Ottoman constitution of 1876</a> was the first among Muslim states, but was <a href="/wiki/First_Constitutional_Era" title="First Constitutional Era">short-lived</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto8&#95;126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto8-126"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}@media screen{html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner span:not(.skin-invert-image):not(.skin-invert):not(.bg-transparent) img{background-color:white}}@media screen and (prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner span:not(.skin-invert-image):not(.skin-invert):not(.bg-transparent) img{background-color:white}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:242px;max-width:242px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:240px;max-width:240px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:160px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:View_of_Topkap%C4%B1_Palace_from_the_Galata_Tower,_Istanbul,_Turkey_001_cropped.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/View_of_Topkap%C4%B1_Palace_from_the_Galata_Tower%2C_Istanbul%2C_Turkey_001_cropped.jpg/250px-View_of_Topkap%C4%B1_Palace_from_the_Galata_Tower%2C_Istanbul%2C_Turkey_001_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="238" height="160" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/View_of_Topkap%C4%B1_Palace_from_the_Galata_Tower%2C_Istanbul%2C_Turkey_001_cropped.jpg/500px-View_of_Topkap%C4%B1_Palace_from_the_Galata_Tower%2C_Istanbul%2C_Turkey_001_cropped.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2802" data-file-height="1885" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:240px;max-width:240px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:130px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Dolmabahce_Istanbul_Turkey.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Dolmabahce_Istanbul_Turkey.jpg/250px-Dolmabahce_Istanbul_Turkey.jpg" decoding="async" width="238" height="130" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Dolmabahce_Istanbul_Turkey.jpg/500px-Dolmabahce_Istanbul_Turkey.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4365" data-file-height="2385" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="Topkapı Palace">Topkapı Palace</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="Dolmabahçe Palace">Dolmabahçe Palace</a> were the primary residences of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_sultans" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman sultans">Ottoman sultans</a> in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> between 1465 and 1856<sup id="cite&#95;ref-nytimes&#95;127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-127"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and 1856 to 1922,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-dolmabahcepalace&#95;128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dolmabahcepalace-128"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> respectively.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>As the empire gradually shrank in size, military power and wealth; especially after the <a href="/wiki/Great_Eastern_Crisis" title="Great Eastern Crisis">Ottoman economic crisis and default</a> in 1875<sup id="cite&#95;ref-NiallFergusonFT&#95;129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NiallFergusonFT-129"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which led to uprisings in the Balkan provinces that culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%931878)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)">Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)</a>. The decline of the Ottoman Empire led to a <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_nationalism_under_the_Ottoman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Rise of nationalism under the Ottoman Empire">rise in nationalist sentiment among its various subject peoples</a>, leading to increased ethnic tensions which occasionally burst into violence, such as the <a href="/wiki/Hamidian_massacres" title="Hamidian massacres">Hamidian massacres</a> of <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Armenians in the Ottoman Empire">Armenians</a>, which claimed up to 300,000 lives.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-nzhistory.net.nz&#95;130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nzhistory.net.nz-130"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Questionable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="some of this information is not in the source (November 2024)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Ottoman territories in Europe (<a href="/wiki/Rumelia" title="Rumelia">Rumelia</a>) were lost in the <a href="/wiki/First_Balkan_War" title="First Balkan War">First Balkan War</a> (1912–1913).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Ottomans managed to recover some territory in Europe, such as <a href="/wiki/Edirne" title="Edirne">Edirne</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Second_Balkan_War" title="Second Balkan War">Second Balkan War</a> (1913).
</p><p>In the 19th and early 20th centuries, <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Muslims_during_the_Ottoman_contraction" title="Persecution of Muslims during the Ottoman contraction">persecution of Muslims during the Ottoman contraction</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Muslims#Russian_Empire" title="Persecution of Muslims">in the Russian Empire</a> resulted in estimated 5 million deaths,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Gibney&#95;2005&#95;437&#95;133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gibney_2005_437-133"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with the casualties including Turks.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Gibney&#95;2005&#95;437&#95;133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gibney_2005_437-133"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Five to seven or seven to nine million <a href="/wiki/Muhacir" title="Muhacir">refugees</a> migrated into modern-day Turkey from the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> islands,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> shifting the center of the Ottoman Empire to Anatolia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In addition to a small number of Jews, the refugees were overwhelmingly Muslim; they were both Turkish and non-Turkish people, such as <a href="/wiki/Circassians" title="Circassians">Circassians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Tatars" title="Crimean Tatars">Crimean Tatars</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Paul_Mojzes" title="Paul Mojzes">Paul Mojzes</a> has called the Balkan Wars an "unrecognized genocide", where multiple sides were both victims and perpetrators.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Circassian refugees included the survivors of the <a href="/wiki/Circassian_genocide" title="Circassian genocide">Circassian genocide</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/1913_Ottoman_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1913 Ottoman coup d&#39;état">1913 coup d'état</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Three_Pashas" title="Three Pashas">Three Pashas</a> took control of the Ottoman government. The Ottoman Empire entered <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> on the side of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> and was ultimately defeated.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During the war, the empire's Armenian subjects were <a href="/wiki/Temporary_Law_of_Deportation" title="Temporary Law of Deportation">deported to Syria</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide" title="Armenian genocide">Armenian genocide</a>. As a result, an estimated 600,000<sup id="cite&#95;ref-britannica-ag&#95;141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-ag-141"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> to more than 1 million,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-britannica-ag&#95;141-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-ag-141"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> or up to 1.5 million<sup id="cite&#95;ref-umichigan&#95;142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-umichigan-142"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-jfreedman&#95;143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jfreedman-143"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-totten-et-al&#95;144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-totten-et-al-144"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Armenians in the Ottoman Empire">Armenians</a> were killed. The Turkish government has <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide_denial" title="Armenian genocide denial">refused to acknowledge</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Tatz&#95;145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tatz-145"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the events as genocide and states that Armenians were only <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer" title="Population transfer">"relocated</a>" from the eastern war zone.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Late_Ottoman_genocides" title="Late Ottoman genocides">Genocidal campaigns</a> were also committed against the empire's other minority groups such as the <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Assyrian genocide">Assyrians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Greeks</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bloxham2005&#95;148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bloxham2005-148"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Levene&#95;149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levene-149"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Ferguson&#95;150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ferguson-150"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Mudros" title="Armistice of Mudros">Armistice of Mudros</a> in 1918, the victorious <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied Powers</a> sought the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Partition of the Ottoman Empire">partition of the Ottoman Empire</a> through the 1920 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of Sèvres">Treaty of Sèvres</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Treaty&#95;of&#95;Sèvres&#95;151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Treaty_of_Sèvres-151"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Republic_of_Türkiye"><span id="Republic_of_T.C3.BCrkiye"></span>Republic of Türkiye</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="History of the Republic of Turkey">History of the Republic of Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Atat%C3%BCrk_%C5%9Fapkas%C4%B1yla_selam_verirken.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Atat%C3%BCrk_%C5%9Fapkas%C4%B1yla_selam_verirken.jpg/250px-Atat%C3%BCrk_%C5%9Fapkas%C4%B1yla_selam_verirken.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="254" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Atat%C3%BCrk_%C5%9Fapkas%C4%B1yla_selam_verirken.jpg/330px-Atat%C3%BCrk_%C5%9Fapkas%C4%B1yla_selam_verirken.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Atat%C3%BCrk_%C5%9Fapkas%C4%B1yla_selam_verirken.jpg/500px-Atat%C3%BCrk_%C5%9Fapkas%C4%B1yla_selam_verirken.jpg 2x" data-file-width="650" data-file-height="868" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Mustafa Kemal Atatürk</a>, the founder and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_Turkey" title="List of presidents of Turkey">first President</a> of the Turkish Republic</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Istanbul" title="Occupation of Istanbul">occupation of Istanbul</a> (1918) and <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Smyrna" title="Occupation of Smyrna">İzmir</a> (1919) by the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allies</a> in the aftermath of World War I initiated the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_National_Movement" title="Turkish National Movement">Turkish National Movement</a>. Under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Pasha" class="mw-redirect" title="Mustafa Kemal Pasha">Mustafa Kemal Pasha</a>, a military commander who had distinguished himself during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gallipoli" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Gallipoli">Battle of Gallipoli</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">Turkish War of Independence</a> (1919–1923) was waged with the aim of revoking the terms of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of Sèvres">Treaty of Sèvres</a> (1920).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Atatürk&#95;152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atatürk-152"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Provisional_Government" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Provisional Government">Turkish Provisional Government</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a>, which had declared itself the legitimate government of the country on <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">23 April 1920</a>, started to formalize the legal transition from the old Ottoman into the new Republican political system. The Ankara Government engaged in armed and diplomatic struggle. In 1921–1923, the Armenian, Greek, French, and British armies had been expelled.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-18sep1922&#95;156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18sep1922-156"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The military advance and diplomatic success of the Ankara Government resulted in the signing of the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Mudanya" title="Armistice of Mudanya">Armistice of Mudanya</a> on 11 October 1922. On 1 November 1922, the Turkish Parliament in Ankara formally abolished the Sultanate, thus ending 623 years of <a href="/wiki/Monarchical" class="mw-redirect" title="Monarchical">monarchical</a> Ottoman rule.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> of 24 July 1923, which superseded the Treaty of Sèvres,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Treaty&#95;of&#95;Sèvres&#95;151-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Treaty_of_Sèvres-151"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Atatürk&#95;152-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atatürk-152"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> led to the international recognition of the sovereignty of the new Turkish state as the successor state of the Ottoman Empire. On 4 October 1923, the Allied occupation of Turkey ended with the withdrawal of the last Allied troops from <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Istanbul" title="Occupation of Istanbul">Istanbul</a>. The Turkish Republic <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Proclamation of the Republic of Turkey">was officially proclaimed</a> on 29 October 1923 in Ankara, the country's new capital.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Convention_Concerning_the_Exchange_of_Greek_and_Turkish_Populations" title="Convention Concerning the Exchange of Greek and Turkish Populations">Lausanne Convention</a> stipulated a <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">population exchange between Greece and Turkey</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Clogg&#95;158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Clogg-158"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Turkey-1658_(2215850337).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Turkey-1658_%282215850337%29.jpg/250px-Turkey-1658_%282215850337%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="248" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Turkey-1658_%282215850337%29.jpg/330px-Turkey-1658_%282215850337%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Turkey-1658_%282215850337%29.jpg/500px-Turkey-1658_%282215850337%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2563" data-file-height="3351" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/An%C4%B1tkabir" title="Anıtkabir">Anıtkabir</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a> was completed in 1953 to become the mausoleum of <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Mustafa Kemal Atatürk</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Mustafa Kemal became the republic's first <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">president</a> and introduced <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_reforms" title="Atatürk&#39;s reforms">many reforms</a>. The reforms aimed to transform the old <a href="/wiki/Millet_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Millet (Ottoman Empire)">religion-based and multi-communal</a> Ottoman monarchy into a Turkish <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a> that would be governed as a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> under a <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution_of_1924" title="Turkish Constitution of 1924">secular constitution</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-BoweringCrone2012&#95;159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoweringCrone2012-159"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Women gained the right to vote nationally in 1934.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> With the <a href="/wiki/Surname_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="Surname Law">Surname Law</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Parliament">Turkish Parliament</a> bestowed upon Kemal the honorific surname "Atatürk" (<i>Father Turk</i>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Atatürk&#95;152-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atatürk-152"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Atatürk's reforms caused discontent in some <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurdish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zazas" title="Zazas">Zaza</a> tribes leading to the <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Said_rebellion" title="Sheikh Said rebellion">Sheikh Said rebellion</a> in 1925<sup id="cite&#95;ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Dersim_rebellion" class="mw-redirect" title="Dersim rebellion">Dersim rebellion</a> in 1937.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/%C4%B0smet_%C4%B0n%C3%B6n%C3%BC" title="İsmet İnönü">İsmet İnönü</a> became the country's second president following Atatürk's death in 1938. In 1939, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Hatay" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Hatay">Republic of Hatay</a> voted in favor of joining Turkey with a referendum. Turkey <a href="/wiki/Second_Cairo_Conference" title="Second Cairo Conference">remained neutral</a> during almost all of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> but entered the war on the side of the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> on <a href="/wiki/Turkish_declaration_of_war_on_Germany_and_Japan" title="Turkish declaration of war on Germany and Japan">23 February 1945</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Later that year, Turkey became a <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Charter" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Charter">charter member</a> of the United Nations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Turkey&#95;UN&#95;165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Turkey_UN-165"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1950 Turkey became a member of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>. After fighting as part of the <a href="/wiki/UN" class="mw-redirect" title="UN">UN</a> forces in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>, Turkey joined <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> in 1952, becoming a bulwark against Soviet expansion into the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Basin">Mediterranean</a>.
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Visit_of_Tansu_%C3%87iller,_Turkish_Prime_Minister,_to_the_EC_6.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Visit_of_Tansu_%C3%87iller%2C_Turkish_Prime_Minister%2C_to_the_EC_6.jpg/250px-Visit_of_Tansu_%C3%87iller%2C_Turkish_Prime_Minister%2C_to_the_EC_6.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="168" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Visit_of_Tansu_%C3%87iller%2C_Turkish_Prime_Minister%2C_to_the_EC_6.jpg/500px-Visit_of_Tansu_%C3%87iller%2C_Turkish_Prime_Minister%2C_to_the_EC_6.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2728" data-file-height="1830" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Tansu_%C3%87iller" title="Tansu Çiller">Tansu Çiller</a>, Turkey's first female prime minister, attends a <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a> meeting in January 1994.</figcaption></figure><p>Military coups or memorandums, which happened in <a href="/wiki/1960_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1960 Turkish coup d&#39;état">1960</a>, <a href="/wiki/1971_Turkish_military_memorandum" title="1971 Turkish military memorandum">1971</a>, <a href="/wiki/1980_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1980 Turkish coup d&#39;état">1980</a>, and <a href="/wiki/1997_Turkish_military_memorandum" title="1997 Turkish military memorandum">1997</a>, complicated Turkey's transition to a democratic <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Multi-party period of the Republic of Turkey">multiparty system</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Between 1960 and the end of the 20th century, the prominent leaders in Turkish politics who achieved multiple election victories were <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCleyman_Demirel" title="Süleyman Demirel">Süleyman Demirel</a>, <a href="/wiki/B%C3%BClent_Ecevit" title="Bülent Ecevit">Bülent Ecevit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turgut_%C3%96zal" title="Turgut Özal">Turgut Özal</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2024)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> PKK started a "campaign of terrorist attacks on civilian and military targets" in the 1980s.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is designated as a <a href="/wiki/Terrorist_organization" class="mw-redirect" title="Terrorist organization">terrorist organization</a> by Turkey,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Ministry&#95;Foreign&#95;Affairs&#95;statement&#95;169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ministry_Foreign_Affairs_statement-169"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the United States,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-department-of-state-list&#95;170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-department-of-state-list-170"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the European Union.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-european-council-list&#95;171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-european-council-list-171"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>168<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tansu_%C3%87iller" title="Tansu Çiller">Tansu Çiller</a> became the first female prime minister of Turkey in 1993. Turkey applied for full membership of the <a href="/wiki/EEC" class="mw-redirect" title="EEC">EEC</a> in 1987, joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">European Union Customs Union</a> in 1995 and started <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">accession negotiations</a> with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 2005.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-TR&#95;EUChrono&#95;172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-172"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>169<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>170<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Customs Union had an important impact on the Turkish manufacturing sector.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>171<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014, prime minister Recep Tayyip Erdoğan won Turkey's first direct <a href="/wiki/2014_Turkish_presidential_election" title="2014 Turkish presidential election">presidential election</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 15 July 2016, an <a href="/wiki/2016_Turkish_coup_attempt" class="mw-redirect" title="2016 Turkish coup attempt">unsuccessful coup attempt</a> tried to oust the government.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the Turkish government, there are 13,251 arrested or convicted people in jail as of 2024, related to the 2016 coup attempt.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> With a <a href="/wiki/2017_Turkish_constitutional_referendum" title="2017 Turkish constitutional referendum">referendum in 2017</a>, the parliamentary republic was replaced by an <a href="/wiki/Executive_president" title="Executive president">executive presidential system</a>. The office of the prime minister was abolished, and its powers and duties were transferred to the president. On the referendum day, while the voting was still underway, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Election_Council_(Turkey)" title="Supreme Election Council (Turkey)">Supreme Electoral Council</a> lifted a rule that required each ballot to have an official stamp.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-WasPostRef2017&#95;180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WasPostRef2017-180"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The opposition parties claimed that as many as 2.5 million <a href="/wiki/2017_Turkish_constitutional_referendum#Unstamped_ballots" title="2017 Turkish constitutional referendum">ballots without a stamp</a> were accepted as valid.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-WasPostRef2017&#95;180-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WasPostRef2017-180"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2025 the PKK declared a ceasefire.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Geography">Geography</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Turkey" title="Geography of Turkey">Geography of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Turkey" title="List of national parks of Turkey">List of national parks of Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Turkey_topo.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/250px-Turkey_topo.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="134" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/500px-Turkey_topo.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="752" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Topographic_map" title="Topographic map">Topographic map</a> of Turkey</figcaption></figure>
<p>Turkey covers an area of 783,562 square kilometres (302,535 square miles).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> With <a href="/wiki/Turkish_straits" title="Turkish straits">Turkish straits</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">Sea of Marmara</a> in between, Turkey bridges <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Southeastern Europe">Southeastern Europe</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kuzucuoğlu&#95;2019&#95;p7&#95;183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kuzucuoğlu_2019_p7-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey's Asian side covers 97% of its surface, and is often called <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-anatolia&#95;definition&#95;184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-anatolia_definition-184"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Another definition of Anatolia's eastern boundary is an imprecise line from the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> to <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Iskenderun" class="mw-redirect" title="Gulf of Iskenderun">Gulf of Iskenderun</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Thrace" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Thrace">Eastern Thrace</a>, Turkey's European side, includes around 10% of the population and covers 3% of the surface area.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The country is encircled by seas on three sides: the <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">Aegean Sea</a> to the west, the Black Sea to the north and the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to the south.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Waskey&#95;2005&#95;922&#95;187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Waskey_2005_922-187"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey is bordered by Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan and Iran to the east.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Waskey&#95;2005&#95;922&#95;187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Waskey_2005_922-187"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> To the south, it's bordered by Syria and Iraq.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> To the north, its Thracian area is bordered by Greece and Bulgaria.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Waskey&#95;2005&#95;922&#95;187-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Waskey_2005_922-187"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey is divided into "<a href="/wiki/Geographical_regions_of_Turkey" title="Geographical regions of Turkey">seven major regions</a>": <a href="/wiki/Marmara_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Marmara Region">Marmara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Aegean Region">Aegean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Anatolia">Central Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Black Sea Region">Black Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Anatolia">Eastern Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Anatolia" class="mw-redirect" title="Southeastern Anatolia">Southeastern Anatolia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region,_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Region, Turkey">Mediterranean</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Waskey&#95;2005&#95;922&#95;187-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Waskey_2005_922-187"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As a general trend, the inland <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_Plateau" class="mw-redirect" title="Anatolian Plateau">Anatolian Plateau</a> becomes increasingly rugged as it progresses eastward.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-TRGeo&#95;TRMinistryTourism&#95;189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism-189"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Mountain ranges include <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ro%C4%9Flu_Mountains" title="Köroğlu Mountains">Köroğlu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Mountains" title="Pontic Mountains">Pontic</a> mountain ranges to the north, and the <a href="/wiki/Taurus_Mountains" title="Taurus Mountains">Taurus Mountains</a> to the south. The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Lakes_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Lakes Region">Lakes Region</a> contains some of the largest lakes in Turkey such as <a href="/wiki/Lake_Bey%C5%9Fehir" title="Lake Beyşehir">Lake Beyşehir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_E%C4%9Firdir" title="Lake Eğirdir">Lake Eğirdir</a>.
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:T%C3%BCrkiye_tectonic_map.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/T%C3%BCrkiye_tectonic_map.jpg/250px-T%C3%BCrkiye_tectonic_map.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="131" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/T%C3%BCrkiye_tectonic_map.jpg/500px-T%C3%BCrkiye_tectonic_map.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1181" data-file-height="617" /></a><figcaption>Tectonic map of Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Straight lines and lines with triangles denote different types of <a href="/wiki/Fault_(geology)" title="Fault (geology)">faults</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/North_Anatolian_Fault" title="North Anatolian Fault">North Anatolian Fault</a> and <a href="/wiki/East_Anatolian_Fault" title="East Anatolian Fault">East Anatolian Fault</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Geographers have used the eastern Anatolian plateau, Iranian plateau, and <a href="/wiki/Armenian_plateau" class="mw-redirect" title="Armenian plateau">Armenian plateau</a> terms to refer to the mountainous area around where <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Plate" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabian Plate">Arabian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Plate" class="mw-redirect" title="Eurasian Plate">Eurasian</a> tectonic plates merge. The eastern Anatolian plateau and Armenian plateau definitions largely overlap.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Oxford&#95;Handbook&#95;p466&#95;191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Handbook_p466-191"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_region" title="Eastern Anatolia region">Eastern Anatolia region</a> contains <a href="/wiki/Mount_Ararat" title="Mount Ararat">Mount Ararat</a>, Turkey's highest point at 5,137 metres (16,854 feet),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-mararat&#95;192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mararat-192"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Van" title="Lake Van">Lake Van</a>, the largest lake in the country.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-lvan&#95;193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lvan-193"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Eastern Turkey is home to the sources of rivers such as the <a href="/wiki/Euphrates" title="Euphrates">Euphrates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tigris" title="Tigris">Tigris</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aras_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Aras River">Aras</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Anatolia_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Southeastern Anatolia Region">Southeastern Anatolia Region</a> includes the northern plains of <a href="/wiki/Upper_Mesopotamia" title="Upper Mesopotamia">Upper Mesopotamia</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_Turkey" title="List of earthquakes in Turkey">Earthquakes</a> happen frequently in Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Ahmed&#95;2006&#95;pp&#95;1575&#95;1576&#95;194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed_2006_pp_1575_1576-194"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Almost the entire population lives in areas with varying seismic risk levels, with around 70% in highest or second-highest seismic areas.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-WorldBank&#95;Overview&#95;April&#95;2024&#95;196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WorldBank_Overview_April_2024-196"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_plate" class="mw-redirect" title="Anatolian plate">Anatolian plate</a> is bordered by <a href="/wiki/North_Anatolian_Fault" title="North Anatolian Fault">North Anatolian Fault</a> zone to the north; <a href="/wiki/East_Anatolian_Fault" title="East Anatolian Fault">East Anatolian Fault</a> zone and Bitlis–Zagros collision zone to the east; <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_subduction_zone" title="Hellenic subduction zone">Hellenic</a> and Cyprus subduction zones to the south; and <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea_Plate" class="mw-redirect" title="Aegean Sea Plate">Aegean extensional zone</a> to the west.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After <a href="/wiki/1999_%C4%B0zmit_earthquake" title="1999 İzmit earthquake">1999 İzmit</a> and <a href="/wiki/1999_D%C3%BCzce_earthquake" title="1999 Düzce earthquake">1999 Düzce</a> earthquakes, North Anatolian Fault zone activity "is considered to be one of the most dangerous natural hazards in Turkey".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/2023_Turkey%E2%80%93Syria_earthquakes" title="2023 Turkey–Syria earthquakes">2023 Turkey–Syria earthquakes</a> were the deadliest in contemporary Turkish history.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey is sometimes unfavorably compared to <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>, a country with a similar <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">developmental level</a> that is more successful with <a href="/wiki/Earthquake_preparedness" title="Earthquake preparedness">earthquake preparedness</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Turkey" title="Wildlife of Turkey">Wildlife of Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Turkey" title="Fauna of Turkey">Fauna of Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Flora_and_vegetation_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Flora and vegetation of Turkey">Flora and vegetation of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Turkey" title="Environmental issues in Turkey">Environmental issues in Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:219px;max-width:219px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:124px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Biodiversity_Hotspots_Map.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img class="tsingle" style="width:169px;max-width:169px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:124px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Uzung%C3%B6l,_Trabzon.jpg" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Uzung%C3%B6l%2C_Trabzon.jpg/330px-Uzung%C3%B6l%2C_Trabzon.jpg 1.5x,
