class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:198px;max-width:198px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:130px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Cappadocia_Aerial_View_Landscape.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Cappadocia_Aerial_View_Landscape.jpg/250px-Cappadocia_Aerial_View_Landscape.jpg" decoding="async" width="196" height="131" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Cappadocia_Aerial_View_Landscape.jpg/330px-Cappadocia_Aerial_View_Landscape.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Cappadocia_Aerial_View_Landscape.jpg/500px-Cappadocia_Aerial_View_Landscape.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" /></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:190px;max-width:190px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:130px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:%C3%87%C4%B1ral%C4%B1,_Kemer_cropped.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/%C3%87%C4%B1ral%C4%B1%2C_Kemer_cropped.jpg/250px-%C3%87%C4%B1ral%C4%B1%2C_Kemer_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="188" height="130" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/%C3%87%C4%B1ral%C4%B1%2C_Kemer_cropped.jpg/330px-%C3%87%C4%B1ral%C4%B1%2C_Kemer_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/%C3%87%C4%B1ral%C4%B1%2C_Kemer_cropped.jpg/500px-%C3%87%C4%B1ral%C4%B1%2C_Kemer_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3254" data-file-height="2250" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Top left: Turkey encompasses rich biodiversity;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kuzucuoğlu&#95;2019&#95;p7&#95;183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kuzucuoğlu_2019_p7-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> it includes three <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot" title="Biodiversity hotspot">biodiversity hotspot</a> areas out of 36 in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Birben&#95;2019&#95;203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Birben_2019-203"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Three examples in the Caucasus, Mediterranean, and Irano-Anatolian hotspot areas are shown (clockwise starting with top right). The Eastern <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Black Sea Region">Black Sea Region</a> is home to mountainous terrain and lush forests<sup id="cite&#95;ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Uzung%C3%B6l" title="Uzungöl">Uzungöl</a> in <a href="/wiki/Trabzon" title="Trabzon">Trabzon</a> is shown). <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region,_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Region, Turkey">Mediterranean Region</a> is "characterized by high relief contrasts and the proximity of the sea"<sup id="cite&#95;ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/%C3%87%C4%B1ral%C4%B1" title="Çıralı">Çıralı</a> village in <a href="/wiki/Antalya_Province" title="Antalya Province">Antalya</a> is shown). Landscapes in <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Anatolia Region">Central Anatolia Region</a> was influenced by volcanic activity<sup id="cite&#95;ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Cappadocia" title="Cappadocia">Cappadocia</a> in Central Anatolia<sup id="cite&#95;ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> is shown).</div></div></div></div>
<p>Turkey has rich biodiversity,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Demir&#95;Guzel&#95;2024&#95;209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Demir_Guzel_2024-209"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Birben&#95;2019&#95;203-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Birben_2019-203"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and includes three <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot" title="Biodiversity hotspot">biodiversity hotspots</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Demir&#95;Guzel&#95;2024&#95;209-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Demir_Guzel_2024-209"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Birben&#95;2019&#95;203-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Birben_2019-203"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> out of the 36 in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Birben&#95;2019&#95;203-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Birben_2019-203"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These are the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Basin">Mediterranean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irano-Anatolian" title="Irano-Anatolian">Irano-Anatolian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> hotspots.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Birben&#95;2019&#95;203-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Birben_2019-203"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolian_steppe" title="Central Anatolian steppe">Central</a> or <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolian_montane_steppe" title="Eastern Anatolian montane steppe">Eastern Anatolian steppe</a> ecosystems contain wild animal and plant species whose genetic variation have important implications for the food industry, agriculture, and medicine. <a href="/wiki/List_of_ecoregions_in_Turkey" title="List of ecoregions in Turkey">Other ecosystems in Turkey</a> include <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_forests,_woodlands,_and_scrub" title="Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub">Mediterranean plant types</a>, <a href="/wiki/Temperate_deciduous_forest" title="Temperate deciduous forest">temperate deciduous forest</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alpine_tundra" title="Alpine tundra">Alpine tundra</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-MFA&#95;2019&#95;210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_2019-210"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> An extensive number of species of plants and animals exist in Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-MFA&#95;2019&#95;210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_2019-210"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These include around 197 <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Turkey" title="List of mammals of Turkey">mammal species</a>, 420 <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Turkey" title="List of birds of Turkey">bird species</a>, 820 marine and freshwater fish species, 130 <a href="/wiki/List_of_reptiles_of_Turkey" title="List of reptiles of Turkey">reptile species</a>, and 10,150 vascular <a href="/wiki/Flora_of_Turkey" title="Flora of Turkey">plant species</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some of these are <a href="/wiki/Endangered" class="mw-redirect" title="Endangered">endangered</a> or <a href="/wiki/Critically_endangered" title="Critically endangered">critically endangered</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-MFA&#95;2019&#95;210-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_2019-210"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A lot of the animal and plant species are <a href="/wiki/Endemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic">endemic</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Birben&#95;2019&#95;203-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Birben_2019-203"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
</p><p>Landscapes in Turkey face a variety of threats and risks such as <a href="/wiki/Desertification" title="Desertification">desertification</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soil_erosion" title="Soil erosion">soil erosion</a>, declining <a href="/wiki/Groundwater" title="Groundwater">groundwater</a> levels, and <a href="/wiki/Soil_salinity" title="Soil salinity">salinization of soil</a>. 27% of Turkey is protected, which includes conservation areas, forests, <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Turkey" title="List of national parks of Turkey">national parks</a>, biosphere reserves, <a href="/wiki/List_of_natural_monuments_of_Turkey" title="List of natural monuments of Turkey">natural monuments</a>, and historical sites.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are 50 national parks;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> most visited in 2022 were <a href="/wiki/Marmaris_National_Park" title="Marmaris National Park">Marmaris National Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beyda%C4%9Flar%C4%B1_Coastal_National_Park" title="Beydağları Coastal National Park">Beydağları Coastal National Park</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2020, <a href="/wiki/Forests_in_Turkey" title="Forests in Turkey">Turkey's forests</a> covered 29% of Turkey's surface area.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey's forests include globally largest concentrations of <a href="/wiki/Cedrus_libani" title="Cedrus libani">Cedrus libani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_cypress" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean cypress">Mediterranean cypress</a> trees, while <a href="/wiki/Wetlands_of_Turkey" title="Wetlands of Turkey">Turkey's wetlands</a> are significant for <a href="/wiki/Migratory_birds" class="mw-redirect" title="Migratory birds">migratory birds</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-MFA&#95;2019&#95;210-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_2019-210"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Climate">Climate</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:390px;max-width:390px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:110px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Temperature_and_Precipitation_in_Turkey.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Temperature_and_Precipitation_in_Turkey.png/500px-Temperature_and_Precipitation_in_Turkey.png" decoding="async" width="388" height="111" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Temperature_and_Precipitation_in_Turkey.png/960px-Temperature_and_Precipitation_in_Turkey.png 1.5x" data-file-width="2541" data-file-height="725" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:390px;max-width:390px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:186px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B6ppen_types_of_Turkey.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/K%C3%B6ppen_types_of_Turkey.jpg/500px-K%C3%B6ppen_types_of_Turkey.jpg" decoding="async" width="388" height="186" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/K%C3%B6ppen_types_of_Turkey.jpg/960px-K%C3%B6ppen_types_of_Turkey.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2128" data-file-height="1022" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Clockwise from top left image: Yearly total precipitation, yearly average temperatures, and Köppen climate types in Turkey<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Taşoğlu&#95;Öztürk&#95;Yazıcı&#95;2024&#95;216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taşoğlu_Öztürk_Yazıcı_2024-216"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Turkey" title="Climate of Turkey">Climate of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Turkey" title="Climate change in Turkey">Climate change in Turkey</a></div>
<p>Turkey's climate is highly varied due to rising overall elevation eastwards and the mountains that run alongside the coasts.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kuzucuoğlu&#95;2019&#95;p7&#95;183-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kuzucuoğlu_2019_p7-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Warm summers, "cool to cold" winters, and year-round wet conditions are found in the northern coasts. Rainless and hot summers, and wet, cool to mild winters describe the western and southern coasts of the country.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:1&#95;217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-217"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Inland areas feature more severe winters, sharper temperature swings,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:1&#95;217-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-217"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and relatively low precipitation.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a>, Turkey has 14 distinct climate zones.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Taşoğlu&#95;Öztürk&#95;Yazıcı&#95;2024&#95;216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taşoğlu_Öztürk_Yazıcı_2024-216"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> is found in the Mediterranean, Aegean, Marmara, and Southeastern Anatolia regions of the country. In the Black Sea area, <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical" class="mw-redirect" title="Humid subtropical">humid subtropical</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a> types are usually found. Large swaths of Central and Eastern Anatolia are classified into <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-arid">semi-arid</a> or <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental climate</a> types.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:0&#95;219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-219"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Turkes&#95;2020&#95;pp105–10&#95;220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Turkes_2020_pp105–10-220"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey is highly <a href="/wiki/Vulnerable_to_climate_change" class="mw-redirect" title="Vulnerable to climate change">vulnerable to climate change</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-World&#95;Bank&#95;climate&#95;change&#95;221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank_climate_change-221"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> due to socioeconomic, climatic, and geographic factors.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-World&#95;Bank&#95;climate&#95;change&#95;221-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank_climate_change-221"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This applies to nine out of ten climate vulnerability dimensions, such as "average annual risk to wellbeing".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-World&#95;Bank&#95;climate&#95;change&#95;221-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank_climate_change-221"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> median is two out of ten.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-World&#95;Bank&#95;climate&#95;change&#95;221-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank_climate_change-221"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Inclusive and swift growth is needed for decreasing vulnerability.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey aims to achieve <a href="/wiki/Net_zero_emissions" class="mw-redirect" title="Net zero emissions">net zero emissions</a> by 2053.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-World&#95;Bank&#95;Türkiye&#95;224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank_Türkiye-224"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto9&#95;225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto9-225"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Accomplishing climate goals would require large investments, but would also result in net economic benefits, broadly due to reduced imports of fuel and due to better health from lowering air pollution.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><br />
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Turkey" title="Politics of Turkey">Politics of Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">Constitution of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:217px;max-width:217px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:215px;max-width:215px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:95px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:TBMM,_October_2021.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="The Parliament of Turkey" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/TBMM%2C_October_2021.jpg/250px-TBMM%2C_October_2021.jpg" decoding="async" width="213" height="96" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/TBMM%2C_October_2021.jpg/330px-TBMM%2C_October_2021.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/TBMM%2C_October_2021.jpg/500px-TBMM%2C_October_2021.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="1816" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">Grand National Assembly</a>,<br /> the <a href="/wiki/Legislative_chamber" title="Legislative chamber">legislative chamber</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:215px;max-width:215px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:113px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Presidential_Palace_Main.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="The Presidential Complex" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Presidential_Palace_Main.jpg/250px-Presidential_Palace_Main.jpg" decoding="async" width="213" height="113" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Presidential_Palace_Main.jpg/330px-Presidential_Palace_Main.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Presidential_Palace_Main.jpg/500px-Presidential_Palace_Main.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3399" data-file-height="1807" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Complex_(Turkey)" title="Presidential Complex (Turkey)">Presidential Complex</a>, residence and workplace of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President of Turkey</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:215px;max-width:215px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:119px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="The Court of Cassation" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg/250px-Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg" decoding="async" width="213" height="120" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg/330px-Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg/500px-Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="2268" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Cassation_(Turkey)" title="Court of Cassation (Turkey)">Court of Cassation</a> is Turkey's <a href="/wiki/Supreme_court" title="Supreme court">supreme court</a> for reviewing verdicts given by courts of criminal and civil justice.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a> within a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Multi-party period of the Republic of Turkey">multi-party system</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-CIAFactbookTurkey&#95;227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAFactbookTurkey-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Due to Erdoğan's <a href="/wiki/Judicial_capture" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial capture">judicial capture</a>, imprisonment of opposition politicians and dissidents, and repression of protest movements, Turkey is not considered a democracy but rather as a <a href="/wiki/Competitive_authoritarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Competitive authoritarian">competitive</a> or fully <a href="/wiki/Authoritarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Authoritarian">authoritarian</a> system.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Borsuk&#95;Levin&#95;2021&#95;pp.&#95;175–187&#95;228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Borsuk_Levin_2021_pp._175–187-228"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">current constitution</a> was approved by <a href="/wiki/1982_Turkish_constitutional_referendum" title="1982 Turkish constitutional referendum">referendum in 1982</a>, which determines the government's structure, lays forth the ideals and standards of the state's conduct, and&#160;sets&#160;out the state's responsibility to its citizens. Furthermore, the constitution specifies the people's rights and obligations, as well as principles for the delegation and exercise of sovereignty that belongs to the people of Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the Turkish <a href="/wiki/Unitary_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Unitary system">unitary system</a>, citizens are subject to <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Turkey" title="Administrative divisions of Turkey">three levels of government</a>: national, provincial, and local. The <a href="/wiki/Local_government" title="Local government">local government</a>'s duties are commonly split between <a href="/wiki/Municipal_corporation" title="Municipal corporation">municipal governments</a> and <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Turkey" title="Districts of Turkey">districts</a>, in which the executive and legislative officials are elected by a <a href="/wiki/Plurality_vote" class="mw-redirect" title="Plurality vote">plurality vote</a> of citizens by district. Turkey is subdivided into <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey" title="Provinces of Turkey">81 provinces</a> for administrative purposes. Each province is divided into districts, for a total of <a href="/wiki/List_of_districts_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="List of districts in Turkey">973 districts</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="National_government">National government</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Turkey" title="Government of Turkey">Government of Turkey</a></div>
<p>The government, regulated by a system of <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">separation of powers</a> as defined by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">constitution of Turkey</a>, comprises three branches:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Legislative" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative">Legislative</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">Parliament</a> makes <a href="/wiki/Law" title="Law">laws</a>, debates and adopts the budget bills, <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_war" title="Declaration of war">declares war</a>, approves treaties, proclaims <a href="/wiki/Amnesty" title="Amnesty">amnesty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pardon" title="Pardon">pardon</a>, and has the power of <a href="/wiki/Impeachment" title="Impeachment">impeachment</a>, by which it can remove incumbent members of the government.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Parliament has 600 voting members, each representing a <a href="/wiki/Constituency" class="mw-redirect" title="Constituency">constituency</a> for a five-year term. Parliamentary seats are distributed among the provinces by population, conforming with the census apportionment.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">Executive</a>: <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">The president</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the military, can veto <a href="/wiki/Bill_(law)" title="Bill (law)">legislative bills</a> before they become law (subject to parliamentary override), can issue <a href="/wiki/Decree" title="Decree">presidential decrees</a> on matters regarding executive power with the exception of fundamental rights, individual rights and certain political rights (parliamentary laws prevail presidential decrees), and appoints the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Turkey" title="Cabinet of Turkey">members of the Cabinet</a> and other officers, who administer and enforce national laws and policies.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The president is <a href="/wiki/Turkish_presidential_elections" title="Turkish presidential elections">elected</a> by <a href="/wiki/Direct_vote" class="mw-redirect" title="Direct vote">direct vote</a> and serves a five-year term. The president can't run for re-elections after two terms of five-years, unless the parliament prematurely renews the presidential elections during the second term of the President. Elections for the Parliament and presidential elections are held on the same day.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Judicial" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial">Judicial</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Turkey" title="Constitutional Court of Turkey">Constitutional Court</a> (for <a href="/wiki/Constitutionality" title="Constitutionality">constitutional adjudication</a> and review of individual applications concerning human rights), the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Cassation_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Court of Cassation of Turkey">Court of Cassation</a> (final decision maker in ordinary judiciary), the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Council_of_State" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Council of State">Council of State</a> (final decision maker in administrative judiciary) and the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Jurisdictional_Disputes" title="Court of Jurisdictional Disputes">Court of Jurisdictional Disputes</a> (for resolving the disputes between courts for constitutional jurisdiction) are the four organizations that are described by the Constitution as supreme courts. The Constitutional Court is composed of fifteen judges and are appointed by the president and the parliament.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Constitution2019&#95;5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution2019-5"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A member is elected for a term of twelve years and can't be re-elected. The members of the Constitutional Court are obliged to retire when they are over the age of sixty-five.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li></ul>
<p>The three-branch system is known as the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a>, in contrast to the <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a> where the executive is part of the legislative body. 
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Turkey" title="Administrative divisions of Turkey">Administrative divisions of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Regions of Turkey">Regions of Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/NUTS_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="NUTS of Turkey">NUTS of Turkey</a></div>
<p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a>. Its administrative system includes central and local administration. Central administration consists of the <a href="/wiki/Central_government" title="Central government">central government</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a>, and local departments such as 81 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey" title="Provinces of Turkey">provinces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Turkey" title="Districts of Turkey">their subdivisions</a>. Local administration authorities consist of metropolitan municipalities, municipalities, neighborhoods or villages, and special provincial administrations. For economic and geographic reasons, Turkey is also categorized into <a href="/wiki/Geographical_regions_of_Turkey" title="Geographical regions of Turkey">seven regions</a> and 21 sub-regions.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center"><div role="img" class="noresize" style="width: 700px; font-size: 85%; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; color:inherit; position: relative;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:BlankMapTurkeyProvinces.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/BlankMapTurkeyProvinces.png/960px-BlankMapTurkeyProvinces.png" decoding="async" width="700" height="342" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/87/BlankMapTurkeyProvinces.png 1.5x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="500" /></a></span>

</div></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Parties_and_elections">Parties and elections</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Turkey" title="Elections in Turkey">Elections in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Political_parties_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Political parties in Turkey">Political parties in Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Electoral_cycle_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Electoral cycle of Turkey">Electoral cycle of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:262px;max-width:262px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:128px;max-width:128px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:173px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2025_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2025_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2025_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="126" height="173" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2025_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan_2025_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1144" data-file-height="1571" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">Recep Tayyip Erdoğan</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President</a> </small></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:130px;max-width:130px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:173px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Cevdet_Yilmaz_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Cevdet Yılmaz" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Cevdet_Yilmaz_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Cevdet_Yilmaz_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="128" height="173" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Cevdet_Yilmaz_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Cevdet_Yilmaz_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="616" data-file-height="834" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Cevdet_Y%C4%B1lmaz" title="Cevdet Yılmaz">Cevdet Yılmaz</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_Turkey" title="Vice President of Turkey">Vice President</a> </small></div></div></div></div></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:2024_Turkish_local_elections.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/2024_Turkish_local_elections.svg/250px-2024_Turkish_local_elections.svg.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="122" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/2024_Turkish_local_elections.svg/500px-2024_Turkish_local_elections.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="250" /></a><figcaption>Results of the <a href="/wiki/2024_Turkish_local_elections" title="2024 Turkish local elections">2024 Turkish local elections</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Elections in Turkey are held for six functions of government: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_presidential_elections" title="Turkish presidential elections">presidential</a> (national), parliamentary (national), <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_municipalities_in_Turkey" title="Metropolitan municipalities in Turkey">municipality mayors</a> (local), district mayors (local), provincial or <a href="/wiki/List_of_municipalities_in_Turkey" title="List of municipalities in Turkey">municipal council members</a> (local), and <a href="/wiki/Muhtar_(title)" class="mw-redirect" title="Muhtar (title)">muhtars</a> (local). <a href="/wiki/Referendum" title="Referendum">Referendums</a> are also held occasionally. Every Turkish citizen who has turned 18 has the <a href="/wiki/Right_to_vote" class="mw-redirect" title="Right to vote">right to vote</a> and stand as a candidate at elections.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2024)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">Universal suffrage</a> for both sexes has been applied throughout Turkey since 1934.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In Turkey, <a href="/wiki/Voter_turnout" title="Voter turnout">turnout rates</a> of both local and general elections are high compared to many other countries, which usually stands higher than 80%.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2024)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> President <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">Recep Tayyip Erdoğan</a> is currently serving as the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/%C3%96zg%C3%BCr_%C3%96zel" title="Özgür Özel">Özgür Özel</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_Main_Opposition_Leaders_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="List of the Main Opposition Leaders of Turkey">Main Opposition Leader</a>.
</p><p>The Constitutional Court can strip the public financing of <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Turkey" title="List of political parties in Turkey">political parties</a> that it deems <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">anti-secular</a> or having ties to <a href="/wiki/Terrorism_in_Turkey" title="Terrorism in Turkey">terrorism</a>, or ban their existence altogether.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Electoral_threshold" title="Electoral threshold">electoral threshold</a> for political parties at national level is seven percent of the votes.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Smaller parties can avoid the electoral threshold by forming an alliance with other parties. <a href="/wiki/Independent_candidates" class="mw-redirect" title="Independent candidates">Independent candidates</a> are not subject to an electoral threshold.
</p><p>On the right side of the Turkish <a href="/wiki/Political_spectrum" title="Political spectrum">political spectrum</a>, parties like the <a href="/wiki/Democrat_Party_(Turkey,_1946%E2%80%931961)" class="mw-redirect" title="Democrat Party (Turkey, 1946–1961)">Democrat Party</a>, <a href="/wiki/Justice_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice Party (Turkey)">Justice Party</a>, <a href="/wiki/Motherland_Party_(Turkey)" title="Motherland Party (Turkey)">Motherland Party</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">Justice and Development Party</a> became the most popular political parties in Turkey, winning numerous elections. Turkish <a href="/wiki/Right-wing" class="mw-redirect" title="Right-wing">right-wing</a> parties are more likely to embrace the principles of political ideologies such as <a href="/wiki/Conservatism" title="Conservatism">conservatism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nationalism" title="Nationalism">nationalism</a> or <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">Islamism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On the left side of the spectrum, parties like the <a href="/wiki/Republican_People%27s_Party" title="Republican People&#39;s Party">Republican People's Party</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Populist_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Social Democratic Populist Party">Social Democratic Populist Party</a> and <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Left_Party_(Turkey)" title="Democratic Left Party (Turkey)">Democratic Left Party</a> once enjoyed the largest electoral success. <a href="/wiki/Left-wing" class="mw-redirect" title="Left-wing">Left-wing</a> parties are more likely to embrace the principles of <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kemalism" title="Kemalism">Kemalism</a> or <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secularism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357&#95;242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-242"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Law">Law</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Turkey" title="Judicial system of Turkey">Judicial system of Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Turkey" title="Law enforcement in Turkey">Law enforcement in Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_(1).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg/250px-PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg/500px-PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3752" data-file-height="2486" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Justice_Palace" title="Istanbul Justice Palace">Istanbul Justice Palace</a> in Istanbul</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbulAnadoluJusticePalace2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/%C4%B0stanbulAnadoluJusticePalace2.jpg/250px-%C4%B0stanbulAnadoluJusticePalace2.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="141" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/%C4%B0stanbulAnadoluJusticePalace2.jpg/500px-%C4%B0stanbulAnadoluJusticePalace2.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="2268" /></a><figcaption>The Anadolu Justice Palace in Istanbul</figcaption></figure>
<p>With the founding of the Republic, Turkey adopted a <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> legal system, replacing <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a>-derived <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_law" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman law">Ottoman law</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_civil_code_(1926)" title="Turkish civil code (1926)">Civil Code</a>, adopted in 1926, was based on the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Civil_Code" title="Swiss Civil Code">Swiss Civil Code</a> of 1907 and the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Code_of_Obligations" title="Swiss Code of Obligations">Swiss Code of Obligations</a> of 1911. Although it underwent a number of changes in 2002, it retains much of the basis of the original Code. The <a href="/wiki/Criminal_Code" class="mw-redirect" title="Criminal Code">Criminal Code</a>, originally based on the <a href="/wiki/Italian_law_codes#Penal_Code" title="Italian law codes">Italian Criminal Code</a>, was replaced in 2005 by a Code with principles similar to the <a href="/wiki/German_Penal_Code" class="mw-redirect" title="German Penal Code">German Penal Code</a> and German law generally. <a href="/wiki/Administrative_law" title="Administrative law">Administrative law</a> is based on the French equivalent and <a href="/wiki/Procedural_law" title="Procedural law">procedural law</a> generally shows the influence of the Swiss, German and French legal systems.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Islamic principles do not play a part in the legal system.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Turkey" title="Law enforcement in Turkey">Law enforcement in Turkey</a> is carried out by several agencies under the jurisdiction of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Turkey)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)">Ministry of Internal Affairs</a>. These agencies are the <a href="/wiki/General_Directorate_of_Security_(Turkey)" title="General Directorate of Security (Turkey)">General Directorate of Security</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie_General_Command" title="Gendarmerie General Command">Gendarmerie General Command</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Coast_Guard_Command" class="mw-redirect" title="Coast Guard Command">Coast Guard Command</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the years of government by the Justice and Development Party and Erdoğan, particularly since 2013, the independence and integrity of the Turkish judiciary has increasingly been said to be in doubt by institutions, parliamentarians and journalists both within and outside of Turkey, because of political interference in the promotion of judges and prosecutors and in their pursuit of public duty.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-EU2015&#95;246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU2015-246"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-EP2016&#95;247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EP2016-247"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-TI2016&#95;248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TI2016-248"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Turkey" title="Foreign relations of Turkey">Foreign relations of Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:300622-SanchezOTANSegunda3.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/300622-SanchezOTANSegunda3.jpg/250px-300622-SanchezOTANSegunda3.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/300622-SanchezOTANSegunda3.jpg/500px-300622-SanchezOTANSegunda3.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1330" /></a><figcaption>Turkey has been a member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> since 1952, has its second largest army and is the host of the <a href="/wiki/Allied_Land_Command" title="Allied Land Command">Allied Land Command</a> headquarters.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Turkey has been characterized as an <a href="/wiki/Emerging_power" title="Emerging power">emerging</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Acharya&#95;2014&#95;249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Acharya_2014-249"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> rising,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> quasi-regional,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional</a> power.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey's constant foreign policy goal is to pursue its national interests. These interests are mainly growing the economy, and maintaining security from <a href="/wiki/Terrorism_in_Turkey" title="Terrorism in Turkey">internal terrorist</a> and external threats.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After the establishment of the Republic, <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk" class="mw-redirect" title="Atatürk">Atatürk</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0smet_%C4%B0n%C3%B6n%C3%BC" title="İsmet İnönü">İnönü</a> followed the "<a href="/wiki/Peace_at_home,_peace_in_the_world" title="Peace at home, peace in the world">peace at home, peace in the world</a>" principle until the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>'s start.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto4&#95;256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-256"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following <a href="/wiki/Soviet_territorial_claims_against_Turkey" title="Soviet territorial claims against Turkey">threats from the Soviet Union</a>, Turkey sought to <a href="/wiki/Turkey%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Turkey–United States relations">ally with the United States</a> and joined <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> in 1952.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto4&#95;256-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-256"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Organization_of_Turkic_States_(orthographic_projection).svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Organization_of_Turkic_States_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/250px-Organization_of_Turkic_States_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="250" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Organization_of_Turkic_States_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/500px-Organization_of_Turkic_States_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="553" data-file-height="553" /></a><figcaption>Members and observers of the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Turkic_States" title="Organization of Turkic States">Organization of Turkic States</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Overall, Turkey aims for good relations with <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, Russia, the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>, and Iran. With the West, Turkey also aims to keep its arrangements.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Martin&#95;2012&#95;234–235&#95;258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martin_2012_234–235-258"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By trading with the east and joining the EU, Turkey pursues economic growth.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Martin&#95;2012&#95;234–235&#95;258-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martin_2012_234–235-258"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">European Union Customs Union</a> in 1995,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> but <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">its EU accession talks</a> are frozen as of 2024.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey has sought closer relations with the Central Asian Turkic states after the breakup of the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Martin&#95;2012&#95;230&#95;261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martin_2012_230-261"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Closer <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan%E2%80%93Turkey_relations" title="Azerbaijan–Turkey relations">relations with Azerbaijan</a>, a culturally close country, was achieved.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Martin&#95;2012&#95;230&#95;261-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martin_2012_230-261"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/International_Organization_of_Turkic_Culture" title="International Organization of Turkic Culture">International Organization of Turkic Culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Turkic_States" title="Organization of Turkic States">Organization of Turkic States</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is also a member of <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Cooperation_in_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe">Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a>, Turkey had problems with countries such as United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, and Egypt.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Reuters&#95;19&#95;May&#95;2023&#95;265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters_19_May_2023-265"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Relations with these countries have improved since then.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Reuters&#95;19&#95;May&#95;2023&#95;265-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters_19_May_2023-265"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are disputes <a href="/wiki/Aegean_dispute" title="Aegean dispute">with Greece over maritime boundaries</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cyprus%E2%80%93Turkey_maritime_zones_dispute" title="Cyprus–Turkey maritime zones dispute">with Cyprus</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2018, the Turkish military and the Turkish-backed forces began an <a href="/wiki/Operation_Olive_Branch" title="Operation Olive Branch">operation in Syria</a> aimed at ousting US-backed <a href="/wiki/YPG" class="mw-redirect" title="YPG">YPG</a> (which Turkey considers to be an offshoot of the outlawed <a href="/wiki/PKK" class="mw-redirect" title="PKK">PKK</a>)<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Atlantic-Council&#95;269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atlantic-Council-269"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Ministry&#95;Foreign&#95;Affairs&#95;statement&#95;169-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ministry_Foreign_Affairs_statement-169"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> from the enclave of <a href="/wiki/Afrin,_Syria" title="Afrin, Syria">Afrin</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-TRT-World-25-05-2022&#95;271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TRT-World-25-05-2022-271"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey has also conducted airstrikes in <a href="/wiki/Iraqi_Kurdistan" title="Iraqi Kurdistan">Iraqi Kurdistan</a>, which was criticized by Iraq for violating its sovereignty and killing civilians.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Turkey_relations" title="Israel–Turkey relations">Diplomatic relations with Israel</a> were damaged after the <a href="/wiki/2010_Gaza_flotilla_raid" title="2010 Gaza flotilla raid">2010 Gaza flotilla raid</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> normalized in 2016,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and cut again following the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_invasion_of_the_Gaza_Strip" class="mw-redirect" title="Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip">Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Reuters&#95;28&#95;May&#95;2024&#95;275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters_28_May_2024-275"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2024, Turkey stopped trading with Israel.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Reuters&#95;28&#95;May&#95;2024&#95;275-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters_28_May_2024-275"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Military">Military</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">Turkish Armed Forces</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Land_Forces" title="Turkish Land Forces">Turkish Land Forces</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Naval_Forces" title="Turkish Naval Forces">Turkish Naval Forces</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Air_Force" title="Turkish Air Force">Turkish Air Force</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:IMG-TAI-TFX.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/IMG-TAI-TFX.jpg/250px-IMG-TAI-TFX.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/IMG-TAI-TFX.jpg/500px-IMG-TAI-TFX.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4096" data-file-height="2730" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/TAI_TF_Kaan" title="TAI TF Kaan">TAI TF Kaan</a> is currently being produced by <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Aerospace_Industries" title="Turkish Aerospace Industries">Turkish Aerospace Industries</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Air_Force" title="Turkish Air Force">Turkish Air Force</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">Turkish Armed Forces</a> are responsible for defense against foreign threats. While the Commander-in-Chief is the President, <a href="/wiki/General_Staff_of_the_Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="General Staff of the Turkish Armed Forces">General Staff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Air_Force" title="Turkish Air Force">Air Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Naval_Forces" title="Turkish Naval Forces">Naval Force</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Land_Forces" title="Turkish Land Forces">Land Force</a> usually report to the Minister of National Defence.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie_General_Command" title="Gendarmerie General Command">Gendarmerie General Command</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Coast_Guard_Command" class="mw-redirect" title="Coast Guard Command">Coast Guard Command</a> are under the jurisdiction of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Turkey)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)">Ministry of the Interior</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Turkey" title="Conscription in Turkey">Military service is required</a> for 6–12 months for men,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which is reduced to one month after paying a fee.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey does not recognize <a href="/wiki/Conscientious_objection" class="mw-redirect" title="Conscientious objection">conscientious objection</a> and does not offer a <a href="/wiki/Alternative_civilian_service" title="Alternative civilian service">civilian alternative</a> to military service.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Baykar_Bayraktar_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lelma_2.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Baykar_Bayraktar_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lelma_2.png/250px-Baykar_Bayraktar_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lelma_2.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="141" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Baykar_Bayraktar_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lelma_2.png/500px-Baykar_Bayraktar_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lelma_2.png 1.5x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1080" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Bayraktar_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lelma" title="Bayraktar Kızılelma">Baykar Kızılelma</a> UCAV on <a href="/wiki/TCG_Anadolu" title="TCG Anadolu">TCG Anadolu</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Turkey has the <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO#Military_personnel" title="Member states of NATO">second-largest military force</a> in NATO, after the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">United States</a>, with an estimated strength of 890,700 military personnel as of February 2022.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-iiss-mb-2022&#95;284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iiss-mb-2022-284"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey is considered a significant power in <a href="/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle" title="Unmanned aerial vehicle">unmanned aerial vehicles</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As part of the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_sharing" title="Nuclear sharing">nuclear sharing</a> policy of NATO, Turkey hosts approximately 20 United States <a href="/wiki/B61_nuclear_bomb" title="B61 nuclear bomb">B61 nuclear bombs</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Incirlik_Air_Base" title="Incirlik Air Base">Incirlik Air Base</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In recent years, <a href="/wiki/Defense_industry_of_Turkey" title="Defense industry of Turkey">Turkey's defense industry</a> has developed rapidly.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aselsan" title="Aselsan">Aselsan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Aerospace_Industries" title="Turkish Aerospace Industries">Turkish Aerospace Industries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roketsan" title="Roketsan">Roketsan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/ASFAT" title="ASFAT">ASFAT</a> are among the top 100 defense companies in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey has participated in international missions under the United Nations and NATO <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Brigade" title="Turkish Brigade">since the Korean War</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> missions in <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Operation_in_Somalia_I" title="United Nations Operation in Somalia I">Somalia</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Protection_Force" title="United Nations Protection Force">Yugoslavia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Ocean_Shield" title="Operation Ocean Shield">Horn of Africa</a>. It supported <a href="/wiki/Coalition_of_the_Gulf_War" title="Coalition of the Gulf War">coalition forces</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">First Gulf War</a>, contributed military personnel to the <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">International Security Assistance Force</a> in Afghanistan, and remains active in <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Force" title="Kosovo Force">Kosovo Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurocorps" title="Eurocorps">Eurocorps</a> and <a href="/wiki/EU_Battlegroup" class="mw-redirect" title="EU Battlegroup">EU Battlegroups</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Enter&#95;the&#95;EU&#95;Battle&#95;Groups&#95;290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Enter_the_EU_Battle_Groups-290"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-tskpeace&#95;291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tskpeace-291"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2016, Turkey has assisted <a href="/wiki/Peshmerga" title="Peshmerga">Peshmerga</a> forces in northern <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Somali_Armed_Forces" title="Somali Armed Forces">Somali Armed Forces</a> with security and training.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-hurriyetdailynews.comq&#95;292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hurriyetdailynews.comq-292"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-reuters.comq&#95;293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters.comq-293"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Turkish Armed Forces have a relatively substantial military presence abroad,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_with_overseas_military_bases" title="List of countries with overseas military bases">military bases</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pasha_Liman_Base" title="Pasha Liman Base">Albania</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-LarrabeeLesser94&#95;295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LarrabeeLesser94-295"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>292<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iraq%E2%80%93Turkey_relations#Turkish_military_presence_in_Iraq" title="Iraq–Turkey relations">Iraq</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Qatar%E2%80%93Turkey_relations#Turkish_military_presence_in_Qatar" title="Qatar–Turkey relations">Qatar</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Camp_TURKSOM" title="Camp TURKSOM">Somalia</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The country also maintains a force of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_military_forces_in_Northern_Cyprus" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish military forces in Northern Cyprus">36,000 troops</a> in <a href="/wiki/Northern_Cyprus" title="Northern Cyprus">Northern Cyprus</a> since 1974.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Richmond1998&#95;299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Richmond1998-299"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>296<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Human_rights">Human rights</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Turkey" title="Human rights in Turkey">Human rights in Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg/250px-Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg/500px-Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" /></a><figcaption>Women demonstrating and asking for non-interference with their clothing in <a href="/wiki/Kad%C4%B1k%C3%B6y" title="Kadıköy">Kadıköy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>297<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Article 2 of the Turkish Constitution includes references to upholding the rule of law and human rights.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>298<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 2000s, legal changes were made for public use of and teaching in the Kurdish language. This included opening a <a href="/wiki/TRT_Kurd%C3%AE" title="TRT Kurdî">Kurdish-language national TV channel</a>. Various "openings" were made to address concerns of minorities such as <a href="/wiki/Alevi" class="mw-redirect" title="Alevi">Alevi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Turkey" title="Kurds in Turkey">ethnic Kurds</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Romani_people_in_Turkey" title="Romani people in Turkey">ethnic Romani people</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Toprak&#95;2012&#95;p222&#95;302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toprak_2012_p222-302"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Sentences for violence against women were strengthened.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Toprak&#95;2012&#95;p222&#95;302-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toprak_2012_p222-302"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, <a href="/wiki/Gezi_Park_protests" title="Gezi Park protests">widespread protests</a> erupted, sparked by a plan to demolish <a href="/wiki/Gezi_Park" title="Gezi Park">Gezi Park</a> but soon growing into general anti-government dissent.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>300<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 20 May 2016, the Turkish parliament stripped almost a quarter of its members of immunity from prosecution, including 101 deputies from the pro-Kurdish <a href="/wiki/Peoples%27_Democratic_Party_(Turkey)" title="Peoples&#39; Democratic Party (Turkey)">HDP</a> and the main opposition <a href="/wiki/Republican_People%27s_Party" title="Republican People&#39;s Party">CHP</a> party.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>301<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-european&#95;court&#95;305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-european_court-305"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>302<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Committee_to_Protect_Journalists" title="Committee to Protect Journalists">Committee to Protect Journalists</a>, there are 13 jailed journalists in Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In its 2023 report, the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a> criticized how democratic institutions in Turkey operate.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>304<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The criticism was rejected by Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2023, Turkey was the country with the highest number of <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights" title="European Court of Human Rights">European Court of Human Rights</a> cases.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg/250px-Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg/500px-Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="640" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Pride" title="Istanbul Pride">Istanbul Pride</a> was organized in 2003 for the first time. Since 2015, parades in Istanbul have been denied permission by the government.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bianet&#95;–&#95;Bagimsiz&#95;Iletisim&#95;Agi&#95;310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bianet_–_Bagimsiz_Iletisim_Agi-310"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Prior to 1858, Ottoman Empire had "a lenient legal accommodation of same-sex intimacy". When prosecuted, the punishment was monetary fines.
