In 1858, the 1810 French Penal Code was adopted by the Ottomans, which had no penalties for same-sex intimacy that is private.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>308<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under the Republic, same sex acts have never been criminalized.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>309<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, LGBT people in Turkey face discrimination, harassment and even violence.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>310<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In a survey conducted in 2016, 33% of respondents said that LGBT people should have equal rights, which increased to 45% in 2020. Another survey in 2018 found that the proportion of people who would not want a homosexual neighbor decreased from 55% in 2018 to 47% in 2019.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>312<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>When the annual <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Pride" title="Istanbul Pride">Istanbul Pride</a> was inaugurated in 2003, Turkey became the first Muslim-majority country to hold a gay pride march.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since 2015, parades at <a href="/wiki/Taksim_Square" title="Taksim Square">Taksim Square</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stiklal_Avenue" title="İstiklal Avenue">İstiklal Avenue</a> have been denied government permission, citing security concerns, but hundreds of people have defied the ban each year.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bianet&#95;–&#95;Bagimsiz&#95;Iletisim&#95;Agi&#95;310-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bianet_–_Bagimsiz_Iletisim_Agi-310"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The bans were criticized.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bianet&#95;–&#95;Bagimsiz&#95;Iletisim&#95;Agi&#95;310-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bianet_–_Bagimsiz_Iletisim_Agi-310"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Economy">Economy</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Turkey" title="Economy of Turkey">Economy of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Turkey" title="Tourism in Turkey">Tourism in Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:T%C3%BCrkiye-gdp-worldbank-constant-usd.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/T%C3%BCrkiye-gdp-worldbank-constant-usd.png/250px-T%C3%BCrkiye-gdp-worldbank-constant-usd.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="176" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/T%C3%BCrkiye-gdp-worldbank-constant-usd.png/500px-T%C3%BCrkiye-gdp-worldbank-constant-usd.png 1.5x" data-file-width="3400" data-file-height="2400" /></a><figcaption>Turkey's nominal <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> between 1960 and 2023 in 2015 <a href="/wiki/Constant_dollars" class="mw-redirect" title="Constant dollars">constant US dollars</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>314<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>315<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Turkey is an <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_income" title="Gross national income">upper-middle</a>-income country and an <a href="/wiki/Emerging_market" title="Emerging market">emerging market</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-WorldBank&#95;Overview&#95;April&#95;2024&#95;196-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WorldBank_Overview_April_2024-196"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>316<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A founding member of the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> and <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, it has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">16th-largest economy by nominal</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">11th-largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>-adjusted GDP in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-IMFWEO.TR&#95;8-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEO.TR-8"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is classified among <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Newly industrialized countries">newly industrialized countries</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Service_sector" class="mw-redirect" title="Service sector">service sector</a> accounts for 61% of the economy, whereas industry accounts for 32% and agriculture contributes about 7%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>317<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/IMF" class="mw-redirect" title="IMF">IMF</a> estimates, Turkey's GDP per capita by PPP is $43,790 in 2025, while its nominal GDP per capita is $18,200.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-IMFWEO.TR&#95;8-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEO.TR-8"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">Foreign direct investment</a> in Turkey peaked at $22.05 billion in 2007 and dropped to $13.09 billion in 2022.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>318<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Potential growth is weakened by long-lasting structural and macro obstacles, such as slow rates of productivity growth and high inflation.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-WorldBank&#95;Overview&#95;April&#95;2024&#95;196-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WorldBank_Overview_April_2024-196"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey has a diversified economy; main industries include automobiles, electronics, textiles, construction, steel, mining, and food processing.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-World&#95;Factbook&#95;Economy&#95;322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Factbook_Economy-322"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>319<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Machinery and manufacturing lead among products in Turkey's merchandise exports.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>320<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_producing_countries_of_agricultural_commodities" title="List of largest producing countries of agricultural commodities">major agricultural producer</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>321<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It ranks <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_steel_production" title="List of countries by steel production">8th in crude steel production</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_motor_vehicle_production" title="List of countries by motor vehicle production">13th in motor vehicle production</a>, ship building (by <a href="/wiki/Tonnage" title="Tonnage">tonnage</a>), and annual industrial robot installation in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Turkey" title="Automotive industry in Turkey">Turkish automative companies</a> include <a href="/wiki/TEMSA" title="TEMSA">TEMSA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otokar" title="Otokar">Otokar</a>, <a href="/wiki/BMC_(Turkey)" class="mw-redirect" title="BMC (Turkey)">BMC</a> and <a href="/wiki/Togg" title="Togg">Togg</a>. Togg is the first all-electric vehicle company of Turkey. <a href="/wiki/Ar%C3%A7elik" title="Arçelik">Arçelik</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vestel" title="Vestel">Vestel</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Beko" title="Beko">Beko</a> are major manufacturers of consumer electronics.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Arçelik is one of the largest producers of household goods in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2022, Turkey ranked second in the world in terms of the number of international contractors in the top 250 list.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is also the fifth largest in the world in terms of textile exports.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Bodrum_-_39976741843.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Bodrum_-_39976741843.jpg/250px-Bodrum_-_39976741843.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Bodrum_-_39976741843.jpg/500px-Bodrum_-_39976741843.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4272" data-file-height="2856" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Bodrum" title="Bodrum">Bodrum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Riviera" title="Turkish Riviera">Turkish Riviera</a>. Bodrum peninsula is a high-end spot for vacationers.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>327<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Turkey's services exports are mostly transport and tourism.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>328<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Tourism accounts for about 8% of Turkey's GDP.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>329<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2024, Turkey <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings#Most_visited_destinations_by_international_tourist_arrivals" title="World Tourism rankings">ranked fourth in the world</a> in the number of international tourist arrivals with 60.6 million foreign tourists.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>330<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey has <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">22 UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey_(Tentative_list)" class="mw-redirect" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey (Tentative list)">84 World Heritage Sites in tentative list</a>. Turkey is home to 625 <a href="/wiki/Blue_Flag_beaches" class="mw-redirect" title="Blue Flag beaches">Blue Flag beaches</a>, third most in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>331<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2024, <a href="/wiki/Euromonitor_International" title="Euromonitor International">Euromonitor International</a> ranked <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antalya" title="Antalya">Antalya</a> among <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_international_visitors" title="List of cities by international visitors">the top ten most visited cities in the world</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>332<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Airlines" title="Turkish Airlines">Turkish Airlines</a> is one of the <a href="/wiki/Largest_airlines_in_the_world" title="Largest airlines in the world">largest airlines in the world</a>.
</p><p>Between 2007 and 2021, the share of population below the PPP-$6.85 per day <a href="/wiki/Poverty_threshold" title="Poverty threshold">international poverty threshold</a> declined from 20% to 7.6%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-WorldBank&#95;Overview&#95;April&#95;2024&#95;196-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WorldBank_Overview_April_2024-196"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2023, 13.9% of the population was below the national at-risk-of-poverty rate.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>333<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2021, 34% of the population were at risk of poverty or social exclusion, using <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a> definition.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>334<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Unemployment in Turkey was 10.4% in 2022.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>335<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2021, it was estimated that 47% of total disposable income was received by the top 20% of income earners, while the lowest 20% received only 6%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>336<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Compared to the OECD average, <a href="/wiki/Labor_force_participation" class="mw-redirect" title="Labor force participation">labor force participation</a> of women is lower. Affordable <a href="/wiki/Childcare" class="mw-redirect" title="Childcare">childcare</a> and better <a href="/wiki/Parental_leave" title="Parental leave">parental leave</a> policies are needed to lift women's employment.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto9&#95;225-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto9-225"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Turkey" title="Energy in Turkey">Energy in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Turkey" title="Renewable energy in Turkey">Renewable energy in Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Turkey" title="Transport in Turkey">Transport in Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Communications_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Communications in Turkey">Communications in Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Turkey" title="Water supply and sanitation in Turkey">Water supply and sanitation in Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:T%C3%BCrkiye_installed_electricity_capacity.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/T%C3%BCrkiye_installed_electricity_capacity.png/250px-T%C3%BCrkiye_installed_electricity_capacity.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="138" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/T%C3%BCrkiye_installed_electricity_capacity.png/500px-T%C3%BCrkiye_installed_electricity_capacity.png 1.5x" data-file-width="920" data-file-height="506" /></a><figcaption>Installed electricity capacity in Turkey between 2000 and 2024 in terms of gigawatts<sup id="cite&#95;ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>337<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Turkey is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_electricity_production" title="List of countries by electricity production">15th-largest electricity</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_renewable_electricity_production" title="List of countries by renewable electricity production">13th-largest renewable electricity</a> producer in the world. <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Turkey" title="Energy in Turkey">Turkey's energy generation</a> capacity increased significantly, with <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Turkey" title="Renewable energy in Turkey">electricity generation from renewable sources</a> tripling in the past decade.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>338<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>339<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It produced 43.8% of <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Electricity sector in Turkey">its electricity</a> from such sources in 2019.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>340<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey is also the <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_power#Utility-grade_stations" title="Geothermal power">fourth-largest producer</a> of <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_energy_in_Turkey" title="Geothermal energy in Turkey">geothermal power</a> in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-2019&#95;Capacity&#95;344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2019_Capacity-344"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>341<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey's first nuclear power station, <a href="/wiki/Akkuyu_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant">Akkuyu</a>, will increase diversification of its energy mix.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-IEA&#95;2021&#95;345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IEA_2021-345"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>342<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> When it comes to <a href="/wiki/World_energy_supply_and_consumption#Final_consumption" title="World energy supply and consumption">total final consumption</a>, fossil fuels still play a large role, accounting for 73%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>343<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A major reason of <a href="/wiki/Turkey%27s_greenhouse_gas_emissions" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkey&#39;s greenhouse gas emissions">Turkey's greenhouse gas emissions</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Coal_in_Turkey" title="Coal in Turkey">large proportion of coal</a> in the energy system.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>344<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2017, while the government had invested in low carbon energy transition, <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel_subsidies" title="Fossil fuel subsidies">fossil fuels were still subsidized</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>345<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By 2053, Turkey aims to have <a href="/wiki/Net_zero_emissions" class="mw-redirect" title="Net zero emissions">net zero emissions</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-World&#95;Bank&#95;Türkiye&#95;224-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank_Türkiye-224"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto9&#95;225-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto9-225"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg/250px-%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="104" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg/500px-%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4787" data-file-height="1985" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Airport" title="Istanbul Airport">Istanbul Airport</a> is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="List of busiest airports by passenger traffic">top 10 busiest airports in the world</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Turkey has made security of its energy supply a top priority, given its heavy reliance on gas and oil imports.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-IEA&#95;2021&#95;345-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IEA_2021-345"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>342<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey's main energy supply sources are <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Russia" title="Energy in Russia">Russia</a>, West Asia, and Central Asia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Martin&#95;2012&#95;234–235&#95;258-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martin_2012_234–235-258"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gas_in_Turkey" title="Gas in Turkey">Gas production</a> began in 2023 in the recently discovered <a href="/wiki/Sakarya_gas_field" title="Sakarya gas field">Sakarya gas field</a>. When fully operational, it will supply about 30% of the natural gas needed domestically.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>346<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>347<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey aims to become a hub for regional energy transportation.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Novikau&#95;Muhasilović&#95;2023&#95;351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Novikau_Muhasilović_2023-351"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Several oil and gas pipelines span the country, including the <a href="/wiki/Blue_Stream" title="Blue Stream">Blue Stream</a>, <a href="/wiki/TurkStream" title="TurkStream">TurkStream</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan" class="mw-redirect" title="Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan">Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan</a> pipelines.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Novikau&#95;Muhasilović&#95;2023&#95;351-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Novikau_Muhasilović_2023-351"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2023, Turkey has 3,726 kilometers of <a href="/wiki/Otoyol" title="Otoyol">controlled-access highways</a> and 29,373 kilometers of <a href="/wiki/Divided_highways" class="mw-redirect" title="Divided highways">divided highways</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Multiple bridges and tunnels connect Asian and European sides of Turkey; the <a href="/wiki/%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge" class="mw-redirect" title="Çanakkale 1915 Bridge">Çanakkale 1915 Bridge</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">Dardanelles</a> strait is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_longest_suspension_bridge_spans#Completed_suspension_bridges" title="List of longest suspension bridge spans">longest suspension bridge in the world</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marmaray" title="Marmaray">Marmaray</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eurasia_Tunnel" title="Eurasia Tunnel">Eurasia</a> tunnels under the <a href="/wiki/Bosporus" title="Bosporus">Bosporus</a> connect both sides of Istanbul.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Osman_Gazi_Bridge" title="Osman Gazi Bridge">Osman Gazi Bridge</a> connects the northern and southern shores of the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_%C4%B0zmit" title="Gulf of İzmit">Gulf of İzmit</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Railways" title="Turkish State Railways">Turkish State Railways</a> operates both conventional and high speed trains, with the government expanding both.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>352<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Turkey" title="High-speed rail in Turkey">High-speed rail</a> lines include the <a href="/wiki/Ankara-Istanbul_high-speed_railway" class="mw-redirect" title="Ankara-Istanbul high-speed railway">Ankara-Istanbul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ankara-Konya_high-speed_railway" class="mw-redirect" title="Ankara-Konya high-speed railway">Ankara-Konya</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ankara%E2%80%93Sivas_high-speed_railway" title="Ankara–Sivas high-speed railway">Ankara-Sivas</a> routes.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>353<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Metro" title="Istanbul Metro">Istanbul Metro</a> is the largest subway network in the country with around 704 million annual ridership in 2019.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Turkey" title="List of airports in Turkey">115 airports</a> as of 2024.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-CIA&#95;transport&#95;358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_transport-358"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Airport" title="Istanbul Airport">Istanbul Airport</a> is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="List of busiest airports by passenger traffic">top 10 busiest airports</a> in the world. Turkey aims to become a transportation hub.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>356<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Atlı&#95;2018&#95;360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atlı_2018-360"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is part of various routes that connect Asia and Europe, including <a href="/wiki/Trans-Caspian_International_Transport_Route" title="Trans-Caspian International Transport Route">the Middle Corridor</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Atlı&#95;2018&#95;360-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atlı_2018-360"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2024, Turkey, Iraq, UAE, and Qatar signed an agreement to link Iraqi port facilities to Turkey via road and rail connections.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Turkey" title="Science and technology in Turkey">Science and technology in Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Scientific_and_Technological_Research_Council_of_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey">Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:TaiIDEF2015_(8).JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG/250px-TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="250" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG/500px-TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG 1.5x" data-file-width="3696" data-file-height="2448" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-1" title="Göktürk-1">Göktürk-1</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-2" title="Göktürk-2">Göktürk-2</a> and <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-3" title="Göktürk-3">Göktürk-3</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Earth_observation_satellite" title="Earth observation satellite">Earth observation satellites</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defense_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of National Defense (Turkey)">Turkish Ministry of National Defense</a>, while state-owned <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrksat_(company)" title="Türksat (company)">Türksat</a> operates the <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrksat_(satellite)" title="Türksat (satellite)">Türksat series</a> of <a href="/wiki/Communications_satellite" title="Communications satellite">communications satellites</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Turkey's spending on <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> as a share of GDP has risen from 0.47% in 2000 to 1.40% in 2023,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> although it is still around half of the average for the OECD.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto2&#95;363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_scientific_and_technical_journal_articles" title="List of countries by number of scientific and technical journal articles">Turkey ranks 16th in the world</a> in terms of article output in scientific and technical journals, and 35th in <a href="/wiki/Nature_Index" title="Nature Index">Nature Index</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>361<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkish patent office ranks 21st worldwide in overall patent applications, and 3rd in industrial design applications. Vast majority of applicants to the Turkish patent office are Turkish residents. In all patent offices globally, <a href="/wiki/World_Intellectual_Property_Indicators#Latest_filing_trends_by_country_of_origin" title="World Intellectual Property Indicators">Turkish residents rank 21st for overall patent applications</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-WIPO&#95;Türkiye&#95;366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WIPO_Türkiye-366"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>363<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2025, Turkey ranked 43rd in the world in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>364<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/T%C3%9CB%C4%B0TAK" class="mw-redirect" title="TÜBİTAK">TÜBİTAK</a> is one of the main agencies for funding and carrying out research.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>366<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-euraxess&#95;Türkiye&#95;370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euraxess_Türkiye-370"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Although Turkey needs more national innovation,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>369<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> it is improving in areas such as high technology and defense.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto2&#95;363-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> To boost the output of high-<a href="/wiki/Value-added" class="mw-redirect" title="Value-added">value-added</a> products, Turkey launched its National Technology Initiative in 2019.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>370<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In line with its research priorities, Turkey developed roadmaps in various areas such as <a href="/wiki/Materials_science" title="Materials science">advanced materials</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence" title="Artificial intelligence">artificial intelligence</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Internet_of_things" title="Internet of things">internet of things</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nanoelectronics" title="Nanoelectronics">nanoelectronics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">robotics</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Quantum_technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Quantum technology">quantum technology</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-euraxess&#95;Türkiye&#95;370-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euraxess_Türkiye-370"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some of the main science and technology programs include the National Research Program, Industry and Technology Strategy, Climate Change Strategy, National Artificial Intelligence Strategy, and <a href="/wiki/Space_program_of_Turkey" title="Space program of Turkey">National Space Program</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-euraxess&#95;Türkiye&#95;370-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euraxess_Türkiye-370"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2024 and 2025, Turkey's first <a href="/wiki/Electron_accelerator" class="mw-redirect" title="Electron accelerator">electron accelerator</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>371<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Quantum_computer" class="mw-redirect" title="Quantum computer">quantum computer</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>372<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrksat_6A" title="Türksat 6A">communication satellite manufactured domestically</a> became operational.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>373<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Demographics">Demographics</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Turkey" title="Demographics of Turkey">Demographics of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turkish people</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Historical_peninsula_and_modern_skyline_of_Istanbul.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Historical_peninsula_and_modern_skyline_of_Istanbul.jpg/250px-Historical_peninsula_and_modern_skyline_of_Istanbul.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="121" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Historical_peninsula_and_modern_skyline_of_Istanbul.jpg/500px-Historical_peninsula_and_modern_skyline_of_Istanbul.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3301" data-file-height="1595" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> is Turkey's largest city<sup id="cite&#95;ref-2021stat&#95;377-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2021stat-377"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>374<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and its economic and financial center.</figcaption></figure>
<p>According to the <i>Address-Based Population Recording System</i>, the country's population was 85,372,377 in 2023, excluding Syrians under temporary protection.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Population&#95;of&#95;Turkey&#95;7-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Population_of_Turkey-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 93% lived in <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">province and district centers</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Population&#95;of&#95;Turkey&#95;7-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Population_of_Turkey-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> People within the 15–64 and 0–14 age groups corresponded to 68.3% and 21.4% of the total population, respectively. Those aged 65 years or older made up 10.2%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Population&#95;of&#95;Turkey&#95;7-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Population_of_Turkey-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Between 1950 and 2020, Turkey's population more than quadrupled from 20.9 million to 83.6 million;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>375<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> however, the population growth rate was 0.1% in 2023.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Population&#95;of&#95;Turkey&#95;7-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Population_of_Turkey-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2023, the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> was 1.51 children per woman, <a href="/wiki/Sub-replacement_fertility" title="Sub-replacement fertility">below the replacement rate of 2.10 per woman</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In a 2018 health survey, the ideal children number was 2.8 children per woman, rising to 3 per married woman.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>377<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1219497266">.mw-parser-output .largestCities-table-background{background:#f9f9f9;color:#222}.mw-parser-output .largestCities-cell-background{background:#f0f0f0;color:#222}</style>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray;">
