<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Gaziantep" title="Gaziantep">Gaziantep</a></td>
<td style="text-align:right;">2,164,134</td>
<td class="largestCities-cell-background" style="text-align:center;">19</td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Ayd%C4%B1n" title="Aydın">Aydın</a></td>
<td style="text-align:right;">1,161,702
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="largestCities-cell-background" style="text-align:center;">10</td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Kocaeli_Province" title="Kocaeli Province">Kocaeli</a></td>
<td style="text-align:right;">2,102,907</td>
<td class="largestCities-cell-background" style="text-align:center;">20</td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Van,_Turkey" title="Van, Turkey">Van</a></td>
<td style="text-align:right;">1,127,612
</td></tr>
</tbody></table></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Ethnicity_and_language">Ethnicity and language</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turkish people</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minorities_in_Turkey" title="Minorities in Turkey">Minorities in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Turkey" title="Languages of Turkey">Languages of Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish language</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Kurdish_population_by_region_(KONDA_2010).png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Kurdish_population_by_region_%28KONDA_2010%29.png/330px-Kurdish_population_by_region_%28KONDA_2010%29.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="141" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Kurdish_population_by_region_%28KONDA_2010%29.png/500px-Kurdish_population_by_region_%28KONDA_2010%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Kurdish_population_by_region_%28KONDA_2010%29.png/960px-Kurdish_population_by_region_%28KONDA_2010%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1579" data-file-height="677" /></a><figcaption>Percentage of <a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Turkey" title="Kurds in Turkey">ethnic Kurds in Turkey</a> by region (2010)<sup id="cite&#95;ref-KONDAkurd&#95;381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KONDAkurd-381"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Article 66 of the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Constitution">Turkish Constitution</a> defines a <i>Turk</i> as anyone who is a citizen.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is estimated that there are at least 47 ethnic groups represented in Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-mutlu&#95;383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mutlu-383"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>380<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Reliable data on the ethnic mix of the population is not available because census figures do not include statistics on ethnicity after the <a href="/wiki/1965_Turkish_census" title="1965 Turkish census">1965 Turkish census</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Turkey&#95;Ethnic&#95;groups&#95;384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Turkey_Ethnic_groups-384"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>381<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">the World Factbook</a>, 70–75% of the country's citizens are ethnic Turks.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Based on a survey, <a href="/wiki/KONDA_Research_and_Consultancy" title="KONDA Research and Consultancy">KONDA</a>'s estimation was 76% in 2006, with 78% of adult citizens self-identifying their ethnic background as <i>Turk</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-KONDA&#95;2006&#95;17&#95;385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KONDA_2006_17-385"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2021, 77% of adult citizens identified as such in a survey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Konda&#95;100&#95;386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Konda_100-386"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Turkey" title="Kurds in Turkey">Kurds</a> are the largest ethnic minority.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kirişci&#95;1997&#95;119–121&#95;387-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kirişci_1997_119–121-387"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Their exact numbers remain disputed,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kirişci&#95;1997&#95;119–121&#95;387-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kirişci_1997_119–121-387"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with estimates ranging from 12 to 20% of the population.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Kurds make up a majority in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/A%C4%9Fr%C4%B1_Province" title="Ağrı Province">Ağrı</a>, <a href="/wiki/Batman_Province" title="Batman Province">Batman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bing%C3%B6l_Province" title="Bingöl Province">Bingöl</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bitlis_Province" title="Bitlis Province">Bitlis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diyarbak%C4%B1r_Province" title="Diyarbakır Province">Diyarbakır</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hakkari_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Hakkari Province">Hakkari</a>, <a href="/wiki/I%C4%9Fd%C4%B1r_Province" title="Iğdır Province">Iğdır</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mardin_Province" title="Mardin Province">Mardin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mu%C5%9F_Province" title="Muş Province">Muş</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siirt_Province" title="Siirt Province">Siirt</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%9E%C4%B1rnak_Province" title="Şırnak Province">Şırnak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tunceli_Province" title="Tunceli Province">Tunceli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Van_Province" title="Van Province">Van</a>; a near majority in <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Eanl%C4%B1urfa_Province" title="Şanlıurfa Province">Şanlıurfa</a> (47%); and a large minority in <a href="/wiki/Kars_Province" title="Kars Province">Kars</a> (20%).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>386<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In addition, internal migration has resulted in <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_diaspora" class="mw-redirect" title="Kurdish diaspora">Kurdish diaspora</a> communities in all of the major cities in central and western Turkey. In Istanbul, there are an estimated three million Kurds, making it the city with the largest Kurdish population in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Nachmani2003&#95;390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nachmani2003-390"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 19% of adult citizens identified as ethnic Kurds in a survey in 2021.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Konda&#95;100&#95;386-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Konda_100-386"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some people have multiple ethnic identities, such as both Turk and Kurd.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>388<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>389<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2006, an estimated 2.7 million ethnic Turks and Kurds were related from interethnic marriages.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Map-TurkicLanguages.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Map-TurkicLanguages.png/330px-Map-TurkicLanguages.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="145" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Map-TurkicLanguages.png/500px-Map-TurkicLanguages.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Map-TurkicLanguages.png/960px-Map-TurkicLanguages.png 2x" data-file-width="1425" data-file-height="625" /></a><figcaption>Areas with speakers of <a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic languages</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>According to the World Factbook, non-Kurdish ethnic minorities are 7–12% of the population.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;13-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2006, KONDA estimated that non-Kurdish and non-Zaza ethnic minorities constituted 8.2% of the population; these were people who gave general descriptions such as Turkish citizen, people with <a href="/wiki/Turkic_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkic people">other Turkic backgrounds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Turkey" title="Arabs in Turkey">Arabs</a>, and others.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-KONDA&#95;2006&#95;17&#95;385-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KONDA_2006_17-385"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2021, 4% of adult citizens identified as non-ethnic Turk or non-ethnic Kurd in a survey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Konda&#95;100&#95;386-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Konda_100-386"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the Constitutional Court, there are only four officially recognized <a href="/wiki/Minorities_in_Turkey" title="Minorities in Turkey">minorities in Turkey</a>: the three non-Muslim minorities recognized in the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> (<a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Turkey" title="Armenians in Turkey">Armenians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greeks_in_Turkey" title="Greeks in Turkey">Greeks</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jews_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Jews in Turkey">Jews</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>d<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>) and the <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians_in_Turkey" title="Bulgarians in Turkey">Bulgarians</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>e<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Toktaş2009&#95;399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toktaş2009-399"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>394<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yağmur2001&#95;400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yağmur2001-400"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>395<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Zetler2014&#95;401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zetler2014-401"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>396<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2013, the Ankara 13th Circuit Administrative Court ruled that the minority provisions of the Lausanne Treaty should also apply to <a href="/wiki/Assyrians_in_Turkey" title="Assyrians in Turkey">Assyrians in Turkey</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Syriac_language" title="Syriac language">Syriac language</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>397<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Akbulut2023&#95;403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Akbulut2023-403"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Erdem2021&#95;404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Erdem2021-404"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>399<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other unrecognized ethnic groups include <a href="/wiki/Albanians_in_Turkey" title="Albanians in Turkey">Albanians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks_in_Turkey" title="Bosniaks in Turkey">Bosniaks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Circassians_in_Turkey" title="Circassians in Turkey">Circassians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgians_in_Turkey" title="Georgians in Turkey">Georgians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laz_people" title="Laz people">Laz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pomaks" title="Pomaks">Pomaks</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Roma</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Roopnarine2015&#95;405-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roopnarine2015-405"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>400<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>401<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>402<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> is <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>, which is the most widely spoken <a href="/wiki/Turkic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkic language">Turkic language</a> in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-katzner&#95;408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-katzner-408"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>403<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-minorityrights.org&#95;409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-minorityrights.org-409"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>404<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is spoken by 85%<sup id="cite&#95;ref-KONDA&#95;2006&#95;19&#95;410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KONDA_2006_19-410"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>405<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-milliyet-languages&#95;411-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milliyet-languages-411"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>406<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> to 90%<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kornfilt&#95;2018&#95;537&#95;412-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kornfilt_2018_537-412"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>407<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> of the population as a <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">first language</a>. Kurdish speakers are the largest linguistic minority.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kornfilt&#95;2018&#95;537&#95;412-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kornfilt_2018_537-412"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>407<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A survey estimated 13% of the population speak Kurdish or Zaza as a first language.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-KONDA&#95;2006&#95;19&#95;410-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KONDA_2006_19-410"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>405<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other minority languages include Arabic, <a href="/wiki/Caucasian_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Caucasian languages">Caucasian languages</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gagauz_language" title="Gagauz language">Gagauz</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kornfilt&#95;2018&#95;537&#95;412-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kornfilt_2018_537-412"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>407<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Linguistic_rights" title="Linguistic rights">linguistic rights</a> of the officially recognized minorities are <i>de jure</i> recognized and protected for <a href="/wiki/Armenian_language" title="Armenian language">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">Bulgarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hebrew" class="mw-redirect" title="Hebrew">Hebrew</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>f<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bayır2013&#95;394-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bayır2013-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Toktaş2009&#95;399-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toktaş2009-399"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>394<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yağmur2001&#95;400-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yağmur2001-400"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>395<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Zetler2014&#95;401-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zetler2014-401"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>396<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Syriac_language" title="Syriac language">Syriac</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Akbulut2023&#95;403-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Akbulut2023-403"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Erdem2021&#95;404-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Erdem2021-404"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>399<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are multiple <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_languages_in_Asia#Turkey" title="List of endangered languages in Asia">endangered languages in Turkey</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Immigration">Immigration</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Turkey" title="Immigration to Turkey">Immigration to Turkey</a></div>
<p>Excluding Syrians under temporary protection, there were 1,570,543 foreign citizens in Turkey in 2023.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Population&#95;of&#95;Turkey&#95;7-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Population_of_Turkey-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Millions of Kurds fled across the mountains to Turkey and the Kurdish areas of Iran during the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> in 1991. <a href="/wiki/Turkey%27s_migrant_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkey&#39;s migrant crisis">Turkey's migrant crisis</a> in the 2010s and early 2020s resulted in the influx of millions of refugees and immigrants.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-esa.un.org&#95;414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-esa.un.org-414"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>408<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey hosts the largest number of refugees in the world as of April 2020.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-unhcr-syrian-refugees&#95;415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unhcr-syrian-refugees-415"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>409<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Disaster_and_Emergency_Management_Presidency" title="Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency">Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency</a> manages the refugee crisis in Turkey. Before the start of the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_civil_war" title="Syrian civil war">Syrian civil war</a> in 2011, the estimated number of <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Turkey" title="Arabs in Turkey">Arabs in Turkey</a> varied from 1 million to more than 2 million.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>410<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2020, there were 3.6 million <a href="/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_civil_war_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Refugees of the Syrian civil war in Turkey">Syrian refugees</a> in Turkey;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>411<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> these included other <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Syria" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnic groups of Syria">ethnic groups of Syria</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Kurds" class="mw-redirect" title="Syrian Kurds">Syrian Kurds</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>412<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Turkmen" title="Syrian Turkmen">Syrian Turkmens</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>413<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of August 2023, the number of these refugees was estimated to be 3.3 million. The number of Syrians had decreased by about 200,000 people since the beginning of the year.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>414<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The government has granted citizenship to 238 thousand Syrians by November 2023.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>415<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of May 2023, approximately 96,000 Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Refugees_of_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Refugees of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">refugees of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a> have sought refuge in Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>416<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2022, nearly 100,000 Russian citizens migrated to Turkey, becoming the first in the list of foreigners who moved to Turkey, meaning an increase of more than 218% from 2021.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>417<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Religion">Religion</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Turkey" title="Religion in Turkey">Religion in Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:146px;max-width:146px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:105px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Camlica_Mosque_Bosporus_Istanbul.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Camlica_Mosque_Bosporus_Istanbul.jpg/250px-Camlica_Mosque_Bosporus_Istanbul.jpg" decoding="async" width="144" height="105" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Camlica_Mosque_Bosporus_Istanbul.jpg/330px-Camlica_Mosque_Bosporus_Istanbul.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2089" data-file-height="1529" /></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:142px;max-width:142px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:105px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Deyrulzaferan_P1030925_20080501122627.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Deyrulzaferan_P1030925_20080501122627.JPG/250px-Deyrulzaferan_P1030925_20080501122627.JPG" decoding="async" width="140" height="105" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Deyrulzaferan_P1030925_20080501122627.JPG/330px-Deyrulzaferan_P1030925_20080501122627.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2304" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Left: <a href="/wiki/%C3%87aml%C4%B1ca_Mosque" title="Çamlıca Mosque">Çamlıca Mosque</a> in Istanbul was designed by two female architects.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>418<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Right: <a href="/wiki/Mor_Hananyo_Monastery" title="Mor Hananyo Monastery">Mor Hananyo Monastery</a> near <a href="/wiki/Mardin" title="Mardin">Mardin</a>. From 1293 to 1932, it was the headquarters of <a href="/wiki/Syriac_Orthodox_Church" title="Syriac Orthodox Church">Syriac Orthodox Church</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>419<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a> with no official <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a>; the constitution provides for <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_conscience" title="Freedom of conscience">conscience</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>421<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>422<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" class="mw-redirect" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a>, Muslims constitute 99.8% of the population, most of them being <a href="/wiki/Sunni" class="mw-redirect" title="Sunni">Sunni</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;13-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Based on a survey, <a href="/wiki/KONDA_Research_and_Consultancy" title="KONDA Research and Consultancy">KONDA</a>'s estimate for Muslims was 99.4% in 2006.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-KONDA&#95;2006&#95;429-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KONDA_2006-429"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>423<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Minority_Rights_Group_International" title="Minority Rights Group International">Minority Rights Group International</a>, estimates of share of <a href="/wiki/Alevi" class="mw-redirect" title="Alevi">Alevi</a> are between 10% and 40% of the population.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-refworld.org1&#95;430-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-refworld.org1-430"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>424<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> KONDA's estimate was 5% in 2006.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-KONDA&#95;2006&#95;429-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KONDA_2006-429"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>423<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 4% of adult citizens identified as Alevi in a survey in 2021, while 88% identified as Sunni.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Konda&#95;100&#95;386-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Konda_100-386"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The percentage of non-Muslims in modern-day Turkey was 19.1% in 1914, but fell to 2.5% in 1927.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>425<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Currently, non-Muslims constitute 0.2% of the population according to the World Factbook.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;13-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2006, KONDA's estimate was that 0.18% of the population adhered to non-Islamic religions.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-KONDA&#95;2006&#95;429-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KONDA_2006-429"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>423<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some of the non-Muslim communities are Armenians, <a href="/wiki/Assyrians_in_Turkey" title="Assyrians in Turkey">Assyrians</a>, Bulgarian Orthodox, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Turkey" title="Catholic Church in Turkey">Catholics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy_in_Turkey" title="Eastern Orthodoxy in Turkey">Greeks</a>, Jews, and <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Turkey" title="Protestantism in Turkey">Protestants</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>426<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Sources estimate that the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Turkey" title="Christianity in Turkey">Christian population in Turkey</a> ranges between 180,000 and 320,000.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>427<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>428<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey has <a href="/wiki/Jewish_population_by_country" title="Jewish population by country">the largest Jewish community</a> among the Muslim-majority countries.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>429<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Currently, there are 439 churches and synagogues in Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>430<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2006, KONDA estimated that 0.47% of the population had no religion.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-KONDA&#95;2006&#95;429-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KONDA_2006-429"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>423<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to KONDA, the share of adult citizens who identified as nonbelievers increased from 2% in 2011 to 6% in 2021.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Konda&#95;100&#95;386-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Konda_100-386"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A 2020 Gezici Araştırma poll found that 28.5% of the <a href="/wiki/Generation_Z" title="Generation Z">Generation Z</a> <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Turkey" title="Irreligion in Turkey">identified as irreligious</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>431<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>432<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Education">Education</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Turkey" title="Education in Turkey">Education in Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Turkey_primary-secondary-tertiary-enrollment-completion-rates.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Turkey_primary-secondary-tertiary-enrollment-completion-rates.png/250px-Turkey_primary-secondary-tertiary-enrollment-completion-rates.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="176" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Turkey_primary-secondary-tertiary-enrollment-completion-rates.png/500px-Turkey_primary-secondary-tertiary-enrollment-completion-rates.png 1.5x" data-file-width="3400" data-file-height="2400" /></a><figcaption>Enrollment rates for <a href="/wiki/Primary_education" title="Primary education">primary</a>, <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education" title="Secondary education">secondary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary education</a> in Turkey between 1971 and 2022. Completion rates for primary and lower secondary education.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>433<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>In the past 20 years, Turkey has improved quality of education and has made significant progress in increasing education access.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-OECD&#95;Taking&#95;stock&#95;p3&#95;440-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_Taking_stock_p3-440"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>434<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From 2011 to 2021, improvements in education access include significant rise in the rates of <a href="/wiki/Upper_secondary" class="mw-redirect" title="Upper secondary">upper secondary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary education</a> completion, and quadrupling of pre-school institutions.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-OECD&#95;Taking&#95;stock&#95;p35&#95;441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_Taking_stock_p35-441"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>435<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/PISA" class="mw-redirect" title="PISA">PISA</a> results suggest improvements in education quality.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-OECD&#95;Taking&#95;stock&#95;p35&#95;441-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_Taking_stock_p35-441"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>435<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There is still a gap with OECD countries. Significant challenges include differences in student outcomes from different schools, differences between rural and urban areas, pre-primary education access, and arrival of students who are Syrian refugees.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-OECD&#95;Taking&#95;stock&#95;p35&#95;441-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_Taking_stock_p35-441"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>435<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Education_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of National Education (Turkey)">Ministry of National Education</a> is responsible for pre-tertiary education.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-wesed&#95;442-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wesed-442"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>436<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Compulsory education is free at public schools and lasts 12 years, divided into three parts.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>437<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-OECD&#95;Taking&#95;stock&#95;p3&#95;440-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_Taking_stock_p3-440"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>434<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are 208 <a href="/wiki/Universities_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Universities in Turkey">universities in Turkey</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-euraxess&#95;Türkiye&#95;370-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euraxess_Türkiye-370"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Students are placed to universities based on their <a href="/wiki/Student_Selection_and_Placement_System" title="Student Selection and Placement System">YKS</a> results and their preferences, by the <a href="/wiki/Measuring,_Selection_and_Placement_Center" title="Measuring, Selection and Placement Center">Measuring, Selection and Placement Center</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>438<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> All state and private universities are under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Higher_Education_(Turkey)" title="Council of Higher Education (Turkey)">Higher Education Board</a>. Since 2016, the president of Turkey directly appoints all rectors of all state and private universities.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>439<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>According to the 2024 <a href="/wiki/Times_Higher_Education_World_University_Rankings" title="Times Higher Education World University Rankings">Times Higher Education ranking</a>, the top universities were <a href="/wiki/Ko%C3%A7_University" title="Koç University">Koç University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middle_East_Technical_University" title="Middle East Technical University">Middle East Technical University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sabanc%C4%B1_University" title="Sabancı University">Sabancı University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">Istanbul Technical University</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>440<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">Academic Ranking of World Universities</a>, the top ones were <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">Istanbul University</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Health_Sciences_(Turkey)" title="University of Health Sciences (Turkey)">University of Health Sciences (Turkey)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hacettepe_University" title="Hacettepe University">Hacettepe University</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>441<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> For foreign students, Turkey has become a regional hub,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>442<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with a large number of international students<sup id="cite&#95;ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>443<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_Scholarships" title="Türkiye Scholarships">international scholarships</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>444<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>445<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>446<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Health">Health</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Turkey" title="Health in Turkey">Health in Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Turkey" title="Health care in Turkey">Health care in Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Ba%C5%9Fak%C5%9FehirCityHospital_(1).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ba%C5%9Fak%C5%9FehirCityHospital_%281%29.jpg/250px-Ba%C5%9Fak%C5%9FehirCityHospital_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ba%C5%9Fak%C5%9FehirCityHospital_%281%29.jpg/500px-Ba%C5%9Fak%C5%9FehirCityHospital_%281%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4691" data-file-height="3107" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Ba%C5%9Fak%C5%9Fehir_%C3%87am_and_Sakura_City_Hospital" title="Başakşehir Çam and Sakura City Hospital">Başakşehir Çam and Sakura City Hospital</a> in Istanbul. It contains 2,068 <a href="/wiki/Seismic_base_isolation" title="Seismic base isolation">seismic base isolation</a> units to <a href="/wiki/Earthquake-resistant_structures" title="Earthquake-resistant structures">withstand earthquakes</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>447<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of Health (Turkey)">Ministry of Health</a> has run a universal public healthcare system since 2003.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-njm&#95;454-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-njm-454"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Known as Universal Health Insurance (<span title="Turkish-language text"><i lang="tr">Genel Sağlık Sigortası</i></span>), it is funded by a tax surcharge on employers, currently at 5%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-njm&#95;454-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-njm-454"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Public-sector funding covers approximately 75.2% of health expenditures.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-njm&#95;454-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-njm-454"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Despite the universal health care, total expenditure on health as a share of GDP in 2018 was the lowest among OECD countries at 6.3% of GDP, compared to the OECD average of 9.3%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-njm&#95;454-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-njm-454"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are many private hospitals in the country.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Oguz&#95;2020&#95;455-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oguz_2020-455"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>449<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The government planned several hospital complexes, known as city hospitals, to be constructed since 2013.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Oguz&#95;2020&#95;455-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oguz_2020-455"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>449<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey is one of the top 10 destinations for <a href="/wiki/Medical_tourism#Turkey" title="Medical tourism">health tourism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>450<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Average life expectancy is 78.6 years (75.9 for males and 81.3 for females), compared with the EU average of 81 years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-njm&#95;454-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-njm-454"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey has high rates of <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a>, with 29.5% of its adult population having a <a href="/wiki/Body_mass_index" title="Body mass index">body mass index</a> (BMI) value of 30 or above.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-WHO&#95;Mean&#95;Body&#95;Mass&#95;Index&#95;BMI&#95;457-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHO_Mean_Body_Mass_Index_BMI-457"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>451<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution_in_Turkey" title="Air pollution in Turkey">Air pollution is a major cause</a> of early death.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>452<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Culture">Culture</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Turkey" title="Culture of Turkey">Culture of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Arts_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Arts in Turkey">Arts in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_folklore" title="Turkish folklore">Turkish folklore</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Festivals_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Festivals in Turkey">Festivals in Turkey</a></div>
<p>In the 19th century, Turkish identity was debated in the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, with three main views: Turkism, Islamism and Westernism.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>453<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In addition to Europe or Islam, Turkish culture was also influenced by Anatolia's native cultures.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>454<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After the establishment of the republic, <a href="/wiki/Kemalism" title="Kemalism">Kemalism</a> emphasized Turkish culture, attempted to make "Islam a matter of personal conviction", and pursued modernization.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>455<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Currently, Turkey has various local cultures. Things such as music, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_folk_dance" title="Turkish folk dance">folk dance</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Kebap" class="mw-redirect" title="Kebap">kebap</a> variety may be used to identify a local area. Turkey also has a national culture, such as national sports leagues, music bands, film stars, and trends in fashion.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>456<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey is home to <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">21 UNESCO World Heritage</a> sites and <a href="/wiki/Intangible_cultural_heritage" title="Intangible cultural heritage">31 UNESCO intangible cultural heritage</a> inscriptions.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>457<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Architecture">Architecture</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Turkey" title="Architecture of Turkey">Architecture of Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architecture</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:156px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Selimiye..._-_panoramio.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Selimiye..._-_panoramio.jpg/250px-Selimiye..._-_panoramio.jpg" class="thumbcaption">Built by <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">Mimar Sinan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Selimiye_Mosque,_Edirne" title="Selimiye Mosque, Edirne">Selimiye Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Edirne" title="Edirne">Edirne</a> is an example of <a href="/wiki/Classical_Ottoman_architecture" title="Classical Ottoman architecture">classical Ottoman architecture</a>.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:155px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2020-02_img05_Crowne_Plaza_Old_City.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img
