height="156" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img05_Crowne_Plaza_Old_City.jpg/330px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img05_Crowne_Plaza_Old_City.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img05_Crowne_Plaza_Old_City.jpg/500px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img05_Crowne_Plaza_Old_City.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5047" data-file-height="3785" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Tayyare_Apartments" title="Tayyare Apartments">Tayyare Apartments</a> in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, an example of the <a href="/wiki/First_national_architectural_movement" title="First national architectural movement">first national architectural movement</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:138px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Eskisehir_Odunpazar%C4%B1_tour_in_2018_8523.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Eskisehir_Odunpazar%C4%B1_tour_in_2018_8523.jpg/250px-Eskisehir_Odunpazar%C4%B1_tour_in_2018_8523.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="138" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Eskisehir_Odunpazar%C4%B1_tour_in_2018_8523.jpg/330px-Eskisehir_Odunpazar%C4%B1_tour_in_2018_8523.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Eskisehir_Odunpazar%C4%B1_tour_in_2018_8523.jpg/500px-Eskisehir_Odunpazar%C4%B1_tour_in_2018_8523.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3280" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">With its traditional Turkish houses, <a href="/wiki/Odunpazar%C4%B1" title="Odunpazarı">Odunpazarı</a> district in <a href="/wiki/Eski%C5%9Fehir" title="Eskişehir">Eskişehir</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Tentative_list_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Tentative list of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">tentative UNESCO World Heritage site</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>458<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Turkey is home to numerous <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> settlements, such as <a href="/wiki/%C3%87atalh%C3%B6y%C3%BCk" title="Çatalhöyük">Çatalhöyük</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>459<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-3&#95;53-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-3-53"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a>, important architectural remnants include <a href="/wiki/Alaca_H%C3%B6y%C3%BCk" title="Alaca Höyük">Alaca Höyük</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Troy#Troy_II" title="Troy">2nd layer of Troy</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Howard&#95;2016-3&#95;53-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Howard_2016-3-53"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are various examples of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_architecture" title="Ancient Greek architecture">Ancient Greek</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Roman_architecture" title="Ancient Roman architecture">Ancient Roman</a> architectures, especially in the Aegean region.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>460<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a> dates back to the 4th century AD. Its best example is <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a>. Byzantine architectural style continued to develop after the <a href="/wiki/Conquest_of_Istanbul" class="mw-redirect" title="Conquest of Istanbul">conquest of Istanbul</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Revival_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine Revival architecture">Byzantine Revival architecture</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>461<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Sultanate_of_Rum" class="mw-redirect" title="Seljuk Sultanate of Rum">Seljuk Sultanate of Rum</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">Turkish principalities</a> period, a distinct architecture emerged, which incorporated Byzantine and <a href="/wiki/Armenian_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Armenian architecture">Armenian</a> architectures with architectural styles found in <a href="/wiki/West_Asia" title="West Asia">West Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>462<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_Seljuk_architecture" title="Anatolian Seljuk architecture">Seljuk architecture</a> often used stones and bricks, and produced numerous <a href="/wiki/Caravanserai" title="Caravanserai">caravanserais</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madrasa" title="Madrasa">madrasas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mausoleum" title="Mausoleum">mausoleums</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>463<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architecture</a> emerged in northwest Anatolia and Thrace. <a href="/wiki/Early_Ottoman_architecture" title="Early Ottoman architecture">Early Ottoman architecture</a> mixed "traditional Anatolian Islamic architecture with local building materials and techniques".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>464<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following the conquest of Istanbul, <a href="/wiki/Classical_Ottoman_architecture" title="Classical Ottoman architecture">classical Ottoman architecture</a> emerged in the 16th and 17th centuries.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto1&#95;471-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-471"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>465<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The most important architect of the classical period is <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">Mimar Sinan</a>, whose major works include the <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Eehzade_Mosque" title="Şehzade Mosque">Şehzade Mosque</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque" title="Süleymaniye Mosque">Süleymaniye Mosque</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Selimiye_Mosque,_Edirne" title="Selimiye Mosque, Edirne">Selimiye Mosque</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto1&#95;471-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-471"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>465<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Beginning in the 18th century, Ottoman architecture was influenced by European elements, resulting in development of <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Baroque_architecture" title="Ottoman Baroque architecture">Ottoman baroque style</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto&#95;472-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-472"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>466<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> European influence continued in the 19th century; examples include works of <a href="/wiki/Balyan_family" title="Balyan family">Balyan family</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Baroque_Revival_architecture" title="Baroque Revival architecture">neo-Baroque</a> style <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="Dolmabahçe Palace">Dolmabahçe Palace</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>467<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The last period of Ottoman architecture consists of the <a href="/wiki/First_National_Architectural_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="First National Architectural Movement">First National Architectural Movement</a>, including works of <a href="/wiki/Vedat_Tek" title="Vedat Tek">Vedat Tek</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Kemaleddin" title="Mimar Kemaleddin">Mimar Kemaleddin</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto&#95;472-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-472"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>466<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1918, Turkish architecture can be divided into three parts. From 1918 to 1950, the first one includes the First National Architectural Movement period, which transitioned into <a href="/wiki/Modernist_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Modernist architecture">modernist architecture</a>. Modernist and monumental buildings were preferred for public buildings, whereas "Turkish house" type <a href="/wiki/Vernacular_architecture" title="Vernacular architecture">vernacular architecture</a> influenced private houses. From 1950 to 1980, the second part includes urbanization, modernization, and internationalization. For residential housing, "reinforced concrete, slab-block, medium-rise apartments" became prevalent. Since 1980, the third part is defined by consumer habits and international trends, such as shopping malls and office towers. Luxury residences with "Turkish house style" have been in demand.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>468<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 21st century, <a href="/wiki/Urban_renewal" title="Urban renewal">urban renewal</a> projects have become a trend.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>469<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Resilience against natural disasters such as earthquakes is one of the main goals for urban renewal projects.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>470<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
Around one-third of Turkey's building stock, corresponding to 6.7 million units, were assessed risky and needing urban renewal.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>471<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Literature,_theatre,_and_visual_arts"><span id="Literature.2C_theatre.2C_and_visual_arts"></span>Literature, theatre, and visual arts</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">Turkish literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_Turkey" title="Theatre of Turkey">Theatre of Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_art" title="Turkish art">Turkish art</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Orhan_Pamuk.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Orhan_Pamuk.jpg/250px-Orhan_Pamuk.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="132" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Orhan_Pamuk.jpg/500px-Orhan_Pamuk.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="521" data-file-height="276" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel</a>-laureate Turkish novelist <a href="/wiki/Orhan_Pamuk" title="Orhan Pamuk">Orhan Pamuk</a> and his <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Angora_cat" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Angora cat">Turkish Angora cat</a> at his personal writing space</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul,_Turkey.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/250px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="181" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/500px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3951" data-file-height="2861" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House" title="Süreyya Opera House">Süreyya Opera House</a> is on the Asian side of <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_Cultural_Center" title="Atatürk Cultural Center">Atatürk Cultural Center</a> is the main <a href="/wiki/Opera_house" title="Opera house">opera house</a> on the European side. <a href="/wiki/Zorlu_PSM" title="Zorlu PSM">Zorlu PSM</a> is the city's largest <a href="/wiki/Performing_arts" title="Performing arts">performing arts theater</a> and <a href="/wiki/Concert_hall" class="mw-redirect" title="Concert hall">concert hall</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">Turkish literature</a> goes back more than a thousand years. The Seljuk and Ottoman periods include numerous works of literature and poetry. Turkic tales and poetry from Central Asia were also kept alive. <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Dede_Korkut" title="Book of Dede Korkut">Tales of Dede Korkut</a> is an example of the <a href="/wiki/Oral_storytelling" title="Oral storytelling">oral narrative</a> tradition. <a href="/wiki/D%C4%ABw%C4%81n_Lugh%C4%81t_al-Turk" title="Dīwān Lughāt al-Turk">Dīwān Lughāt al-Turk</a>, from the 11th century, contains Turkish linguistic information and poetry. <a href="/wiki/Yunus_Emre" title="Yunus Emre">Yunus Emre</a>, influenced by <a href="/wiki/Rumi" title="Rumi">Rumi</a>, was one of the most important writers of Anatolian Turkish poetry. Ottoman <a href="/wiki/Diwan_(poetry)" title="Diwan (poetry)">Divan</a> poetry used "refined diction" and complex vocabulary. It included <a href="/wiki/Sufi_mysticism" class="mw-redirect" title="Sufi mysticism">Sufi mysticism</a>, romanticism, and formal elements.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Halman&#95;2012&#95;Literature&#95;478-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Halman_2012_Literature-478"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>472<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Beginning in the 19th century, Ottoman literature was influenced by the West. New genres, such as novels and journalistic style, were introduced. <span title="Turkish-language text"><i lang="tr"><a href="/wiki/A%C5%9Fk-%C4%B1_Memnu_(novel)" title="Aşk-ı Memnu (novel)">Aşk-ı Memnu</a></i></span>, written by <a href="/wiki/Halid_Ziya_U%C5%9Fakl%C4%B1gil" title="Halid Ziya Uşaklıgil">Halid Ziya Uşaklıgil</a>, was the "first truly refined Turkish novel". <a href="/wiki/Fatma_Aliye_Topuz" title="Fatma Aliye Topuz">Fatma Aliye Topuz</a>, the first female Turkish novelist, wrote fiction. After the proclamation of the republic in 1923, <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_reforms" title="Atatürk&#39;s reforms">Atatürk instituted reforms</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language_reform" title="Turkish language reform">language reform</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_alphabet_reform" title="Turkish alphabet reform">alphabet reform</a>. Since then, Turkish literature reflected the socioeconomic conditions in Turkey with increasing variety. "Village Novel" genre appeared in the mid-1950s, which talked about difficulties faced from poverty.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Halman&#95;2012&#95;Literature&#95;478-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Halman_2012_Literature-478"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>472<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> An example is <a href="/wiki/Memed,_My_Hawk" title="Memed, My Hawk">Memed, My Hawk</a> by <a href="/wiki/Ya%C5%9Far_Kemal" title="Yaşar Kemal">Yaşar Kemal</a>, which was <a href="/wiki/1973_Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="1973 Nobel Prize in Literature">Turkey's first Nobel Prize in Literature nominee in 1973</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Halman&#95;2012&#95;Literature&#95;478-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Halman_2012_Literature-478"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>472<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>473<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Orhan_Pamuk" title="Orhan Pamuk">Orhan Pamuk</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2006_Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="2006 Nobel Prize in Literature">2006 Nobel Prize in Literature</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Halman&#95;2012&#95;Literature&#95;478-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Halman_2012_Literature-478"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>472<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey has four "major theatrical traditions": "folk theatre, popular theatre, court theater, and Western theater." Turkish folk theatre goes back thousands of years and has survived among rural communities. Popular theatre includes plays by live actors, puppet and <a href="/wiki/Shadow_play" title="Shadow play">shadow</a> plays, and <a href="/wiki/Meddah" title="Meddah">storytelling performances</a>. An example for shadow play is <span title="Turkish-language text"><i lang="tr"><a href="/wiki/Karag%C3%B6z_and_Hacivat" title="Karagöz and Hacivat">Karagöz and Hacivat</a></i></span>. Court theatre was the refined version of popular theatre. Beginning in the 19th century, Western theatre tradition started appearing in Turkey. Following the establishment of Turkish Republic, a state conservatory and the State Theatre Company were formed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>474<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey's visual arts scene can be categorized into two, as "decorative" and "fine" arts. Fine arts, or <span title="Turkish-language text"><i lang="tr">güzel sanatlar</i></span>, includes sculpture and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Modern_Turkish_painting" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Modern Turkish painting">painting</a>. Turkish artists in these areas have gained global recognition. Photography, fashion design, graphic arts, and graphic design are some of the other areas Turkish artists are known for in the world. The inaugural contemporary Turkish art sale by <a href="/wiki/Sotheby%27s" title="Sotheby&#39;s">Sotheby's London</a> was in 2009. <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Modern" title="Istanbul Modern">Istanbul Modern</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Biennial" title="Istanbul Biennial">Istanbul Biennial</a> are examples of art galleries or exhibitions of contemporary Turkish art. Turkey has also seen a resurgence of traditional arts. This includes Ottoman-era traditional arts, such as <a href="/wiki/Iznik_pottery" title="Iznik pottery">ceramics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_rug" title="Anatolian rug">carpets</a>. Textile and carpet design, glass and ceramics, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calligraphy" title="Islamic calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paper_marbling" title="Paper marbling">paper marbling (ebru)</a> are some of the art forms for which modern-day Turkish artists are recognized as leaders in the Islamic world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Denny&#95;2012&#95;Fine&#95;Arts&#95;481-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Denny_2012_Fine_Arts-481"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>475<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Music_and_dance">Music and dance</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Turkey" title="Music of Turkey">Music of Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_folk_dance" title="Turkish folk dance">Turkish folk dance</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Baris_Manco.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Baris_Manco.jpg/250px-Baris_Manco.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Baris_Manco.jpg/500px-Baris_Manco.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1272" data-file-height="745" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o" title="Barış Manço">Barış Manço</a> was a Turkish rock musician and one of the founders of the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_rock" title="Anatolian rock">Anatolian rock</a> genre.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Although classifying genres of Turkish music can be problematic, three broad categories can be considered. These are "<a href="/wiki/Turkish_folk_music" title="Turkish folk music">Turkish folk music</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Turkish_art_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish art music">Turkish art music</a>", and multiple popular music styles. These Popular music styles include <a href="/wiki/Arabesque_(Turkish_music)" title="Arabesque (Turkish music)">arabesque</a>, pop, and <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_rock" title="Anatolian rock">Anatolian rock</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>476<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The resurging popularity of pop music gave rise to several international Turkish pop stars such as <a href="/wiki/Ajda_Pekkan" title="Ajda Pekkan">Ajda Pekkan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sezen_Aksu" title="Sezen Aksu">Sezen Aksu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Erol_Evgin" title="Erol Evgin">Erol Evgin</a>, <a href="/wiki/MF%C3%96" title="MFÖ">MFÖ</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tarkan_(singer)" title="Tarkan (singer)">Tarkan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Sandal" title="Mustafa Sandal">Mustafa Sandal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sertab_Erener" title="Sertab Erener">Sertab Erener</a>, <a href="/wiki/Teoman_(singer)" title="Teoman (singer)">Teoman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kenan_Do%C4%9Fulu" title="Kenan Doğulu">Kenan Doğulu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Levent_Y%C3%BCksel" title="Levent Yüksel">Levent Yüksel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hande_Yener" title="Hande Yener">Hande Yener</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2024)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Internationally acclaimed Turkish <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Blues" title="Blues">blues</a> musicians and composers include <a href="/wiki/Ahmet_Ertegun" title="Ahmet Ertegun">Ahmet Ertegun</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>477<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Media_and_cinema">Media and cinema</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Media_in_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Media in Turkey">Media in Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Turkey" title="Cinema of Turkey">Cinema of Turkey</a></div>
<p>Hundreds of television channels, thousands of local and national radio stations, several dozen newspapers, a productive and profitable <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Turkey" title="Cinema of Turkey">national cinema</a> and a rapid growth of <a href="/wiki/Broadband" title="Broadband">broadband</a> Internet use constitute a vibrant media industry in Turkey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-tesevmedya&#95;484-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tesevmedya-484"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>478<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-485" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-485"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>479<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The majority of the TV audiences are shared among public broadcaster <a href="/wiki/TRT" class="mw-redirect" title="TRT">TRT</a> and the network-style channels such as <a href="/wiki/Kanal_D" title="Kanal D">Kanal D</a>, <a href="/wiki/Show_TV" title="Show TV">Show TV</a>, <a href="/wiki/ATV_(Turkey)" class="mw-redirect" title="ATV (Turkey)">ATV</a> and <a href="/wiki/Star_TV_(Turkey)" title="Star TV (Turkey)">Star TV</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Broadcast_media" class="mw-redirect" title="Broadcast media">broadcast media</a> have a very high penetration as <a href="/wiki/Satellite_dishes" class="mw-redirect" title="Satellite dishes">satellite dishes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cable_television" title="Cable television">cable</a> systems are widely available.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cp&#95;486-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cp-486"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>480<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/RT%C3%9CK" class="mw-redirect" title="RTÜK">Radio and Television Supreme Council (RTÜK)</a> is the government body overseeing the broadcast media.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>481<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By circulation, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Turkey" title="List of newspapers in Turkey">most popular newspapers</a> are <i><a href="/wiki/Posta_(newspaper)" title="Posta (newspaper)">Posta</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/H%C3%BCrriyet" title="Hürriyet">Hürriyet</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/S%C3%B6zc%C3%BC" title="Sözcü">Sözcü</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sabah_(newspaper)" title="Sabah (newspaper)">Sabah</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Habert%C3%BCrk" title="Habertürk">Habertürk</a></i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>482<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:322px;max-width:322px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:85px;max-width:85px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:132px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Nuri_Bilge_Ceylan,_Cines_del_Sur.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Nuri_Bilge_Ceylan%2C_Cines_del_Sur.jpg/120px-Nuri_Bilge_Ceylan%2C_Cines_del_Sur.jpg" decoding="async" width="83" height="132" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Nuri_Bilge_Ceylan%2C_Cines_del_Sur.jpg/250px-Nuri_Bilge_Ceylan%2C_Cines_del_Sur.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1079" data-file-height="1719" /></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:130px;max-width:130px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:132px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Beren_Saat_17.4.15_cropped.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Beren_Saat_17.4.15_cropped.jpg/250px-Beren_Saat_17.4.15_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="128" height="132" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Beren_Saat_17.4.15_cropped.jpg/330px-Beren_Saat_17.4.15_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="559" data-file-height="576" /></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:101px;max-width:101px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:132px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Turkan_Soray_1310395.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkan_Soray_1310395.jpg/120px-Turkan_Soray_1310395.jpg" decoding="async" width="99" height="132" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkan_Soray_1310395.jpg/250px-Turkan_Soray_1310395.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1150" data-file-height="1534" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Nuri_Bilge_Ceylan" title="Nuri Bilge Ceylan">Nuri Bilge Ceylan</a> (left), <a href="/wiki/Beren_Saat" title="Beren Saat">Beren Saat</a> (middle), and <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkan_%C5%9Eoray" title="Türkan Şoray">Türkan Şoray</a> (right)</div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Filiz_Ak%C4%B1n" title="Filiz Akın">Filiz Akın</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fatma_Girik" title="Fatma Girik">Fatma Girik</a>, <a href="/wiki/H%C3%BClya_Ko%C3%A7yi%C4%9Fit" title="Hülya Koçyiğit">Hülya Koçyiğit</a>, and <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkan_%C5%9Eoray" title="Türkan Şoray">Türkan Şoray</a> represent their period of Turkish cinema.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Magnan&#95;489-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Magnan-489"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>483<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkish directors like <a href="/wiki/Metin_Erksan" title="Metin Erksan">Metin Erksan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuri_Bilge_Ceylan" title="Nuri Bilge Ceylan">Nuri Bilge Ceylan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Y%C4%B1lmaz_G%C3%BCney" title="Yılmaz Güney">Yılmaz Güney</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zeki_Demirkubuz" title="Zeki Demirkubuz">Zeki Demirkubuz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ferzan_%C3%96zpetek" title="Ferzan Özpetek">Ferzan Özpetek</a> won numerous international awards such as the <span title="French-language text"><span lang="fr" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d&#39;Or">Palme d'Or</a></span></span> and <a href="/wiki/Golden_Bear" title="Golden Bear">Golden Bear</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-berlinale&#95;1964&#95;490-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-berlinale_1964-490"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>484<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Turkish_television_drama" title="Turkish television drama">Turkish television dramas</a> are increasingly becoming popular beyond Turkey's borders and are among the country's most vital exports, both in terms of profit and public relations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-491" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-491"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>485<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After sweeping the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>'s television market over the past decade, Turkish shows have aired in more than a dozen <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">Central American</a> countries in 2016.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>486<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey is today the world's second largest exporter of television series.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>487<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-494" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-494"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>488<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-495" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-495"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>489<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cuisine">Cuisine</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish cuisine</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">Ottoman cuisine</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/250px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="171" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/500px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2510" data-file-height="1719" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Turkish_coffee" title="Turkish coffee">Turkish coffee</a> with <a href="/wiki/Turkish_delight" title="Turkish delight">Turkish delight</a>. Turkish coffee is a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">UNESCO-listed intangible cultural heritage</a> of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turks</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-496" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-496"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>490<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-497" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-497"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>491<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Turkey has a diverse and rich cuisine, varying geographically.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yayla&#95;Aktaş&#95;2021&#95;498-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yayla_Aktaş_2021-498"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>492<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkish cuisine has been influenced by Anatolian, <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_cuisine" title="Mediterranean cuisine">Mediterranean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iranian_cuisine" title="Iranian cuisine">Iranian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Asian_cuisine" title="Central Asian cuisine">Central Asian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Asian_cuisine#East_Asian_cuisine" title="Asian cuisine">East Asian</a> cuisines.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Oxford&#95;Companion&#95;to&#95;Food&#95;loc&#95;Turkey&#95;499-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Companion_to_Food_loc_Turkey-499"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>493<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkish and Ottoman cuisine have also influenced others. <a href="/wiki/D%C4%ABw%C4%81n_Lugh%C4%81t_al-Turk" title="Dīwān Lughāt al-Turk">Dīwān Lughāt al-Turk</a>, from the 11th century, documents "the ancient lineage of much of present-day Turkish cuisine".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Oxford&#95;Companion&#95;to&#95;Food&#95;loc&#95;Turkey&#95;499-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Companion_to_Food_loc_Turkey-499"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>493<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BCve%C3%A7" title="Güveç">Güveç</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgur" title="Bulgur">Bulgur</a>, and <a href="/wiki/B%C3%B6rek" title="Börek">Börek</a> are some of the earliest recorded examples of Turkish cuisine. Even though <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">kebab</a> as a word comes from <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>, Turkic people had been familiar with using skewers to cook meat. Turkish cuisine can be distinguished by its various kinds of kebabs. Similarly, <a href="/wiki/Pilaf" title="Pilaf">pilaf</a> dishes were influenced by Turkish cuisine. Further information about cuisine during the Seljuk and Ottoman periods comes from the works of <a href="/wiki/Rumi" title="Rumi">Rumi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Evliya_%C3%87elebi" title="Evliya Çelebi">Evliya Çelebi</a>. The latter describes "food-related guilds of Istanbul".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Oxford&#95;Companion&#95;to&#95;Food&#95;loc&#95;Turkey&#95;499-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Companion_to_Food_loc_Turkey-499"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>493<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Food staples in Turkey include <a href="/wiki/Bread" title="Bread">bread</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a>. Some of bread varieties are <a href="/wiki/Lavash" title="Lavash">lavash</a> and <span title="Turkish-language text"><i lang="tr">pide</i></span> (a type of <a href="/wiki/Pita" title="Pita">pita</a> bread). <a href="/wiki/Ayran" title="Ayran">Ayran</a> is a drink made of yoghurt. In western parts of Turkey, <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a> is used. Grains include wheat, maize, barley, oats, and millet. Beans, chickpeas, nuts, aubergines, and lamb are some of the commonly used ingredients.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Oxford&#95;Companion&#95;to&#95;Food&#95;loc&#95;Turkey&#95;499-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Companion_to_Food_loc_Turkey-499"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>493<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Doner_kebab" title="Doner kebab">Doner kebab</a>, originally from Turkey, is marinated lamb slices cooked vertically.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-500" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-500"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>494<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Seafood includes <a href="/wiki/Anchovy" title="Anchovy">anchovy</a> and others. <a href="/wiki/Dolma" title="Dolma">Dolma</a> varieties and <span title="Turkish-language text"><i lang="tr"><a href="/wiki/Mant%C4%B1" class="mw-redirect" title="Mantı">mantı</a></i></span> are made by stuffing vegetables or pasta.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Oxford&#95;Companion&#95;to&#95;Food&#95;loc&#95;Turkey&#95;499-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Companion_to_Food_loc_Turkey-499"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>493<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sarma_(food)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sarma (food)">Sarma</a> is made by rolling edible leaf over the filling.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-501" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-501"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>495<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yahni" title="Yahni">Yahni</a> dishes are vegetable stews.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Oxford&#95;Companion&#95;to&#95;Food&#95;loc&#95;Turkey&#95;499-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Companion_to_Food_loc_Turkey-499"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>493<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Turkey is one of the countries with the <a href="/wiki/Meze" title="Meze">meze</a> tradition.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>496<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Honey, <a href="/wiki/Pekmez" class="mw-redirect" title="Pekmez">pekmez</a>, dried fruit, or fruit are used for sweetening.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Oxford&#95;Companion&#95;to&#95;Food&#95;loc&#95;Turkey&#95;499-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Companion_to_Food_loc_Turkey-499"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>493<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Filo" title="Filo">Filo</a> is an originally Turkish <a href="/wiki/Dough" title="Dough">dough</a> that is used to make <a href="/wiki/Baklava" title="Baklava">baklava</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-503" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-503"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>497<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Turkish_delight" title="Turkish delight">Turkish delight</a> is a "delicate but gummy jelly".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-504" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-504"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>498<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Sports">Sports</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Turkey" title="Sport in Turkey">Sport in Turkey</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Turkey" title="Football in Turkey">Football in Turkey</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:AUT_vs._TUR_2016-03-29_(001).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/AUT_vs._TUR_2016-03-29_%28001%29.jpg/250px-AUT_vs._TUR_2016-03-29_%28001%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/AUT_vs._TUR_2016-03-29_%28001%29.jpg/500px-AUT_vs._TUR_2016-03-29_%28001%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4500" data-file-height="3000" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Turkey_national_football_team" title="Turkey national football team">Turkey</a> at <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016" title="UEFA Euro 2016">UEFA Euro 2016</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The most popular sport is <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-505" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-505"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>499<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(football)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (football)">Galatasaray</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2000_UEFA_Cup_Final" class="mw-redirect" title="2000 UEFA Cup Final">UEFA Cup</a> and <a href="/wiki/2000_UEFA_Super_Cup" title="2000 UEFA Super Cup">UEFA Super Cup</a> in 2000.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-uefa.com&#95;506-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uefa.com-506"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>500<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Turkey_national_football_team" title="Turkey national football team">Turkey national football team</a> won the bronze medal at the <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a>, the <a href="/wiki/2003_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2003 FIFA Confederations Cup">2003 FIFA Confederations Cup</a> and <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008" title="UEFA Euro 2008">UEFA Euro 2008</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-tff.org1&#95;507-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tff.org1-507"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>501<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Other mainstream sports such as basketball and volleyball are also popular.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-508" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-508"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>502<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Turkey_men%27s_national_basketball_team" title="Turkey men&#39;s national basketball team">men's national basketball team</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkey_women%27s_national_basketball_team" title="Turkey women&#39;s national basketball team">women's national basketball team</a> have been successful. <a href="/wiki/Anadolu_Efes_S.K." title="Anadolu Efes S.K.">Anadolu Efes S.K.</a> is the most successful Turkish basketball club in international competitions.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>503<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-510" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-510"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>504<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Men%27s_Basketball" class="mw-redirect" title="Fenerbahçe Men&#39;s Basketball">Fenerbahçe</a> reached the final of the <a href="/wiki/EuroLeague" title="EuroLeague">EuroLeague</a> in three consecutive seasons (<a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Euroleague" title="2015–16 Euroleague">2015–2016</a>, <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_EuroLeague" title="2016–17 EuroLeague">2016–2017</a> and <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_EuroLeague" title="2017–18 EuroLeague">2017–2018</a>), becoming the European champions in 2017.
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg/250px-Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg/500px-Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="5472" data-file-height="3648" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Vak%C4%B1fBank_S.K." title="VakıfBank S.K.">VakıfBank S.K.</a> is one of the best women's volleyball team in the world, having won the <a href="/wiki/FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="FIVB Volleyball Women&#39;s Club World Championship">FIVB World Championship</a> four times and the <a href="/wiki/CEV_Women%27s_Champions_League" title="CEV Women&#39;s Champions League">CEV Champions Cup</a> six times.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The final of the <a href="/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_EuroLeague_Women" title="2013–14 EuroLeague Women">2013–14 EuroLeague Women</a> basketball championship was played between two Turkish teams, <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(women%27s_basketball)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (women&#39;s basketball)">Galatasaray</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Basketball" class="mw-redirect" title="Fenerbahçe Women&#39;s Basketball">Fenerbahçe</a>, and won by Galatasaray.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-fibaeurope.com2&#95;511-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fibaeurope.com2-511"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>505<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Fenerbahçe won the <a href="/wiki/2023_FIBA_Europe_SuperCup_Women" title="2023 FIBA Europe SuperCup Women">2023 FIBA Europe SuperCup Women</a> after two consecutive Euroleague wins in the <a href="/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_EuroLeague_Women" title="2022–23 EuroLeague Women">2022–23</a> and <a href="/wiki/2023%E2%80%9324_EuroLeague_Women" title="2023–24 EuroLeague Women">2023–24</a> seasons.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Turkey_women%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Turkey women&#39;s national volleyball team">women's national volleyball team</a> has won several medals.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-tvf.org.tr&#95;512-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tvf.org.tr-512"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>506<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Women's volleyball clubs, namely <a href="/wiki/Vak%C4%B1fBank_S.K." title="VakıfBank S.K.">VakıfBank S.K.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Volleyball" class="mw-redirect" title="Fenerbahçe Women&#39;s Volleyball">Fenerbahçe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1_Dynavit" class="mw-redirect" title="Eczacıbaşı Dynavit">Eczacıbaşı</a>, have won numerous European championship titles and medals.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-CEV-2023&#95;513-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CEV-2023-513"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>507<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The traditional national sport of Turkey has been <a href="/wiki/Ya%C4%9Fl%C4%B1_g%C3%BCre%C5%9F" class="mw-redirect" title="Yağlı güreş">yağlı güreş</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">oil</a> <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">wrestling</a></i>) since Ottoman times.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-514" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-514"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>508<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Edirne Province has hosted the annual <a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1rkp%C4%B1nar" title="Kırkpınar">Kırkpınar</a> oil wrestling tournament since 1361, making it the oldest continuously held sporting competition in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-515" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-515"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>509<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-516" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-516"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>510<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 19th and early 20th centuries, oil wrestling champions such as <a href="/wiki/Koca_Yusuf" class="mw-redirect" title="Koca Yusuf">Koca Yusuf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nurullah_Hasan" title="Nurullah Hasan">Nurullah Hasan</a> and <a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lc%C4%B1kl%C4%B1_Mahmut" title="Kızılcıklı Mahmut">Kızılcıklı Mahmut</a> acquired international fame in Europe and North America by winning world heavyweight wrestling championship titles. International wrestling styles governed by <a href="/wiki/International_Federation_of_Associated_Wrestling_Styles" class="mw-redirect" title="International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles">FILA</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_wrestling" title="Freestyle wrestling">freestyle wrestling</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_wrestling" title="Greco-Roman wrestling">Greco-Roman wrestling</a> are also popular, with many European, World and Olympic championship titles won by Turkish wrestlers both individually and as a national team.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-517" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-517"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>511<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2></div>

English <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="&#39;t&#39; in &#39;tie&#39;">t</span><span title="/ɜːr/: &#39;ur&#39; in &#39;fur&#39;">ɜːr</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="&#39;k&#39; in &#39;kind&#39;">k</span><span title="/iː/: &#39;ee&#39; <li id="cite&#95;note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Turkish: <i lang="tr">Türkiye Cumhuriyeti</i> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="tr-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Turkish" title="Help:IPA/Turkish">&#91;ˈtyɾcije<span class="wrap"> </span>dʒumˈhuːɾijeti&#93;</a></span> <span class="ext-phonos"><span data-nosnippet="" id="ooui-php-2" class="noexcerpt ext-phonos-PhonosButton ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel oo-ui-widget oo-ui-widget-enabled oo-ui-buttonElement oo-ui-buttonElement-frameless oo-ui-iconElement oo-ui-buttonWidget" data-ooui="{&quot;_&quot;:&quot;mw.Phonos.PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;href&quot;:&quot;\/\/upload.wikimedia.org\/wikipedia\/commons\/transcoded\/3\/37\/Tur-T%C3%BCrkiye_Cumhuriyeti.ogg\/Tur-T%C3%BCrkiye_Cumhuriyeti.ogg.mp3&quot;,&quot;rel&quot;:[&quot;nofollow&quot;],&quot;framed&quot;:false,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;volumeUp&quot;,&quot;data&quot;:{&quot;ipa&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;lang&quot;:&quot;en&quot;,&quot;wikibase&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;file&quot;:&quot;Tur-T\u00fcrkiye Cumhuriyeti.ogg&quot;},&quot;classes&quot;:[&quot;noexcerpt&quot;,&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel&quot;]}"><a role="button" tabindex="0" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/3/37/Tur-T%C3%BCrkiye_Cumhuriyeti.ogg/Tur-T%C3%BCrkiye_Cumhuriyeti.ogg.mp3" rel="nofollow" aria-label="Play audio" title="Play audio" class="oo-ui-buttonElement-button"><span class="oo-ui-iconElement-icon oo-ui-icon-volumeUp"></span><span class="oo-ui-labelElement-label"></span><span class="oo-ui-indicatorElement-indicator oo-ui-indicatorElement-noIndicator"></span></a></span><sup class="ext-phonos-attribution noexcerpt navigation-not-searchable"><a href="/wiki/File:Tur-T%C3%BCrkiye_Cumhuriyeti.ogg" title="File:Tur-Türkiye Cumhuriyeti.ogg">ⓘ</a></sup></span>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-65"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-65">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The origin of Indo-European languages is unknown.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_hypothesis" title="Anatolian hypothesis">They may be native to Anatolia</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> or non-native.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-395"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-395">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Even though they are not explicitly mentioned in the Treaty of Lausanne.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bayır2013&#95;394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bayır2013-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-398"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-398">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians_in_Turkey" title="Bulgarians in Turkey">Bulgarian community in Turkey</a> is now so small that this disposition is <i>de facto</i> not applied.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bayır2013&#95;394-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bayır2013-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>392<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Özlem2019&#95;397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Özlem2019-397"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>393<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-413"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-413">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Turkish government considers that, for the purpose of the Treaty of Lausanne, the language of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Jews" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish Jews">Turkish Jews</a> is <a href="/wiki/Hebrew" class="mw-redirect" title="Hebrew">Hebrew</a>, even though the mother tongue of Turkish Jews was not Hebrew but historically <a href="/wiki/Judaeo-Spanish" title="Judaeo-Spanish">Judaeo-Spanish</a> (Ladino) or other <a href="/wiki/Jewish_languages" title="Jewish languages">Jewish languages</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yağmur2001&#95;400-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yağmur2001-400"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>395<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Zetler2014&#95;401-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zetler2014-401"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>396<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite&#95;note-TC&#95;Constituton&#95;Art.&#95;3-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-TC_Constituton_Art._3_2-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation news cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200702232731/https://www.tbmm.gov.tr/develop/owa/tc_anayasasi.maddeler?p3=3">"Türkiye Cumhuriyeti Anayasası"</a> (in Turkish). <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">Grand National Assembly of Turkey</a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.tbmm.gov.tr/develop/owa/tc_anayasasi.maddeler?p3=3">the original</a> on 2 July 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 July</span> 2020</span>. <q>3. Madde: Devletin Bütünlüğü, Resmi Dili, Bayrağı, Milli Marşı ve Başkenti: Türkiye Devleti, ülkesi ve milletiyle bölünmez bir bütündür. Dili Türkçedir. Bayrağı, şekli kanununda belirtilen, beyaz ay yıldızlı al bayraktır. Milli marşı 'İstiklal Marşı' dır. Başkenti Ankara'dır.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=T%C3%BCrkiye+Cumhuriyeti+Anayasas%C4%B1&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tbmm.gov.tr%2Fdevelop%2Fowa%2Ftc&#95;anayasasi.maddeler%3Fp3%3D3&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Constitutional&#95;Court&#95;of&#95;Turkey&#95;-&#95;Constitution&#95;Art.&#95;3-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Constitutional_Court_of_Turkey_-_Constitution_Art._3_3-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation news cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200621023406/https://www.anayasa.gov.tr/tr/mevzuat/anayasa/">"Mevzuat: Anayasa"</a> (in Turkish). <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Turkey" title="Constitutional Court of Turkey">Constitutional Court of Turkey</a>. <li id="cite&#95;note-Population&#95;of&#95;Turkey-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Population_of_Turkey_7-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Population_of_Turkey_7-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Population_of_Turkey_7-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Population_of_Turkey_7-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Population_of_Turkey_7-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Population_of_Turkey_7-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Population_of_Turkey_7-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Population_of_Turkey_7-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://data.tuik.gov.tr/Bulten/Index?p=The-Results-of-Address-Based-Population-Registration-System-2025-53899&amp;dil=2">"The Results of Address Based Population Registration System, 2025"</a>. <i>www.tuik.gov.tr</i>. <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Statistical_Institute" title="Turkish Statistical Institute">Turkish Statistical Institute</a>. 9 February 2026<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite&#95;note-HDI-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-HDI_10-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://hdr.undp.org/system/files/documents/global-report-document/hdr2025reporten.pdf">"Human Development Report 2025"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme" title="United Nations Development Programme">United Nations Development Programme</a>. 6 May 2025. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20250506051232/https://hdr.undp.org/system/files/documents/global-report-document/hdr2025reporten.pdf">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 6 May 2025<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-cia-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-cia_13-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cia_13-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cia_13-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cia_13-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cia_13-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/turkey-turkiye/#people-and-society">"Turkey (Turkiye)"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">The World Factbook</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">19 May</span> 2024</span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+World+Factbook&amp;rft.atitle=Turkey+%28Turkiye%29&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cia.gov%2Fthe-world-factbook%2Fcountries%2Fturkey-turkiye%2F%23people-and-society&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, p.&#160;24</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><a href="#CITEREFSagonaZimansky2015">Sagona &amp; Zimansky 2015</a>, p.&#160;1</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, p.&#160;xv</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFMcMahonSteadman2012a">McMahon &amp; Steadman 2012a</a>, pp.&#160;3–12</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFMatthews2012">Matthews 2012</a>, p.&#160;49</li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><a href="#CITEREFAhmed2006">Ahmed 2006</a>, p.&#160;1576: "Turkey's diversity is derived from its central location near the world's earliest civilizations as well as a history replete with population movements and invasions. The Hattite culture was prominent during the Bronze Age prior to 2000 BCE, but was replaced by the Indo-European Hittites who conquered Anatolia by the second millennium. Meanwhile, Turkish Thrace came to be dominated by another Indo-European group, the Thracians for whom the region is named."</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><a href="#CITEREFSteadman2012">Steadman 2012</a>, p.&#160;234: "By the time of the Old Assyrian Colony period in the early second millennium b.c.e . (see Michel, chapter 13 in this volume) the languages spoken on the plateau included Hattian, an indigenous Anatolian language, Hurrian (spoken in northern Syria), and Indo-European languages known as Luwian, Hittite, and Palaic"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFMichel2012">Michel 2012</a>, p.&#160;327</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFMelchert2012">Melchert 2012</a>, p.&#160;713</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, p.&#160;26</li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, p.&#160;29: "The sudden disappearance of the Persian Empire and the conquest of virtually the entire Middle Eastern world from the Nile to the Indus by Alexander the Great caused tremendous political and cultural upheaval.<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>[...] statesmen throughout the conquered regions attempted to implement a policy of Hellenization. For indigenous elites, this amounted to the forced assimilation of native religion and culture to Greek models. It met resistance in Anatolia as elsewhere, especially from priests and others who controlled temple wealth."</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><a href="#CITEREFAhmed2006">Ahmed 2006</a>, p.&#160;1576: "Subsequently, hellenization of the elites transformed Anatolia into a largely Greek-speaking region"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFMcMahonSteadman2012a">McMahon &amp; Steadman 2012a</a>, p.&#160;5</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFMcMahon2012">McMahon 2012</a>, p.&#160;16</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFSams2012">Sams 2012</a>, p.&#160;617</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFKaldellis2024">Kaldellis 2024</a>, p.&#160;26</li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><a href="#CITEREFDavison1990">Davison 1990</a>, pp.&#160;3–4: "So the Seljuk sultanate was a successor state ruling part of the medieval Greek empire, and within it the process of Turkification of a previously Hellenized Anatolian population continued. That population must already have been of very mixed ancestry, deriving from ancient Hittite, Phrygian, Cappadocian, and other civilizations as well as Roman and Greek."</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, pp.&#160;33–44</li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Howard&#95;2016&#95;38–39-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Howard_2016_38–39_19-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Howard_2016_38–39_19-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, pp.&#160;38–39</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, p.&#160;45</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><a href="#CITEREFSomel2010">Somel 2010</a>, p.&#160;xcvii</li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-21">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><a href="#CITEREFHanioğlu2012">Hanioğlu 2012</a>, pp.&#160;15–25</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><a href="#CITEREFKayalı2012">Kayalı 2012</a>, pp.&#160;26–28</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFDavison1990">Davison 1990</a>, pp.&#160;115–116</li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><a href="#CITEREFKaser2011">Kaser 2011</a>, p.&#160;336: "The emerging Christian nation states justified the prosecution of their Muslims by arguing that they were their former "suppressors". The historical balance: between about 1820 and 1920, millions of Muslim casualties and refugees back to the remaining Ottoman Empire had to be registered; estimations speak about 5 million casualties and the same number of displaced persons"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><a href="#CITEREFFábos2005">Fábos 2005</a>, p.&#160;437: "Muslims had been the majority in Anatolia, the Crimea, the Balkans, and the Caucasus and a plurality in southern Russia and sections of Romania. Most of these lands were within or contiguous with the Ottoman Empire. By 1923, 'only Anatolia, eastern Thrace, and a section of the southeastern Caucasus remained to the Muslim land<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>[...] Millions of Muslims, most of them Turks, had died; millions more had fled to what is today Turkey. Between 1821 and 1922, more than five million Muslims were driven from their lands. Five and one-half million Muslims died, some of them killed in wars, others perishing as refugees from starvation and disease' (McCarthy 1995, 1). Since people in the Ottoman Empire were classified by religion, Turks, Albanians, Bosnians, and all other Muslim groups were recognized—and recognized themselves—simply as Muslims. Hence, their persecution and forced migration is of central importance to an analysis of 'Muslim migration.'"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation journal cs1">Schayegh, Cyrus (2024). "A Late/Post-Imperial Region of Difference: The Ottoman Empire and its Successor Polities in Southeastern Europe, Turkey, and the Arab East, c. 1850s–1940s". <i>Journal of World History</i>. <b>35</b> (4): <span class="nowrap">579–</span>622. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1353%2Fjwh.2024.a943172">10.1353/jwh.2024.a943172</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/1527-8050">1527-8050</a>. <q>Between 1821 and the 1919–1922 Turko-Greek War, about five and a half million Muslims died of religious-ethnic war-related causes, including disease and hunger during forced migration, in southeastern Europe and the Crimea and Caucasus.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+World+History&amp;rft.atitle=A+Late%2FPost-Imperial+Region+of+Difference%3A+The+Ottoman+Empire+and+its+Successor+Polities+in+Southeastern+Europe%2C+Turkey%2C+and+the+Arab+East%2C+c.+1850s%E2%80%931940s&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=579-622&amp;rft.date=2024&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1353%2Fjwh.2024.a943172&amp;rft.issn=1527-8050&amp;rft.aulast=Schayegh&amp;rft.aufirst=Cyrus&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFKarpat2001">Karpat 2001</a>, p.&#160;343: "The main migrations started from Crimea in 1856 and were followed by those from the Caucasus and the Balkans in 1862 to 1878 and 1912 to 1916. These have continued to our day. The quantitative indicators cited in various sources show that during this period a total of about 7 million migrants from Crimea, the Caucasus, the Balkans, and the Mediterranean islands settled in Anatolia. These immigrants were overwhelmingly Muslim, except for a number of Jews who left their homes in the Balkans and Russia in order to live in the Ottoman lands. By the end of the century the immigrants and their descendants constituted some 30 to 40 percent of the total population of Anatolia, and in some western areas their percentage was even higher.<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>[...] The immigrants called themselves Muslims rather than Turks, although most of those from Bulgaria, Macedonia, and eastern Serbia descended from the Turkish Anatolian stock who settled in the Balkans in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries."</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFKarpat2004">Karpat 2004</a>, pp.&#160;5–6: "Migration was a major force in the social and cultural reconstruction of the Ottoman state in the nineteenth century. While some seven to nine million, mostly Muslim, refugees from lost territories in the Caucasus, Crimea, Balkans and Mediterranean islands migrated to Anatolia and Eastern Thrace, during the last quarter of the nineteenth and the early part of the twentieth centuries<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>[...]"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFPekesen2012">Pekesen 2012</a>: "The immigration had far-reaching social and political consequences for the Ottoman Empire and Turkey.<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>[...] Between 1821 and 1922, some 5.3 million Muslims migrated to the Empire.50 It is estimated that in 1923, the year the republic of Turkey was founded, about 25 per cent of the population came from immigrant families.51"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFBiondich2011">Biondich 2011</a>, p.&#160;93: "The road from Berlin to Lausanne was littered with millions of casualties. In the period between 1878 and 1912, as many as two million Muslims emigrated voluntarily or involuntarily from the Balkans. When one adds those who were killed or expelled between 1912 and 1923, the number of Muslim casualties from the Balkan far exceeds three million. By 1923 fewer than one million remained in the Balkans"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFArmour2012">Armour 2012</a>, p.&#160;213: "To top it all, the Empire was host to a steady stream of Muslim refugees. Russia between 1854 and 1876 expelled 1.4 million Crimean Tartars, and in the mid-1860s another 600,000 Circassians from the Caucasus. Their arrival produced further economic dislocation and expense."</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFBosmaLucassenOostindie2012a">Bosma, Lucassen &amp; Oostindie 2012a</a>, p.&#160;17: "In total, many millions of Turks (or, more precisely, Muslim immigrants, including some from the Caucasus) were involved in this 'repatriation' – sometimes more than once in a lifetime – the last stage of which may have been the immigration of seven hundred thousand Turks from Bulgaria between 1940 and 1990. Most of these immigrants settled in urban north-western Anatolia. Today between a third and a quarter of the Republic's population are descendants of these Muslim immigrants, known as Muhacir or Göçmen"</li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Tatz2-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Tatz2_23-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFTatzHiggins2016" class="citation book cs1">Tatz, Colin; Higgins, Winton (2016). <i>The Magnitude of Genocide</i>. ABC-CLIO. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4408-3161-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4408-3161-4"><bdi>978-1-4408-3161-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Magnitude+of+Genocide&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4408-3161-4&amp;rft.aulast=Tatz&amp;rft.aufirst=Colin&amp;rft.au=Higgins%2C+Winton&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-SchallerZimmerer-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-SchallerZimmerer_24-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFSchallerZimmerer2008" class="citation journal cs1">Schaller, Dominik J.; Zimmerer, Jürgen (2008). "Late Ottoman genocides: the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire and Young Turkish population and extermination policies – introduction". <i>Journal of Genocide Research</i>. <b>10</b> (1): <span class="nowrap">7–</span>14. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F14623520801950820">10.1080/14623520801950820</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/1462-3528">1462-3528</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:71515470">71515470</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Genocide+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Late+Ottoman+genocides%3A+the+dissolution+of+the+Ottoman+Empire+and+Young+Turkish+population+and+extermination+policies+%E2%80%93+introduction&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=7-14&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A71515470%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=1462-3528&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F14623520801950820&amp;rft.aulast=Schaller&amp;rft.aufirst=Dominik+J.&amp;rft.au=Zimmerer%2C+J%C3%BCrgen&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMorrisZe&#39;evi2021" class="citation book cs1">Morris, Benny; Ze'evi, Dror (2021). <i>The Thirty-Year Genocide - Turkey's Destruction of Its Christian Minorities, 1894–1924</i>. <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University_Press" title="Harvard University Press">Harvard University Press</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-674-25143-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-674-25143-4"><bdi>978-0-674-25143-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Thirty-Year+Genocide+-+Turkey%27s+Destruction+of+Its+Christian+Minorities%2C+1894%E2%80%931924&amp;rft.pub=Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2021&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-674-25143-4&amp;rft.aulast=Morris&amp;rft.aufirst=Benny&amp;rft.au=Ze%27evi%2C+Dror&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em;
