<li id="cite&#95;note-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-28">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFAtun2015" class="citation journal cs1">Atun, Rifat (2015). "Transforming Turkey's Health System — Lessons for Universal Coverage". <i>New England Journal of Medicine</i>. <b>373</b> (14): <span class="nowrap">1285–</span>1289. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1056%2FNEJMp1410433">10.1056/NEJMp1410433</a>. <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26422719">26422719</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=New+England+Journal+of+Medicine&amp;rft.atitle=Transforming+Turkey%27s+Health+System+%E2%80%94+Lessons+for+Universal+Coverage&amp;rft.volume=373&amp;rft.issue=14&amp;rft.pages=1285-1289&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1056%2FNEJMp1410433&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Apmid%2F26422719&amp;rft.aulast=Atun&amp;rft.aufirst=Rifat&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><a href="#CITEREFOECD_Taking_stock_of_education_reforms_for_access_and_quality_in_Türkiye2023">OECD Taking stock of education reforms for access and quality in Türkiye 2023</a>, p.&#160;35</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><a href="#CITEREFWorld_Intellectual_Property_Organization_(WIPO)2024">World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) 2024</a>, p.&#160;22</li></ul></div></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFBerg2023" class="citation book cs1">Berg, Miriam (2023). <i>Turkish Drama Serials: The Importance and Influence of a Globally Popular Television Phenomenon</i>. <li id="cite&#95;note-constantine&#95;vii-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-constantine_vii_37-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMoravcsik1967" class="citation book cs1">Moravcsik, Gyula, ed. (1967). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3al15wpFWiMC&amp;pg=PA65"><i>Constantine Porphyrogenitus: De Administrando Imperio</i></a>. Translated by R.J.H. Jenkins (New, revised&#160;ed.). Washington, D.C.: Dumbarton Oaks Center for Byzantine Studies. p.&#160;65. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-88402-021-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-88402-021-9"><bdi>978-0-88402-021-9</bdi></a> &#8211; via Google Books. <q>Patzinakia, the Pecheneg realm, stretches west as far as the Siret River (or even the Eastern Carpathian Mountains), and is four days distant from Tourkia [i.e. Hungary].</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Constantine+Porphyrogenitus%3A+De+Administrando+Imperio&amp;rft.place=Washington%2C+D.C.&amp;rft.pages=65&amp;rft.edition=New%2C+revised&amp;rft.pub=Dumbarton+Oaks+Center+for+Byzantine+Studies&amp;rft.date=1967&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-88402-021-9&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3al15wpFWiMC%26pg%3DPA65&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). <li id="cite&#95;note-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-42">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFReference-OED-Turkey" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1"><span class="id-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.oed.com/search/dictionary/?q=Turkey">"Turkey"</a></span>. <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i> (Online&#160;ed.). Oxford University Press.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Turkey&amp;rft.btitle=Oxford+English+Dictionary&amp;rft.edition=Online&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.oed.com%2Fsearch%2Fdictionary%2F%3Fq%3DTurkey&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span>&#32;<span style="font-size:0.95em; font-size:95%; color: var( --color-subtle, #555 )">(Subscription or <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.oed.com/public/login/loggingin#withyourlibrary">participating institution membership</a> required.)</span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-43"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-43">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFHertslet1875" class="citation book cs1">Hertslet, Edward (1875). "General treaty between Great Britain, Austria, France, Prussia, Russia, Sardinia and Turkey, signed at Paris on 30th March 1856". <i>The Map of Europe by Treaty showing the various political and territorial changes which have taken place since the general peace of 1814, with numerous maps and notes</i>. Vol.&#160;2. Butterworth. pp.&#160;<span class="nowrap">1250–</span>1265.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=General+treaty+between+Great+Britain%2C+Austria%2C+France%2C+Prussia%2C+Russia%2C+Sardinia+and+Turkey%2C+signed+at+Paris+on+30th+March+1856&amp;rft.btitle=The+Map+of+Europe+by+Treaty+showing+the+various+political+and+territorial+changes+which+have+taken+place+since+the+general+peace+of+1814%2C+with+numerous+maps+and+notes&amp;rft.pages=1250-1265&amp;rft.pub=Butterworth&amp;rft.date=1875&amp;rft.aulast=Hertslet&amp;rft.aufirst=Edward&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/protocolsofconfe00grea/mode/1up?view=theater"><i>Protocols of conferences held at Paris relative to the general Treaty of Peace. <li id="cite&#95;note-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-55">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFKılınçOmrakÖzerGünther2016" class="citation journal cs1">Kılınç, Gülşah Merve; et&#160;al. (2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5069350">"The Demographic Development of the First Farmers in Anatolia"</a>. <i>Current Biology</i>. <b>26</b> (19): <span class="nowrap">2659–</span>2666. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016CBio...26.2659K">2016CBio...26.2659K</a>. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="id-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1016%2Fj.cub.2016.07.057">10.1016/j.cub.2016.07.057</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a>&#160;<span class="id-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5069350">5069350</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27498567">27498567</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Current+Biology&amp;rft.atitle=The+Demographic+Development+of+the+First+Farmers+in+Anatolia&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=19&amp;rft.pages=2659-2666&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC5069350%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Apmid%2F27498567&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1016%2Fj.cub.2016.07.057&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Abibcode%2F2016CBio...26.2659K&amp;rft.aulast=K%C4%B1l%C4%B1n%C3%A7&amp;rft.aufirst=G%C3%BCl%C5%9Fah+Merve&amp;rft.au=Omrak%2C+Ay%C3%A7a&amp;rft.au=%C3%96zer%2C+F%C3%BCsun&amp;rft.au=G%C3%BCnther%2C+Torsten&amp;rft.au=B%C3%BCy%C3%BCkkarakaya%2C+Ali+Metin&amp;rft.au=B%C4%B1%C3%A7ak%C3%A7%C4%B1%2C+Erhan&amp;rft.au=Baird%2C+Douglas&amp;rft.au=D%C3%B6nerta%C5%9F%2C+Handan+Melike&amp;rft.au=Ghalichi%2C+Ayshin&amp;rft.au=Yaka%2C+Reyhan&amp;rft.au=Koptekin%2C+Dilek&amp;rft.au=A%C3%A7an%2C+Sinan+Can&amp;rft.au=Parvizi%2C+Poorya&amp;rft.au=Krzewi%C5%84ska%2C+Maja&amp;rft.au=Daskalaki%2C+Evangelia+A.&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC5069350&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" <li id="cite&#95;note-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-56">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFLipsonSzécsényi-NagyMallickPósa2017" class="citation journal cs1">Lipson, Mark; et&#160;al. (2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5973800">"Parallel palaeogenomic transects reveal complex genetic history of early European farmers"</a>. <i>Nature</i>. <b>551</b> (7680): <span class="nowrap">368–</span>372. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017Natur.551..368L">2017Natur.551..368L</a>. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" <li id="cite&#95;note-Howard&#95;2016-74"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Howard_2016_74-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Howard_2016_74-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Howard_2016_74-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Howard_2016_74-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Howard_2016_74-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Howard_2016_74-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, p.&#160;28</span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-Bryce&#95;2012&#95;pp369–370-75"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Bryce_2012_pp369–370_75-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Bryce_2012_pp369–370_75-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBryce2012">Bryce 2012</a>, pp.&#160;369–370: "The only clear evidence we have for significant Mycenaean settlement anywhere in the Near Eastern region is at Miletus on the southwestern Anatolian coast, at the mouth of the Maeander River, and at the site now called Müsgebi<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>[...]"</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Britannica-76"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Britannica_76-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Britannica_76-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Anatolia/Greek-colonies-on-the-Anatolian-coasts-c-1180-547-bce">"Anatolia – Greek colonies on the Anatolian coasts, c. 1180–547 bce"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclopedia_Britannica" class="mw-redirect" title="Encyclopedia Britannica">Encyclopedia Britannica</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230321122314/https://www.britannica.com/place/Anatolia/Greek-colonies-on-the-Anatolian-coasts-c-1180-547-bce">Archived</a> from the original on 21 March 2023<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 February</span> 2024</span>. <q>Before the Greek migrations that followed the end of the Bronze Age (c. 1200 BCE), probably the only Greek-speaking communities on the west coast of Anatolia were Mycenaean settlements at Iasus and Müskebi on the Halicarnassus peninsula and walled Mycenaean colonies at Miletus and Colophon.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclopedia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Anatolia+%E2%80%93+Greek+colonies+on+the+Anatolian+coasts%2C+c.+1180%E2%80%93547+bce&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Fplace%2FAnatolia%2FGreek-colonies-on-the-Anatolian-coasts-c-1180-547-bce&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-77"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-77">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHarl2012">Harl 2012</a>, p.&#160;760: "Greek cities on the shores of Asia Minor and on the Aegean islands were the nexus 
of trade and cultural exchange in the early Greek world, so Archaic Greek civilization was to a great extent the product of the Greek cities of Asia Minor."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-78">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHarl2012">Harl 2012</a>, pp.&#160;753–756</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-79">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGreaves2012">Greaves 2012</a>, p.&#160;505</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-80">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHarl2012">Harl 2012</a>, p.&#160;753</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-81">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHarl2012">Harl 2012</a>, pp.&#160;753–754</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-82">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMark&#95;Cartwright" class="citation web cs1">Mark Cartwright. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.worldhistory.org/Celsus_Library/">"Celsus Library"</a>. <a href="/wiki/World_History_Encyclopedia" title="World History Encyclopedia">World History Encyclopedia</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20240328151448/https://www.worldhistory.org/Library_of_Celsus/?arg1=Celsus_Library&amp;arg2=&amp;arg3=&amp;arg4=&amp;arg5=">Archived</a> from the original on 28 March 2024<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 February</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Celsus+Library&amp;rft.pub=World+History+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.au=Mark+Cartwright&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldhistory.org%2FCelsus&#95;Library%2F&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-83">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.worldhistory.org/article/128/">"The Temple of Artemis at Ephesus: The Un-Greek Temple and Wonder"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/World_History_Encyclopedia" title="World History Encyclopedia">World History Encyclopedia</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20240328151417/https://www.worldhistory.org/Temple_of_Artemis_at_Ephesus/">Archived</a> from the original on 28 March 2024<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 February</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=World+History+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Temple+of+Artemis+at+Ephesus%3A+The+Un-Greek+Temple+and+Wonder&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldhistory.org%2Farticle%2F128%2F&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-84">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMcMahonSteadman2012a">McMahon &amp; Steadman 2012a</a>, p.&#160;5</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-85">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMcMahon2012">McMahon 2012</a>, p.&#160;16</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-86">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSams2012">Sams 2012</a>, p.&#160;617</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Howard&#95;2016&#95;a-87"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Howard_2016_a_87-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, p.&#160;29: "The sudden disappearance of the Persian Empire and the conquest of virtually the entire Middle Eastern world from the Nile to the Indus by Alexander the Great caused tremendous political and cultural upheaval.<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>[...] statesmen throughout the conquered regions attempted to implement a policy of Hellenization. For indigenous elites, this amounted to the forced assimilation of native religion and culture to Greek models. It met resistance in Anatolia as elsewhere, especially from priests and others who controlled temple wealth."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-88"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-88">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, pp.&#160;28–29</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-89">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMitchell1995">Mitchell 1995</a>, pp.&#160;3–4</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, p.&#160;29</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-91"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-91">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHoyos2019">Hoyos 2019</a>, pp.&#160;35–37</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-92">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHoyos2019">Hoyos 2019</a>, pp.&#160;62, 83, 115</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-auto6-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-auto6_93-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-auto6_93-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHoward2016">Howard 2016</a>, p.&#160;30</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-94">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://global.britannica.com/topic/Hagia-Sophia">"Hagia Sophia"</a>. <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210429163151/https://global.britannica.com/topic/Hagia-Sophia">Archived</a> from the original on 29 April 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 February</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Hagia+Sophia&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fglobal.britannica.com%2Ftopic%2FHagia-Sophia&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Horrocks&#95;pp&#95;778-779-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Horrocks_pp_778-779_95-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Horrocks_pp_778-779_95-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHorrocks2008">Horrocks 2008</a>, pp.&#160;778–779: "Thus the majority of traditional 'Greek' lands, including the coastal areas of Asia Minor, remained essentially Greek-speaking, despite the superimposition of Latin and the later Slavic incursions into the Balkans during the sixth and seventh centuries. Even on the Anatolian plateau, where Hellenic culture had come only with Alexander's conquests, both the extremely heterogeneous indigenous populations and immigrant groups (including Celts, Goths, Jews, and Persians) had become heavily Hellenized, as the steady decline in epigraphic evidence for the native languages and the great mass of public and private inscriptions in Greek demonstrate. Though the disappearance of these languages from the written record did not entail their immediate abandonment as spoken languages<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>[...]"</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-96">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFvan_den_Hout2011">van den Hout 2011</a>, p.&#160;1</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Uchiyama&#95;et&#95;al&#95;2020-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Uchiyama_et_al_2020_97-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Uchiyama_et_al_2020_97-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFUchiyamaGillamSavelyevNing2020" class="citation journal cs1">Uchiyama, Junzo; et&#160;al. (2020). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2Fehs.2020.11">"Populations dynamics in Northern Eurasian forests: a long-term perspective from Northeast Asia"</a>. <i>Evolutionary Human Sciences</i>. <b>2</b> e16. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="id-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2Fehs.2020.11">10.1017/ehs.2020.11</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a>&#160;<span class="id-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10427466">10427466</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37588381">37588381</a>. <q>Most linguists and historians agree that Proto-Turkic, the common ancestor of all ancient and contemporary Turkic languages, must have been spoken somewhere in Central-East Asia</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Evolutionary+Human+Sciences&amp;rft.atitle=Populations+dynamics+in+Northern+Eurasian+forests%3A+a+long-term+perspective+from+Northeast+Asia&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.artnum=e16&amp;rft.date=2020&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC10427466%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Apmid%2F37588381&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2Fehs.2020.11&amp;rft.aulast=Uchiyama&amp;rft.aufirst=Junzo&amp;rft.au=Gillam%2C+J.+Christopher&amp;rft.au=Savelyev%2C+Alexander&amp;rft.au=Ning%2C+Chao&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1017%252Fehs.2020.11&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span> <i><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="//creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/" title="creativecommons:by/4.0/"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Creative_Commons_by_small.svg/120px-Creative_Commons_by_small.svg.png" decoding="async" width="80" height="15" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Creative_Commons_by_small.svg/250px-Creative_Commons_by_small.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="80" data-file-height="15" /></a></span>&#160;This article incorporates text&#32;from this source, which is available under the <a href="//creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/" class="extiw" title="creativecommons:by/4.0/">CC BY 4.0</a> license.</i></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-98"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-98">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><a href="#CITEREFLee2023">Lee 2023</a>, p.&#160;4: "It should also be noted that even the early Turkic peoples, including the Tiele and the Türks, were made up of heterogeneous elements. Importantly, DNA studies demonstrate that the expansion process of the Turkic peoples involved the Turkicization of various non-Turkic-speaking groups. The "Turks" intermixed with and Turkicized various indigenous groups across Eurasia: Uralic hunter-gatherers in northern Eurasia; Mongolic nomads in Mongolia; Indo-European-speaking nomads and sedentary populations in Xinjiang, Transoxiana, Iran, Kazakhstan, and South Siberia; and Indo-European elements (the Byzantine subjects, among others) in Anatolia and the Balkans.11"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><a href="#CITEREFFindley2005">Findley 2005</a>, p.&#160;18: "Moreover, Turks do not all physically look alike. They never did. The Turks of Turkey are famous for their range of physical types. Given the Turks' ancient Inner Asian origins, it is easy to imagine that they once presented a uniform Mongoloid appearance. Such traits seem to be more characteristic in the eastern Turkic world; however, uniformity of type can never have prevailed there either. Archeological evidence indicates that Indo-Europeans, or certainly Europoid physical types, inhabited the oases of the Tarim basin and even parts of Mongolia in ancient times. In the Tarim basin, persistence of these former inhabitants' genes among the modern Uyghurs is both observable and scientifically demonstrable.32 Early Chinese sources describe the Kirghiz as blue-eyed and blond or red-haired. The genesis of Turkic ethnic groups from earliest times occurred in confederations of diverse peoples. As if to prove the point, the earliest surviving texts in Turkic languages are studded with terms from other languages."</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFGolden2018" class="citation journal cs1">Golden, Peter B. (2018). "The Ethnogonic Tales of the Türks". <i>The Medieval History Journal</i>. <b>21</b> (2): <span class="nowrap">291–</span>327. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1177%2F0971945818775373">10.1177/0971945818775373</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/0971-9458">0971-9458</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:166026934">166026934</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Medieval+History+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=The+Ethnogonic+Tales+of+the+T%C3%BCrks&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=291-327&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A166026934%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=0971-9458&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1177%2F0971945818775373&amp;rft.aulast=Golden&amp;rft.aufirst=Peter+B.&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span> "Some DNA tests point to the Iranian connections of the Ashina and Ashide,133 highlighting further that the Turks as a whole 'were made up of heterogeneous and somatically dissimilar populations'.134 Geographically, the accounts cover the regions of Inner Mongolia, Gansu, Xinjiang, the Yenisei zone and the Altay, regions with Turkic, Indo-European (Iranian [Saka] and Tokharian), Yeniseic, Uralic and other populations. Wusun elements, like most steppe polities of an ethno-linguistic mix, may have also played a substratal role."</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFLeeKuang2017" class="citation journal cs1">Lee, Joo-Yup; Kuang, Shuntu (2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1163%2F22105018-12340089">"A Comparative Analysis of Chinese Historical Sources and Y-DNA Studies with Regard to the Early and Medieval Turkic Peoples"</a>. <i>Inner Asia</i>. <b>19</b> (2): <span class="nowrap">197–</span>239. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="id-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1163%2F22105018-12340089">10.1163/22105018-12340089</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/2210-5018">2210-5018</a>. <q>Both Chinese histories and modern dna studies indicate that the early and medieval Turkic peoples were made up of heterogeneous populations</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Inner+Asia&amp;rft.atitle=A+Comparative+Analysis+of+Chinese+Historical+Sources+and+Y-DNA+Studies+with+Regard+to+the+Early+and+Medieval+Turkic+Peoples&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=197-239&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1163%2F22105018-12340089&amp;rft.issn=2210-5018&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Joo-Yup&amp;rft.au=Kuang%2C+Shuntu&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1163%252F22105018-12340089&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Lee&#95;p84-99"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Lee_p84_99-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Lee_p84_99-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Lee_p84_99-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Lee_p84_99-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLee2023">Lee 2023</a>, p.&#160;84</span>
</li>

<li id="cite&#95;note-102"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-102">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLee2023">Lee 2023</a>, p.&#160;91</span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-103"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-103">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPeacock2015">Peacock 2015</a>, p.&#160;9</span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-Ahmed&#95;2006&#95;p1576&#95;h-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ahmed_2006_p1576_h_104-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFAhmed2006">Ahmed 2006</a>, p.&#160;1576: "Subsequently, hellenization of the elites transformed Anatolia into a largely Greek-speaking region"</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Davison&#95;1990&#95;p3&#95;4-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Davison_1990_p3_4_105-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Davison_1990_p3_4_105-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDavison1990">Davison 1990</a>, pp.&#160;3–4: "So the Seljuk sultanate was a successor state ruling part of the medieval Greek empire, and within it the process of Turkification of a previously Hellenized Anatolian population continued. That population must already have been of very mixed ancestry, deriving from ancient Hittite, Phrygian, Cappadocian, and other civilizations as well as Roman and Greek."</span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-nytimes-127"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-nytimes_127-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFSimons1993" class="citation news cs1">Simons, Marlise (22 August 1993). <span class="id-lock-limited" title="Free access subject to limited trial, subscription normally required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/1993/08/22/travel/center-of-ottoman-power.html">"Center of Ottoman Power"</a></span>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180712043016/https://www.nytimes.com/1993/08/22/travel/center-of-ottoman-power.html">Archived</a> from the original on 12 July 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite&#95;note-Bloxham2005-148"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Bloxham2005_148-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFDonald&#95;Bloxham2005" class="citation book cs1">Donald Bloxham (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=TSRkGNoEPFwC&amp;pg=PA150"><i>The Great Game of Genocide: Imperialism, Nationalism, And the Destruction of the Ottoman Armenians</i></a>. Oxford University Press. p.&#160;150. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-927356-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-927356-0"><bdi>978-0-19-927356-0</bdi></a> &#8211; via Google Books.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Great+Game+of+Genocide%3A+Imperialism%2C+Nationalism%2C+And+the+Destruction+of+the+Ottoman+Armenians&amp;rft.pages=150&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-927356-0&amp;rft.au=Donald+Bloxham&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DTSRkGNoEPFwC%26pg%3DPA150&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-Levene-149"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Levene_149-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFLevene1998" class="citation journal cs1">Levene, Mark (Winter 1998). <li id="cite&#95;note-BoweringCrone2012-159"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-BoweringCrone2012_159-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFGerhard&#95;BoweringPatricia&#95;CroneWadad&#95;KadiDevin&#95;J.&#95;Stewart2012" class="citation book cs1">Gerhard Bowering; Patricia Crone; Wadad Kadi; Devin J. <li id="cite&#95;note-164"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-164">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMacFie1989" class="citation journal cs1">MacFie, A.L. (1989). "The Turkish straits in the second world war, 1939–45". <i>Middle Eastern Studies</i>. <b>25</b> (2): <span class="nowrap">238–</span>248. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F00263208908700778">10.1080/00263208908700778</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/0026-3206">0026-3206</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Middle+Eastern+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=The+Turkish+straits+in+the+second+world+war%2C+1939%E2%80%9345&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=238-248&amp;rft.date=1989&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F00263208908700778&amp;rft.issn=0026-3206&amp;rft.aulast=MacFie&amp;rft.aufirst=A.L.&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-Kuzucuoğlu&#95;2019&#95;p7-183"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Kuzucuoğlu_2019_p7_183-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Kuzucuoğlu_2019_p7_183-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Kuzucuoğlu_2019_p7_183-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKuzucuoğlu2019">Kuzucuoğlu 2019</a>, p.&#160;7</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-anatolia&#95;definition-184"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-anatolia_definition_184-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><a href="#CITEREFWaskey2005">Waskey 2005</a>, p.&#160;922: "Thrace, its European area, is about the size of VERMONT at 9,412 square mi (24,378 square km). Its Asian area (Asia Minor) is called Anatolia and covers 291,971 square mi (756,202 square km)"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><a href="#CITEREFAkbulutBayarıAkbulutÖzyurt2022">Akbulut et al. 2022</a>, p.&#160;853: "About 97% of the country is in Asia Minor (Anatolia) and 3% in Europe (Thrace)"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/turkey-turkiye/#geography">"Turkey (Turkiye) &#124; Geography - note"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">The World Factbook</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 May</span> 2024</span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+World+Factbook&amp;rft.atitle=Turkey+%28Turkiye%29+%26%23124%3B+Geography+-+note&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cia.gov%2Fthe-world-factbook%2Fcountries%2Fturkey-turkiye%2F%23geography&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span>: "the 97% of the country in Asia is referred to as Anatolia"</li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Anatolia">"Anatolia"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclopedia_Britannica" class="mw-redirect" title="Encyclopedia Britannica">Encyclopedia Britannica</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite&#95;note-201"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-201">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.indyturk.com/node/703981/r%C3%B6portaj/profes%C3%B6r-mustafa-erdik-t%C3%BCrkiyede-imar-bar%C4%B1%C5%9F%C4%B1-olmasayd%C4%B1-da-%C3%A7ok-%C5%9Fey-de%C4%9Fi%C5%9Fmezdi">"Profesör Mustafa Erdik: Türkiye'de imar barışı olmasaydı da çok şey değişmezdi"</a>. <i>Independent Türkçe</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20240406122353/https://www.indyturk.com/node/703981/r%C3%B6portaj/profes%C3%B6r-mustafa-erdik-t%C3%BCrkiyede-imar-bar%C4%B1%C5%9F%C4%B1-olmasayd%C4%B1-da-%C3%A7ok-%C5%9Fey-de%C4%9Fi%C5%9Fmezdi">Archived</a> from the original on 6 April 2024.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Independent+T%C3%BCrk%C3%A7e&amp;rft.atitle=Profes%C3%B6r+Mustafa+Erdik%3A+T%C3%BCrkiye%27de+imar+bar%C4%B1%C5%9F%C4%B1+olmasayd%C4%B1+da+%C3%A7ok+%C5%9Fey+de%C4%9Fi%C5%9Fmezdi&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.indyturk.com%2Fnode%2F703981%2Fr%25C3%25B6portaj%2Fprofes%25C3%25B6r-mustafa-erdik-t%25C3%25BCrkiyede-imar-bar%25C4%25B1%25C5%259F%25C4%25B1-olmasayd%25C4%25B1-da-%25C3%25A7ok-%25C5%259Fey-de%25C4%259Fi%25C5%259Fmezdi&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-Taşoğlu&#95;Öztürk&#95;Yazıcı&#95;2024-216"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Taşoğlu_Öztürk_Yazıcı_2024_216-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Taşoğlu_Öztürk_Yazıcı_2024_216-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFTaşoğluÖztürkYazıcı2024" class="citation journal cs1">Taşoğlu, Enes; Öztürk, Muhammed Zeynel; Yazıcı, Öznur (2024). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1002%2Fjoc.8635">"High Resolution Köppen-Geiger Climate Zones of Türkiye"</a>. <i>International Journal of Climatology</i>. <b>44</b> (14): <span class="nowrap">5248–</span>5265. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2024IJCli..44.5248T">2024IJCli..44.5248T</a>. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="id-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1002%2Fjoc.8635">10.1002/joc.8635</a></span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Climatology&amp;rft.atitle=High+Resolution+K%C3%B6ppen-Geiger+Climate+Zones+of+T%C3%BCrkiye&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=14&amp;rft.pages=5248-5265&amp;rft.date=2024&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1002%2Fjoc.8635&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Abibcode%2F2024IJCli..44.5248T&amp;rft.aulast=Ta%C5%9Fo%C4%9Flu&amp;rft.aufirst=Enes&amp;rft.au=%C3%96zt%C3%BCrk%2C+Muhammed+Zeynel&amp;rft.au=Yaz%C4%B1c%C4%B1%2C+%C3%96znur&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1002%252Fjoc.8635&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-:1-217"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:1_217-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:1_217-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFSelekTuncokSelek2018" class="citation journal cs1">Selek, Bulent; Tuncok, Kaan; Selek, Zeliha (March 2018). "Changes in climate zones across Turkey". <i>Journal of Water and Climate Change</i>. <b>9</b> (1): <span class="nowrap">178–</span>195. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.2166%2Fwcc.2017.121">10.2166/wcc.2017.121</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/2040-2244">2040-2244</a>. <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><a href="/wiki/ProQuest" title="ProQuest">ProQuest</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.proquest.com/docview/2021148526">2021148526</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Water+and+Climate+Change&amp;rft.atitle=Changes+in+climate+zones+across+Turkey&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=178-195&amp;rft.date=2018-03&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2166%2Fwcc.2017.121&amp;rft.issn=2040-2244&amp;rft.aulast=Selek&amp;rft.aufirst=Bulent&amp;rft.au=Tuncok%2C+Kaan&amp;rft.au=Selek%2C+Zeliha&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-218"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-218">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFKomuscu2022" class="citation journal cs1">Komuscu, Ali Umran (2022). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.2166%2Fwcc.2022.186">"Dynamics of precipitation regions of Turkey: A clustering approach by K-means methodology in respect of climate variability"</a>. <i>Journal of Water and <li id="cite&#95;note-251"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-251">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFGiedraityte2023" class="citation journal cs1">Giedraityte, Ieva (2023). <li id="cite&#95;note-252"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-252">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMesquitaChien2021" class="citation journal cs1">Mesquita, Rafael; Chien, Jia Huei (2021). "Do regional powers prioritise their regions? Comparing Brazil, South Africa and Turkey". <i>Third World Quarterly</i>. <b>42</b> (7): <span class="nowrap">1544–</span>1565. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F01436597.2021.1898280">10.1080/01436597.2021.1898280</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/1360-2241">1360-2241</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Third+World+Quarterly&amp;rft.atitle=Do+regional+powers+prioritise+their+regions%3F+Comparing+Brazil%2C+South+Africa+and+Turkey&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.pages=1544-1565&amp;rft.date=2021&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F01436597.2021.1898280&amp;rft.issn=1360-2241&amp;rft.aulast=Mesquita&amp;rft.aufirst=Rafael&amp;rft.au=Chien%2C+Jia+Huei&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-253"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-253">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBankKaradag2012">Bank &amp; Karadag 2012</a>, p.&#160;3</span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-Bianet&#95;–&#95;Bagimsiz&#95;Iletisim&#95;Agi-310"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Bianet_–_Bagimsiz_Iletisim_Agi_310-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Bianet_–_Bagimsiz_Iletisim_Agi_310-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Bianet_–_Bagimsiz_Iletisim_Agi_310-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.bianet.org/english/lgbti/209921-police-attack-with-shields-pepper-gas-after-pride-parade-statement-read">"17th İstanbul LGBTI+ Pride Parade: Police Attack with Shields, Pepper Gas After Pride Parade Statement Read"</a>. <i>Bianet – Bagimsiz Iletisim Agi</i>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Bianet+%E2%80%93+Bagimsiz+Iletisim+Agi&amp;rft.atitle=17th+%C4%B0stanbul+LGBTI%2B+Pride+Parade%3A+Police+Attack+with+Shields%2C+Pepper+Gas+After+Pride+Parade+Statement+Read&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bianet.org%2Fenglish%2Flgbti%2F209921-police-attack-with-shields-pepper-gas-after-pride-parade-statement-read&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-311"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-311">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFOzsoy2021" class="citation journal cs1">Ozsoy, Elif Ceylan (2021). <li id="cite&#95;note-325"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-325">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist" style="display:inline;"><ul style="display:inline;"><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;display:inline; margin:0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://worldsteel.org/data/annual-production-steel-data/?ind=P1_crude_steel_total_pub/CHN/IND">"Total production of crude steel"</a>. <i>The World Steel Association</i>. 22 March 2024.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+World+Steel+Association&amp;rft.atitle=Total+production+of+crude+steel&amp;rft.date=2024-03-22&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fworldsteel.org%2Fdata%2Fannual-production-steel-data%2F%3Find%3DP1&#95;crude&#95;steel&#95;total&#95;pub%2FCHN%2FIND&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></li><li style="margin-bottom:.5em; display:block;;margin-top:.5em;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230408125523/https://www.oica.net/category/production-statistics/2022-statistics/">"2022 Production Statistics"</a>. <i>oica.net</i>. <li id="cite&#95;note-341"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-341">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230508085807/https://www.worldbank.org/en/results/2019/04/12/30-years-of-world-bank-group-partnership-with-turkey-achieving-development-results-together">"30 Years of World Bank Group Partnership with Turkey: Achieving Development Results Together"</a>. <i>World Bank</i>. <li id="cite&#95;note-361"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-361">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/iraq-turkey-qatar-uae-sign-preliminary-deal-cooperate-development-road-project-2024-04-22/">"Iraq, Turkey, Qatar, UAE sign preliminary deal to cooperate on Development Road project"</a>. <i>Reuters</i>. 22 April 2024.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Reuters&amp;rft.atitle=Iraq%2C+Turkey%2C+Qatar%2C+UAE+sign+preliminary+deal+to+cooperate+on+Development+Road+project&amp;rft.date=2024-04-22&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.reuters.com%2Fworld%2Fmiddle-east%2Firaq-turkey-qatar-uae-sign-preliminary-deal-cooperate-development-road-project-2024-04-22%2F&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-396"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-396">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFKöksal2006" class="citation journal cs1">Köksal, Yonca (2006). "Minority Policies in Bulgaria and Turkey: The Struggle to Define a Nation". <i>Southeast European and Black Sea Studies</i>. <b>6</b> (4): <span class="nowrap">501–</span>521. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F14683850601016390">10.1080/14683850601016390</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/1468-3857">1468-3857</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:153761516">153761516</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Southeast+European+and+Black+Sea+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=Minority+Policies+in+Bulgaria+and+Turkey%3A+The+Struggle+to+Define+a+Nation&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=501-521&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A153761516%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=1468-3857&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F14683850601016390&amp;rft.aulast=K%C3%B6ksal&amp;rft.aufirst=Yonca&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-Özlem2019-397"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Özlem2019_397-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFÖzlem2019" class="citation journal cs1">Özlem, Kader (2019). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ceeol.com/search/article-detail?id=802933">"An Evaluation on Istanbul's Bulgarians as the "Invisible Minority" of Turkey"</a>. <i>Turan-Sam</i>. <b>11</b> (43): <span class="nowrap">387–</span>393. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/1308-8041">1308-8041</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Turan-Sam&amp;rft.atitle=An+Evaluation+on+Istanbul%27s+Bulgarians+as+the+%22Invisible+Minority%22+of+Turkey&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=43&amp;rft.pages=387-393&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rft.issn=1308-8041&amp;rft.aulast=%C3%96zlem&amp;rft.aufirst=Kader&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ceeol.com%2Fsearch%2Farticle-detail%3Fid%3D802933&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Toktaş2009-399"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Toktaş2009_399-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Toktaş2009_399-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFToktaşAraş2009" class="citation journal cs1">Toktaş, Şule; Araş, Bulent (2009). "The EU and Minority Rights in Turkey". <i>Political Science Quarterly</i>. <b>124</b> (4): <span class="nowrap">697–</span>720. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1002%2Fj.1538-165X.2009.tb00664.x">10.1002/j.1538-165X.2009.tb00664.x</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/0032-3195">0032-3195</a>. <a href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/25655744">25655744</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Political+Science+Quarterly&amp;rft.atitle=The+EU+and+Minority+Rights+in+Turkey&amp;rft.volume=124&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=697-720&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.issn=0032-3195&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F25655744%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1002%2Fj.1538-165X.2009.tb00664.x&amp;rft.aulast=Tokta%C5%9F&amp;rft.aufirst=%C5%9Eule&amp;rft.au=Ara%C5%9F%2C+Bulent&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Yağmur2001-400"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Yağmur2001_400-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Yağmur2001_400-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Yağmur2001_400-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFYağmur2001" class="citation book cs1">Yağmur, Kutlay (2001). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=hvmy_skUPNYC&amp;pg=PA407">"Languages in Turkey"</a>. In Extra, G.; Gorter, D. (eds.). <i>The Other Languages of Europe: Demographic, Sociolinguistic and Educational Perspectives</i>. Clevedon, UK: Multilingual Matters. pp.&#160;<span class="nowrap">407–</span>427. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-85359-510-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-85359-510-3"><bdi>978-1-85359-510-3</bdi></a> &#8211; via Google Books. <q><span class="cs1-kern-left"></span>'Mother tongue' education is mostly limited to Turkish teaching in Turkey. No other language can be taught as a mother tongue other than Armenian, Greek, and Hebrew, as agreed in the Lausanne Treaty<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>[...] Like Jews and Greeks, Armenians enjoy the privilege of an officially recognized minority status.<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>[...] No language other than Turkish can be taught at schools or at cultural centers. Only Armenian, Greek, and Hebrew are exceptions to this constitutional rule.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Languages+in+Turkey&amp;rft.btitle=The+Other+Languages+of+Europe%3A+Demographic%2C+Sociolinguistic+and+Educational+Perspectives&amp;rft.place=Clevedon%2C+UK&amp;rft.pages=407-427&amp;rft.pub=Multilingual+Matters&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-85359-510-3&amp;rft.aulast=Ya%C4%9Fmur&amp;rft.aufirst=Kutlay&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dhvmy&#95;skUPNYC%26pg%3DPA407&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Zetler2014-401"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Zetler2014_401-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Zetler2014_401-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Zetler2014_401-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFZetler2014" class="citation journal cs1">Zetler, Reyhan (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.sagw.ch/fileadmin/redaktion_judaistik/dokumente/Judaistik/2014/III.%20R.%20Zetler%20-%20Bulletin%20SGJF%20Nr.%2023%20%282014%29.pdf">"Turkish Jews between 1923 and 1933 – What Did the Turkish Policy between 1923 and 1933 Mean for the Turkish Jews?"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Bulletin der Schweizerischen Gesellschaft für Judaistische Forschung</i> (23): 26. <a href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/oclc/865002828">865002828</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Bulletin+der+Schweizerischen+Gesellschaft+f%C3%BCr+Judaistische+Forschung&amp;rft.atitle=Turkish+Jews+between+1923+and+1933+%E2%80%93+What+Did+the+Turkish+Policy+between+1923+and+1933+Mean+for+the+Turkish+Jews%3F&amp;rft.issue=23&amp;rft.pages=26&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F865002828&amp;rft.aulast=Zetler&amp;rft.aufirst=Reyhan&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.sagw.ch%2Ffileadmin%2Fredaktion&#95;judaistik%2Fdokumente%2FJudaistik%2F2014%2FIII.%2520R.%2520Zetler%2520-%2520Bulletin%2520SGJF%2520Nr.%252023%2520%25282014%2529.pdf&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-Akbulut2023-403"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Akbulut2023_403-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Akbulut2023_403-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFAkbulut2023" class="citation journal cs1">Akbulut, Olgun (19 October 2023). <li id="cite&#95;note-Roopnarine2015-405"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Roopnarine2015_405-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFJaipaul&#95;L.&#95;Roopnarine2015" class="citation book cs1">Jaipaul L. <li id="cite&#95;note-431"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-431">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFİçduyguToktaşAli&#95;Soner2008" class="citation journal cs1">İçduygu, Ahmet; Toktaş, Şule; Ali Soner, B. (1 February 2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.academia.edu/761694">"The politics of population in a nation-building process: Emigration of non-Muslims from Turkey"</a>. <i>Ethnic and Racial Studies</i>. <b>31</b> (2): <span class="nowrap">358–</span>389. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F01419870701491937">10.1080/01419870701491937</a>. <a href="/wiki/Hdl_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hdl (identifier)">hdl</a>:<span class="id-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://hdl.handle.net/11729%2F308">11729/308</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:143541451">143541451</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Ethnic+and+Racial+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=The+politics+of+population+in+a+nation-building+process%3A+Emigration+of+non-Muslims+from+Turkey&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=358-389&amp;rft.date=2008-02-01&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Ahdl%2F11729%2F308&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A143541451%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F01419870701491937&amp;rft.aulast=%C4%B0%C3%A7duygu&amp;rft.aufirst=Ahmet&amp;rft.au=Tokta%C5%9F%2C+%C5%9Eule&amp;rft.au=Ali+Soner%2C+B.&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.academia.edu%2F761694&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-497"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-497">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFÇakır&#95;Morin2013" class="citation news cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source">Çakır Morin, Arzu (5 December 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/kultur-sanat/25284675.asp">"Türk kahvesi Unesco korumasında"</a>. <i>Hürriyet</i> (in Turkish)<span class="reference-accessdate">. </div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2"><div>
<ul><li><sup>1</sup> Spans the conventional boundary between Europe and another continent.</li>
<li><sup>2</sup> Considered European for cultural, political and historical reasons but is geographically in Western Asia.</li>
<li><sup>3</sup> <a href="/wiki/Island#Oceanic_islands" title="Island">Oceanic islands</a> within the vicinity of Europe are usually grouped with the continent even though they are not situated on its continental shelf.</li>
<li><sup>4</sup> Governed by the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> which has sovereignty over Vatican City.</li></ul>

<ul><li><span class="flagicon nowrap"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Flag_of_Azerbaijan.svg/40px-Flag_of_Azerbaijan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Flag_of_Azerbaijan.svg/60px-Flag_of_Azerbaijan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a></li>
